July 29, 2011
To:
The Securityholders of ECU Silver Mining Inc. (“ECU”)
The board of directors (the “ECU Board”) of ECU invites you to attend a special meeting (the “Meeting”) of the 
holders (collectively, the “ECU Securityholders”) of outstanding: (i) common shares of ECU (“ECU Shares”, and 
the  holders  thereof,  the  “ECU Shareholders”);  (ii)  options  to  purchase  ECU  Shares  (“ECU Options”,  and  the 
holders thereof, the “ECU Optionholders”); (iii) warrants exercisable to acquire ECU Shares (“ECU Warrants”, 
and the holders thereof, the “ECU Warrantholders”); and (iv) 0.0% convertible senior unsecured notes due June 
30,  2012  of  ECU  (the  “ECU  Convertible  Notes”,  and  the  holder  thereof,  the  “ECU  Convertible  Noteholder”) 
(ECU Shares, ECU Options, ECU Warrants and ECU Convertible Notes are collectively, “ECU Securities”), to be 
held at 11:00 a.m. (Eastern Time) on August 30, 2011 at the Crescent Room of Hôtel Le Crystal, 1100 rue de la 
Montagne, Montreal, Québec H3G 0A1.
On  June  24,  2011,  ECU  entered  into  an  arrangement  agreement  (the  “Arrangement  Agreement”)  with  Golden 
Minerals  Company  (“Golden”)  whereby,  subject  to  the  terms  and  conditions  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement, 
Golden will acquire all of the outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants, and the ECU Convertible 
Notes will be replaced with non-convertible notes, pursuant to an arrangement under the Business Corporations Act
(Québec) (the  “Arrangement”). Assuming the  Arrangement becomes effective: (a) the  ECU Shareholders (other 
than  dissenting  shareholders  and  Golden)  will  receive  0.05  (the  “Exchange  Ratio”)  shares  of  common  stock  of 
Golden (“Golden  Stock”) and Cdn$0.000394 in cash for  each ECU  Share  held; (b) the ECU Optionholders  will 
receive  options  to  acquire  Golden  Stock  (“Golden  Replacement  Options”)  and  the  ECU  Warrantholders  will 
receive warrants to acquire Golden Stock (“Golden Replacement Warrants”) in replacement of their outstanding 
ECU Options and ECU Warrants, as applicable, in each case exercisable to acquire that number of shares of Golden 
Stock  that  such  holders  would  have  acquired  if  they  had  exercised  their  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants,  as 
applicable, immediately prior to the effective time of the Arrangement and had received ECU Shares in exchange 
therefor,  with  the  exercise  price  of  the  Golden  Replacement  Options  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  being 
adjusted  based  on  the  Exchange  Ratio;  (c)  the  ECU  Convertible  Noteholder  will  receive  notes  of  ECU  in 
replacement of its outstanding ECU Convertible Notes that are identical to the ECU Convertible Notes except that 
they will not be convertible into ECU Shares; and (d) the current shareholder rights plan of ECU will be terminated 
and  all  rights  issued  pursuant  thereto  will  expire,  all  as  more  particularly  described  in  the  accompanying 
management  information  circular  of  ECU  dated  July  29,  2011  (the  “Circular”).    At  the  Meeting,  the  ECU 
Securityholders will be asked to approve the Arrangement.
After  careful  consideration  of  various  factors  described  more  fully  in  the  Circular,  including  a  fairness 
opinion  issued  by  Stonecap  Securities  Inc.,  a  Canadian  registered  investment  dealer,  and  following 
consultation  with  its  financial  and  legal  advisors,  the  ECU  Board  has  unanimously  determined  that  the 
Arrangement is in the best interests of ECU and is fair to the ECU Securityholders from a financial point of 
view.  Accordingly, the ECU Board unanimously recommends that ECU Securityholders (other than Golden 
and its affiliates, for which no recommendation is provided) vote FOR the Arrangement.
The ECU Board believes that the combined company resulting from the Arrangement will be a new leading junior 
silver mining company with an attractive portfolio of assets in Mexico, Argentina and Peru, with increased leverage 
to silver and gold and with significant credits to zinc and lead. The ECU Board believes the combined company will 
have greater scale and financial strength to advance the expansion and development of current mining properties, 
and improved access to global capital markets to assist future growth efforts. The Arrangement would combine the 
complementary  management  teams  of  ECU  and  Golden,  whose  proven  track  records  of  success  are  expected  to 
result in the enhancement and expansion of the portfolio of assets of the combined company.
To be effective, the Arrangement must be approved by a resolution (the “Arrangement Resolution”) passed by: (a) 
at least 66 2/3% of the votes cast by ECU Shareholders present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and
entitled to vote; (b) at least 66 2/3% of the votes cast by all ECU Securityholders, voting together as a single class, 
present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to vote; and (c) a simple majority of the votes 
cast by ECU Shareholders present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to vote, excluding 
the votes cast in respect of ECU Shares beneficially owned or over which control or direction is exercised by Mr. 
Michel Roy, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of ECU, and Mr. Stephen J. Altmann, President of ECU, and by 
their respective related parties or joint actors.  ECU Shareholders, ECU Optionholders and ECU Warrantholders are 
entitled to one vote for each ECU Share, ECU Option or ECU Warrant, as applicable, held by them, and the ECU 
Convertible Noteholder is entitled to such number of votes as is equal to the number of ECU Shares into which the 
ECU Convertible Notes held by it are convertible.  The directors and officers of ECU have entered into a voting 
agreement with Golden, whereby they have agreed to vote their ECU Securities in favour of the Arrangement.  The 
Arrangement is also subject to approval by the Superior Court of Québec and to the  satisfaction of certain other 
conditions.
The accompanying Circular provides a description of the Arrangement and includes certain additional information 
to assist  you in considering how to  vote on the  Arrangement  Resolution. You are urged to read this information 
carefully and, if you require assistance, to consult your tax, financial, legal or other professional advisors.
ECU has engaged Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. to provide proxy solicitation services to ECU and to act as 
information  agent  to  provide  a  resource  for  information  for  ECU  Securityholders.  Questions  and  requests  for 
assistance  may  be  directed  to  Kingsdale  Shareholder  Services  Inc.  by  calling  toll  free  within  North  America  at

We  encourage  you  to  complete,  sign,  date  and  return  the  appropriate  accompanying  form  of  proxy,  or  voting 
instruction form, in accordance with the instructions set out therein and in the Circular so that your ECU Securities 
can be voted at the Meeting in accordance with your instructions. Note that there are five different forms of proxy 
for use in connection with the Meeting, one for voting each of the ECU Shares, the ECU Options, the two classes of 
ECU Warrants and the ECU Convertible Notes.
An  ECU  Securityholder may  attend  the  Meeting  in  person  or  may  be  represented  by  proxy.    ECU 
Securityholders who are unable to attend the Meeting or any adjournment or postponement thereof in person 
are requested to date, sign and return the appropriate accompanying form of proxy for use at the Meeting or 
any adjournment or postponement thereof.  To be effective, such proxy must be received by Computershare 
Investor Services Inc. by 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on August 26, 2011, or two Business Days prior to the time 
of the reconvening of any adjournment or postponement of the Meeting.
We  also  encourage  registered  holders  of  ECU  Shares  and  ECU  Warrants  to  complete,  sign,  date  and  return  the 
appropriate enclosed letter of transmittal in accordance with the instructions set out therein and in the Circular so 
that if the Arrangement is completed, the cash and shares of Golden Stock and the Golden Replacement Warrants, as 
the  case  may  be,  to  which  you  are  entitled  can  be  sent  to  you  as  soon  as  possible  following  completion  of  the 
Arrangement. Note that there are two different forms of letter of transmittal, one for ECU Shares (printed on blue 
paper) and one for ECU Warrants (printed on yellow paper).
If you hold ECU Securities through a broker, investment dealer, bank, trust company, trustee or other intermediary, 
please  follow  the  instructions  provided  by  your  intermediary  to  ensure  your  vote  is  counted  at  the  Meeting  and 
arrange for your intermediary to complete the necessary transmittal documents to ensure that you receive cash and 
Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants, as the case  may be, in exchange  for your ECU Securities if the 
proposed Arrangement is completed.
Subject to obtaining the approvals of the ECU Securityholders and the Superior Court of Québec, and to satisfying 
certain other conditions, the Arrangement is expected to close on or about September 2, 2011.
Yours very truly,

NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETING OF SECURITYHOLDERS
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that, pursuant to an interim order of the Superior Court of Québec dated July 14, 2011, 
as the same may be amended (the “Interim Order”), a special meeting (the “Meeting”) of the holders (collectively, the 
“ECU Securityholders”)  of  (i)  outstanding  common  shares  of  ECU  (“ECU Shares”,  and  the  holders  thereof,  the 
“ECU Shareholders”), (ii) outstanding options to purchase ECU Shares (“ECU Options”), (iii) outstanding warrants 
exercisable to acquire ECU Shares (“ECU Warrants”), and (iv) outstanding 0.0% convertible senior unsecured notes 
due June 30, 2012 of ECU (the “ECU Convertible Notes”, and together with the ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU 
Warrants, the “ECU Securities”), will be held at 11:00 a.m. (Eastern Time) on August 30, 2011 at the Crescent Room 
of Hôtel Le Crystal, 1100 rue de la Montagne, Montreal, Québec H3G 0A1, for the following purposes:
1.
2.
to consider and, if thought advisable, to pass a special resolution (the “Arrangement Resolution”) to approve 
a  plan  of  arrangement  (the  “Plan  of  Arrangement”)  involving  ECU,  the  ECU  Securityholders  and  Golden 
Minerals  Company  pursuant  to  Chapter  XVI  –  Division  II  of  the  Business  Corporations  Act  (Québec)  (the 
“QBCA”).    The  full  text  of  the  Arrangement  Resolution  is  set  forth  in  Appendix  A  to  the  accompanying 
management information circular dated July 29, 2011 (the “Circular”); and
to transact such further and other business as may properly be brought before the Meeting or any adjournment 
or postponement thereof.
Specific details of the matters proposed to be put before the Meeting are set forth in the Circular.
The record date for determining the ECU Securityholders entitled to receive notice of and vote at the Meeting is the 
close of business on July 26, 2011 (the “Record Date”).  Only ECU Securityholders whose names have been entered in 
the applicable register of ECU Securityholders as of 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on the Record Date are entitled to receive 
notice  of  and  vote  at  the  Meeting.    The  ECU  Securityholders  of  record  will  be  included  in  the  list  of  ECU 
Securityholders prepared as at the Record Date and will be entitled to vote the ECU Securities recorded therein at the 
Meeting.
An  ECU  Securityholder may  attend  the  Meeting  in  person  or  may  be  represented  by  proxy.    ECU 
Securityholders who are unable to attend the Meeting or any adjournment or postponement thereof in person 
are requested to date, sign and return the appropriate accompanying form of proxy for use at the Meeting or any 
adjournment or postponement thereof.  To be effective, such proxy must be received by Computershare Investor 
Services  Inc.  by  5:00  p.m.  (Eastern  Time)  on  August  26,  2011,  or  two  Business  Days  prior  to  the  time  of  the 
reconvening of any adjournment or postponement of the Meeting.
Please note that five different forms of proxy have been prepared for use in connection with the Meeting, one for 
voting each of: the ECU Shares, the ECU Options, the two classes of ECU Warrants and the ECU Convertible 
Notes.    ECU  Securityholders who  are  planning  to  return  the  appropriate  form(s)  of  proxy  are  encouraged to 
review the Circular carefully before submitting such form(s) of proxy.
If  you  are  an  unregistered  holder  of  ECU  Securities  and  have  received  these  materials  through  your  broker, 
investment dealer, bank, trust company, trustee or other intermediary, please complete and return the form of 
proxy  provided  to  you  by  your  broker  or  other  intermediary  in  accordance  with  the  instructions  provided 
therein.
Pursuant to the Interim Order, each registered ECU Shareholder as of the Record Date is entitled to exercise dissent 
rights in respect of the Plan of Arrangement and, if the Plan of Arrangement becomes effective, to receive the fair value 
of  such  holder’s  ECU  Shares,  in  accordance  with  the  QBCA as  modified  by  the  Interim  Order  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement.  To exercise such right, (a) a written notice of intent to exercise its right to demand the repurchase of its 
ECU  Shares  must  be  received  from  the  registered  ECU  Shareholder  by  ECU  at  its  registered  office  at  1116  ave.
Granada,  Rouyn-Noranda,  Québec  J9Y 1G9  no  later  than  5:00  p.m.  (Eastern  Time)  on  August  26,  2011,  or  two 
Business Days prior to the reconvening of any adjournment or postponement of the Meeting, (b) the ECU Shareholder 
must exercise all the voting rights carried by the ECU Shares held by such ECU Shareholder against the Arrangement 
Resolution, and (c) the ECU Shareholder must have otherwise complied with the provisions of the QBCA as modified 
by  the  Interim  Order  and  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  respecting  the  exercise  of  dissent  rights.    The  right  to  dissent  is 
described  in  the  Circular  and  the  text  of  the  Interim  Order  is  set  forth  in  Appendix  E  to  the  Circular.  For  greater 
certainty, there are no dissent rights with respect to ECU Options, ECU Warrants or ECU Convertible Notes.
Persons who are beneficial owners of ECU Shares registered in the name of a broker, investment dealer, bank, 
trust  company,  custodian,  nominee  or  other  intermediary  who  wish  to  dissent  should  be  aware  that  only 
registered holders of ECU Shares as of the Record Date are entitled to dissent rights.  Accordingly, a beneficial 
owner of ECU Shares desiring to exercise this right must make arrangements for the ECU Shares beneficially owned by 
such person to be registered in his, her or its name prior to the time the written notice of intention to exercise its dissent 
rights in respect of the Plan of Arrangement is required to be received by ECU or, alternatively, make arrangements for 
the registered holder of ECU Shares to exercise the dissent rights on his, her or its behalf. Failure to strictly comply 
with the requirements set forth in the QBCA, the Interim Order and the Plan of Arrangement may result in the 
loss of any dissent rights.
If you require any assistance in completing your proxy, please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. by calling 
toll free within North America at 1-877-659-1819 or collect outside North America at (416) 867-2272 or by e-mail at 
contactus@kingsdaleshareholder.com
DATED at Montreal, Québec this 29th day of July 2011.

NOTE TO UNITED STATES SECURITYHOLDERS
THE  GOLDEN  SECURITIES  AND  ECU  REPLACEMENT  NOTES  ISSUABLE  IN  CONNECTION  WITH  THE 
ARRANGEMENT HAVE NOT BEEN APPROVED OR DISAPPROVED BY THE UNITED STATES SECURITIES 
AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION OR SECURITIES REGULATORY AUTHORITIES IN ANY STATE, NOR HAS 
THE UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION OR THE SECURITIES REGULATORY
AUTHORITIES  OF  ANY  STATE  PASSED  UPON  THE  ADEQUACY  OR  ACCURACY  OF  THIS  CIRCULAR. 
ANY REPRESENTATION TO THE CONTRARY IS A CRIMINAL OFFENSE.
The  Golden  Stock,  Golden  Replacement  Options  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  to  be  issued  under  the 
Arrangement have not been registered under the U.S. Securities Act, and are being issued in reliance on the exemption 
from registration set forth in Section 3(a)(10) thereof on the basis of the approval of the Court, which will consider, 
among other things, the fairness of the terms and condition of the Arrangement to the ECU Securityholders.  The ECU 
Replacement  Notes  have  not  been  registered  under  the  U.S.  Securities  Act,  and  are  being  issued  in  reliance  on  the 
exemption from registration set forth in Section 3(a)(9) thereof.  See “Securities Laws Considerations – U.S. Securities 
Laws.”
Information  concerning  the  properties  and  operations  of  ECU  and  Golden  has  been  prepared  in  accordance  with 
Canadian standards under applicable Canadian Securities Laws, and may not be comparable to similar information for 
U.S.  companies.  The  terms  “mineral  resource”,  “measured  mineral  resource”,  “indicated  mineral  resource”  and 
“inferred mineral resource” used in this Circular or in ECU’s documents incorporated by reference herein are Canadian 
mining terms as defined in accordance with NI 43-101 under definitions and guidelines set out by the CIM in the CIM 
Standards.  While  the  terms  “mineral  resource”,  “measured  mineral  resource”,  “indicated  mineral  resource”  and 
“inferred mineral resource” are recognized and required by Canadian Securities Laws, they are not defined terms under 
standards  of  the  SEC.  As  such,  certain  information  contained  in  this  Circular  or  in  the  documents  incorporated  by 
reference herein concerning descriptions of mineralization and resources under Canadian standards is not comparable to 
similar information made public by U.S. companies subject to the reporting and disclosure requirements of the SEC. An 
“inferred  mineral  resource”  has  a  great  amount  of  uncertainty  as  to  its  existence  and  as  to  its  economic  and  legal 
feasibility. It cannot be assumed that all or any part of an “inferred mineral resource” will ever be upgraded to a higher 
category. Under Canadian Securities Laws, estimates of inferred mineral resources may not form the basis of feasibility 
or  other  economic  studies.  Investors  are  cautioned  not  to  assume  that  all  or  any  part  of  measured  mineral 
resources  or  indicated  mineral  resources  will  ever  be  converted  into  mineral  reserves.  Investors  are  also 
cautioned not to assume that all or any part of an inferred mineral resource exists, or is economically or legally 
mineable.
In addition, the definitions of “proven mineral reserve” and “probable mineral reserve” under CIM Standards differ in 
certain respects from the SEC standards.
ECU Securityholders should be aware that the acquisition of the securities described herein may have tax consequences 
both in the United States and in Canada. Such consequences for investors who are resident in, or citizens of, the United 
States  may  not  be  described  fully  herein.    See  “Certain  United  States  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations.”  U.S. 
securityholders should consult their own tax advisors with respect to their own particular circumstances.
The  solicitation  of  proxies  hereby  is  not  subject  to  the  proxy  requirements  of  Section  14(a)  of  the  U.S.  Securities 
Exchange Act. Accordingly, this Circular has been prepared in accordance with applicable disclosure requirements in 
Canada. ECU Securityholders in the United States should be aware that such requirements are different than those of the 
United States.
Certain  financial  statements  and  information  included  or  incorporated  by  reference  herein  have  been  prepared  in 
accordance  with  Canadian  GAAP  or  IFRS,  as  applicable,  and  are  subject  to  auditing  and  auditor  independence 
standards in Canada, and thus may not be comparable to financial statements of U.S. companies.
The  enforcement  by  investors  of  civil  liabilities  under  the  United  States  federal  securities  laws  may  be  affected 
adversely by the fact that ECU is incorporated or organized outside the United States, that some or all of its officers and

directors and the experts named herein are residents of a foreign country, and that all or a substantial portion of the 
assets of ECU and said persons are located outside the United States. As a result, it may be difficult or impossible for

REPORTING CURRENCIES AND ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES
All references to “Cdn$” in this Circular refer to Canadian dollars and all reference to “US$” in this Circular refer to

ECU’s historical financial statements are reported in Canadian dollars and were prepared in accordance with Canadian 
GAAP at December 31, 2010 and for periods prior thereto, and in accordance with IFRS at March 31, 2011. Golden’s 
financial statements that are incorporated by reference herein, as well as the Pro Forma Financial Information included 
as  Appendix  I  to  this  Circular,  are  reported  in  U.S.  dollars  and  were  prepared  in  accordance  with  U.S.  GAAP. 
Accordingly,  in  preparing  the  Pro  Forma  Financial  Information,  certain  material  adjustments  were  made  in  order  to 
reconcile  ECU’s  Canadian  GAAP  or  IFRS  financial  statements  to  U.S.  GAAP,  as  described  under  “Information 
Concerning the Combined Company – Pro Forma Financial Information” in this Circular.

(amended) for the three-months ended March 31, 2011, together  with the notes thereto, were adjusted to conform to 
U.S.  GAAP  and  translated  to  U.S.  dollars  (such  adjusted  financial  statements  are  included  as  Appendix  J  to  this 
Circular),  and  ECU’s  audited  consolidated  financial  statements  (amended)  for  the  year  ended  December  31,  2010, 
together  with  the  notes  thereto  and  the  accompanying  report  of  the  auditor,  were  also  adjusted  to  conform  to  U.S. 
GAAP and translated to U.S. dollars (such adjusted financial statements are included as Appendix K to this Circular).

SUMMARY
The following summarizes the principal features of the Arrangement and certain other matters.  This Summary should 
be read together with and is qualified in its entirety by the more detailed information and financial data and statements 
contained elsewhere in this Circular, including the appendices hereto and documents incorporated into this Circular by 
reference. Capitalized terms in this Summary have the meanings set out in the Glossary of Terms which follows this 
Summary or as set out in this Summary. The full text of the Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of Arrangement are 
included as Appendix B and Appendix C, respectively.
The Meeting
Date, Time and Place of Meeting
The Meeting will be held on August 30, 2011, at 11:00 a.m. (Eastern Time), at the Crescent Room of Hôtel Le Crystal, 
1100 rue de la Montagne, Montreal, Québec H3G 0A1.
The Record Date
The Record Date for determining the ECU Securityholders entitled to receive notice of and to vote at the Meeting is July 
26, 2011.  Only ECU Securityholders of record as of 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on the Record Date are entitled to receive 
notice of and to vote at the Meeting.  The Record Date will remain the same even if the Meeting is adjourned or postponed.
Purpose of the Meeting
The purpose of the Meeting is for ECU Securityholders to consider and, if thought fit, pass, the Arrangement Resolution.  If 
the Arrangement is completed, Golden will acquire all of the issued and outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU 
Warrants and ECU will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Golden, and the ECU Convertible Notes will be replaced 
with non-convertible notes of ECU. As a result of the  Arrangement, and subject to rounding as provided in the Plan of 
Arrangement  with  respect  to  fractional  Golden  Securities  otherwise  receivable  thereunder,  (a)  ECU  Shareholders  (other 
than Dissenting Shareholders and Golden) will receive 0.05 shares of Golden Stock and Cdn$0.000394 in cash for each 
ECU Share held; (b) ECU Optionholders will receive Golden Replacement Options and ECU Warrantholders will receive 
Golden  Replacement  Warrants  in  replacement  of  their  outstanding  ECU  Options  and  ECU  Warrants,  respectively, 
exercisable to acquire that number of shares of Golden Stock that such holders would have acquired if they had exercised 
their ECU Options or ECU Warrants, as applicable, immediately prior to the Effective Time and had received ECU Shares 
in exchange therefor, with the exercise price of the Golden Replacement Options and the Golden Replacement Warrants 
being adjusted based on the Exchange Ratio; (c) the ECU Convertible Noteholder will receive ECU Replacement Notes in 
replacement of its outstanding ECU Convertible Notes; and (d) the Shareholder Rights Plan will be terminated and all SRP 
Rights will expire.
See “The Arrangement”.
Votes Required to Approve the Arrangement
In order for the Arrangement to be effective, the Arrangement Resolution must be approved by: (a) at least 66 2/3% of the 
votes cast by ECU Shareholders present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to vote; (b) at least 
66 2/3% of the votes cast by all ECU Securityholders, voting together as a single class, present in person or represented by 
proxy at the Meeting and entitled to vote; and (c) a simple majority of the votes cast by ECU Shareholders present in person 
or  represented  by  proxy  at  the  Meeting  and  entitled  to  vote  after  excluding  the  votes  cast  in  respect  of  ECU  Shares 
beneficially  owned  or  over  which  control  or  direction  is  exercised  by  Mr.  Michel  Roy,  Chairman  and  Chief  Executive 
Officer of ECU, and Mr. Stephen J. Altmann, President of ECU, and by their respective related parties or joint actors.  Each 
ECU Security that is voted at the Meeting will vote only once on the Arrangement Resolution but three separate tabulations 
of the votes will be conducted, one for each of the foregoing required approvals.  ECU Shareholders, ECU Optionholders 
and ECU Warrantholders are entitled to one vote for each ECU Share, ECU Option or ECU Warrant, as applicable, held by 
them, and the ECU Convertible Noteholder is currently entitled to 15,480,000 votes (being such number of votes as is equal 
to the number of ECU Shares into which the ECU Convertible Notes held by it are convertible).  The directors and officers 
of  ECU,  who  beneficially  own  or  control  ECU  Securities  representing,  in  the  aggregate,  approximately  1.5%  of  the
- 7 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
outstanding ECU Shares and approximately 4.2% of the aggregate number of votes attached to all ECU Securities entitled 
to be voted on the Arrangement Resolution at the Meeting, have entered into the Voting Agreement with Golden whereby 
they have agreed to vote their ECU Securities in favour of the Arrangement Resolution. The Arrangement Resolution must 
receive  the  required  ECU  Securityholder  approval  in  order  for  ECU  to  seek  the  Final  Order  and  implement  the 
Arrangement on the Effective Date.
See “The Arrangement – Securityholder and Court Approvals” and “The Arrangement – Interests of Directors and Officers 
of ECU in the Arrangement”.
The Arrangement
Parties to the Arrangement
ECU is a corporation incorporated under the Laws of the Province of Québec.  ECU’s head office is located at 1116 ave. 
Granada, Rouyn-Noranda, Québec, Canada J9Y 1G9. ECU also has an executive office located at 87 Front Street East, 2nd 
Floor,  Toronto,  Ontario,  Canada  M5E  1B8.  ECU’s  operations  office  is  located  at  Rio  Támesis  No.  2505,  Col.  Las 
Magdalenas,  Torréon,  Coahuila,  Mexico  27010.    The  ECU  Shares  are  listed  for  trading  on  the  TSX  under  the  symbol 
“ECU” and the February 2009 Warrants are listed for trading on the TSX under the symbol “ECU.WT”.
Golden  is  a  company  incorporated  under  the  Laws  of  the  State  of  Delaware.    Golden’s  principal  offices  are  located  in 
Golden, Colorado at 350 Indiana Street, Suite 800, Golden, CO 80401 and its registered office is the Corporation Trust 
Company,  1209  Orange  Street,  Wilmington,  DE  19801.    Golden  also  maintains  exploration  offices  in  Argentina  at 
Sarmiento 447 – 3 Piso, Salta, CP A4400ERE, in Mexico at Ave. Xòchitl 236, Colonia Ciudad del Sol, Zapopan, Jalisco 
C.P. 45050, and in Peru at Ave. Jose Gálvez Barrenechea No 566; Piso 3, oficinas 301 – 302, Urbanización CORPAC, San 
Isidro – LIMA 27.  Golden Stock is listed for trading on the TSX under the symbol “AUM” and on the NYSE Amex under 
the symbol “AUMN”.
See “Information Concerning Golden” and “Information Concerning the Combined Company”.
Terms of the Arrangement
The  purpose  of  the  Arrangement  is  to  effect  a  business  combination  between  ECU  and  Golden.    Pursuant  to  the 
Arrangement, Golden  will acquire all of the issued and outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants  and 
ECU will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Golden.  As a result of the Arrangement, ECU Shareholders (other than 
Dissenting Shareholders and Golden) will receive shares of Golden Stock for their ECU Shares at the Exchange Ratio plus 
a cash payment of Cdn$0.000394 for each ECU Share held, ECU Optionholders and ECU Warrantholders will receive in 
exchange for their ECU Options and ECU Warrants, respectively, Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement 
Warrants,  as  applicable,  adjusted  based  on  the  Exchange  Ratio,  and  the  ECU  Convertible  Noteholder  will  receive  ECU 
Replacement  Notes.    The  Arrangement  is  to  be  carried  out  pursuant  to  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement.

outstanding ECU Options and ECU Warrants are exercised before consummation of the Arrangement.

Recommendation of the ECU Board
ECU retained the Financial Advisor to act as its financial advisor and retained the Fairness Advisor to provide the Fairness 
Opinion.  The Fairness Advisor has provided a written opinion to the ECU Board, as at June 23, 2011, and subject to the 
assumptions, limitations and qualifications set forth therein, that the Consideration to be paid by Golden to holders of ECU 
Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates) pursuant to the terms of the Arrangement is fair, from a financial point of view, 
to  the  holders  of  ECU  Shares  (other  than  Golden  and  its  affiliates).    The  ECU  Board,  having  taken  into  account  such 
opinion  of  the  Fairness  Advisor  and  such  other  matters  as  it  considered  relevant,  has  unanimously  determined  that  the 
Arrangement  is  in  the  best  interests  of  ECU  and  is  fair  to  the  ECU  Securityholders  from  a  financial  point  of  view.  
Accordingly,  the  ECU  Board  unanimously  recommends  that  ECU  Securityholders  (other  than  Golden  and  its 
affiliates for which no recommendation is provided) vote FOR the Arrangement Resolution.
See “The Arrangement – Recommendation of the ECU Board”.
Reasons for the Arrangement
In  the  course  of  their  evaluation  of  the  Arrangement,  the  ECU  Board  consulted  with  ECU’s  senior  management,  legal 
counsel, the Financial Advisor and the Fairness Advisor, reviewed a significant amount of information and considered a 
number of factors which show compelling business reasons for the Arrangement, including, among others, the following:
!
Review  of  Strategic  Alternatives.    The  Arrangement  was  arrived  at  following  an  extensive  review  of  strategic 
alternatives which was conducted with the assistance of the Financial Advisor, including considering a range of 
potential transactions with a number of possible counterparties identified by the Financial Advisor and agreed to 
by ECU.

The Arrangement creates a combined company with greater scale and financial strength and an enhanced capital 
markets profile:
(cid:2)

(cid:2)
the Combined Company is expected to have sufficient cash to advance expansion plans at the Velardeña 
District Properties and the continued development of the El Quevar Project; 
the  Combined  Company’s  basic  market  capitalization  will  be  over  US$600  million,  based  upon  the 
closing  trading  prices of  ECU  and  Golden  as  at  June  23,  2011,  with  an  expected  increased  liquidity 
profile on both the NYSE Amex and the TSX; and
the Combined Company’s increased scale is expected to improve access to global capital markets to assist 
future growth efforts.
The Arrangement combines complementary management teams with proven track records of success to enhance 
and expand the existing portfolio of combined assets:
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
Golden’s  management  team  has  strong  expertise  and  a  proven  track  record  in  mine  building  and 
operations,  which  can  be  leveraged  in  order  to  seek  to  optimize  and  potentially  expand  the  Velardeña 
District Properties mining operations;
ECU has an operations team totalling nearly 500 people that can operate mines and mills in Mexico as 
required by the planning team;
ECU’s exploration expertise is expected to further enhance exploration efforts at the El Quevar Project, 
the Zacatecas Project and other drill testing projects across South America; and
the Combined Company will have a large portfolio of projects which, combined with enhanced scale and 
broader reach, will create opportunities for growth in existing and new jurisdictions.
The Arrangement increases leverage to precious metals with significant base metals credits:
(cid:2)

of approximately 25 million ounces silver, 0.3 million ounces gold, 26 million pounds lead and 37 million

and Peru.

Continued Participation by ECU Shareholders in Velardeña District Properties.  ECU Shareholders, through their

District Properties.
Increased Portfolio of Silver Assets.  The Arrangement continues the strategy to which ECU Securityholders are 
currently exposed of building a portfolio of quality silver producing assets in low political risk jurisdictions.
Exchange Ratio.  The following is a discussion of the Exchange Ratio in relation to trading prices of ECU Shares 
and Golden Stock on the TSX and other Canadian trading platforms (collectively, the “Canadian Market”) and 
trading prices of Golden Stock on the TSX and on the NYSE Amex and trading platforms in the United States (the 
NYSE  Amex  and  U.S.  trading  platforms,  collectively,  the  “U.S.  Market”).  Whereas  the  Exchange  Ratio
- 11 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
represents a discount of 7% based on the closing trading prices of the ECU Shares and Golden Stock on the TSX 
on June 23, 2011, the last trading day prior to the date of announcement of the proposed Arrangement (6% if based 
on the closing trading prices of Golden Stock in the U.S. Market and the ECU Shares in the Canadian Market on 
such date), based on the VWAP for the 20 trading days ended June 23, 2011 in each case as indicated below, the 
Exchange Ratio represents a modest premium or an “at-market” transaction:
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
the Exchange Ratio represents a premium of approximately 7% to the VWAP of the ECU Shares in the 
Canadian Market based on the June 23, 2011 closing trading price of Golden Stock in the U.S. Market 
(where most of Golden Stock trades);
the Exchange Ratio represents a premium of approximately 4% to the VWAP of the ECU Shares on the 
TSX based on the June 23, 2011 closing trading price of Golden Stock on the TSX; and
the Exchange Ratio represents an “at-market” transaction based on the VWAP of the ECU Shares in the 
Canadian Market and the VWAP of Golden Stock on the U.S. Market (or a 2% discount to the VWAP of 
the ECU Shares on the TSX, based on the VWAP of Golden Stock on the TSX).
The  Financial  Advisor  and  the  Fairness  Advisor.  The  ECU  Board  considered  the  financial  presentations  and 
advice of the Financial Advisor, as well as the Fairness Opinion of the Fairness Advisor delivered orally to the 
ECU Board on June 23, 2011, and subsequently confirmed in writing as of such date, as to the fairness, from a 
financial  point  of  view,  of  the  Consideration  to  be  received  by  ECU  Shareholders,  other  than  Golden  and  its 
affiliates, under the Arrangement.  The written Fairness Opinion is attached as Appendix D to this Circular.
Alternatives to the Arrangement.  The ECU Board will remain able to respond, in accordance with its fiduciary 
duties, to bona fide unsolicited written Acquisition Proposals that are more favourable to ECU Shareholders than 
the Arrangement and constitute Superior Proposals under the Arrangment Agreement.  Under such circumstances, 
subject to payment of the ECU Termination Fee in the amount of Cdn$10 million, ECU may, in accordance with 
the  Arrangement  Agreement,  terminate  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  approve  and  recommend  any  such 
Superior Proposal if Golden does not exercise its right to match such Superior Proposal in accordance with the 
Arrangement Agreement. The Golden Board has the same rights under the Arrangment Agreement, and Golden 
would be subject to payment of the Golden Termination Fee in the amount of Cdn$10 million if the Golden Board
wished  to  terminate  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  approve  and  recommend  any  Superior  Proposal  made  to 
Golden if ECU does not exercise its right to match such Superior Proposal in accordance with the Arrangement 
Agreement.
Intervening Events.  The ECU Board will also remain able to respond, in accordance with its fiduciary duties, to 
the  occurrence  of  any  Intervening  Event.  Under  such  circumstances,  ECU  may,  in  accordance  with  the 
Arrangement  Agreement,  change  its  recommendation  in  favour  of  the  approval  of  the  Arrangement  Resolution 
(subject to payment of the ECU Termination Fee if Golden elects to terminate the Arrangement Agreement as a 
result  of  such  change  of  recommendation)  if  Golden  does  not  exercise  its  right  to  respond  to  such  Intervening 
Event to the satisfaction of the ECU Board in accordance with the Arrangement Agreement.  The Golden Board 
will also be able to similary respond to any Intervening Event.
Termination Fee Reasonable. The ECU Board believes that the ECU Termination Fee payable to Golden in certain 
circumstances is reasonable and not preclusive of other proposals.
Voting Agreement. The directors and officers of ECU, being the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders, who in total 
held approximately 1.5% of the outstanding ECU Shares, approximately 87.9% of the outstanding ECU Options, 
none of the outstanding February 2009 Warrants and none of the outstanding December 2009 Warrants as at June 
24, 2011, entered into the Voting Agreement with Golden pursuant to which they agreed, among other things, to 
vote in favour of the Arrangement Resolution.

Reasonable  Terms  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement.  The  terms  and  conditions  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement, 
including ECU’s and Golden’s representations,  warranties and covenants, and the conditions to their respective 
obligations are, in the judgment of ECU, after consultation with its legal counsel, reasonable.
Likelihood of Completion. It is likely that the conditions to complete the Arrangement will be satisfied, including 
taking into account the nature of the approvals required by both ECU and Golden to be obtained as a condition to 
completing the Arrangement.
No Material Regulatory Issues. There are no material competition or other regulatory issues which are expected to 
arise in connection with the Arrangement so as to prevent its completion, and all required regulatory clearances 
and approvals are expected to be obtained.
Free to Support Superior Proposal. If a Superior Proposal is made to ECU Shareholders, ECU Securityholders 
other than the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders are free to support such Superior Proposal and vote against the 
Arrangement Resolution. In the event that the Arrangement Agreement is terminated by ECU or Golden to enable 
ECU to enter into an acquisition agreement  with a third party that  has  made a Superior Proposal and the ECU 
Termination Fee is paid, then the Voting Agreement to which the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders are party will 
also terminate and such securityholders will also be free to support such Superior Proposal.
Free  to  Support  Intervening  Event.  If  an  Intervening  Event  occurs,  ECU  Securityholders  other  than  the  ECU 
Locked-Up Securityholders are free to vote against the Arrangement Resolution. In the event that the Arrangement 
Agreement is terminated by Golden as a result of ECU changing its recommendation in favour of the approval of 
the Arrangement Resolution and the ECU Termination Fee is paid, then the Voting Agreement to which the ECU 
Locked-Up Securityholders are party will also terminate and such Securityholders will also be free to vote against 
the Arrangement Resolution.
Independent  Advice.  ECU  retained  independent  financial  and  legal  advisors  who  advised  ECU  throughout  the 
process as noted above.
Arm’s-length  Negotiations.  The  Arrangement  Agreement  is  a  result  of  arm’s-length  negotiations  between  ECU 
and Golden.

Risk Factors of the Arrangement
In the course of its deliberations, the ECU Board also identified and considered a variety of risks and potentially negative 
factors in connection with the Arrangement, including, but not limited to, the following:
!
!
The Exchange Ratio is fixed and, as a result, the Golden Stock issued on closing of the Arrangement may have a 
market value different than at the time of announcement of the Arrangement.
The completion of the Arrangement is subject to several conditions that must be satisfied or waived.
- 13 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
The Arrangement Agreement may be terminated by ECU or Golden in certain circumstances, in which case the 
market price for ECU Shares may be adversely affected.
The  Combined  Company  will  incur  significant  transaction,  combination-related  and  restructuring  costs  in 
connection with the Arrangement.
The  Combined  Company  may  incur  significant  costs  related  to  contractual  arrangements  that  are  not  currently 
anticipated.
The exercise of Dissent Rights  may increase the consideration payable pursuant to the  Plan of  Arrangement or 
hinder the closing of the Arrangement.
The  directors  and  officers  of  ECU  may  have  interests  that  are  different  from  the  interests  of  other  ECU 
Securityholders.
The trading price of Golden Stock could be depressed by sales of shares of Golden Stock by ECU Securityholders 
or Golden Stockholders who sell their shares of Golden Stock.
The existence of a significant number of options and warrants may have a negative effect on the market price of 
Golden Stock.
The  ECU  Termination  Fee  provided  for  under  the  Arrangement  Agreement  may  discourage  other  parties  from 
attempting to acquire ECU. If ECU is required to pay the ECU Termination Fee and an alternative transaction is 
not completed, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
If ECU is required to pay the expense reimbursement fee contemplated by the Arrangement Agreement in certain 
circumstances, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
The Arrangement  will present challenges associated  with integrating operations, personnel and other aspects of 
ECU and Golden.
ECU  and  Golden  have  both  historically  incurred  operating  losses  and  operating  cash  flow  deficits  and  it  is 
expected that the Combined Company will continue to incur operating losses in the foreseeable future.
ECU’s and Golden’s properties may not contain mineral reserves.
The Combined Company is expected to continue to require substantial external financing to pay its operating and 
general and administrative expenses, continue the advancement of the Velardeña Property expansion and the El 
Quevar Project and fund its other exploration activities.
The  Combined  Company  will  be  subject  to  a  broad  range  of  Environmental  Laws  and  associated  costs  and 
liabilities.
The long-term cash flow and profitability of the Combined Company will be affected by changes in the prices of 
silver and other metals.
If the Combined Company is unable to obtain all of its required governmental permits or obtain property rights on 
favourable terms or at all, its operations could be negatively impacted.
The Combined Company may not meet key production or cost estimates.
See “The Arrangement – Risk Factors of the Arrangement” and “Risk Factors”. See also “The Arrangement – Opinion of 
the Fairness Advisor” and the financial statements attached as Appendices I, J and K to, or incorporated by reference into, 
this Circular.

if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Voting Agreement
Each of the ECU  Locked-Up Securityholders, holding in the aggregate, as of July 22, 2011, approximately 1.5% of the

Securityholder shall remain obligated to vote all of its ECU Securities in the manner provided for by the Voting Agreement 
regardless of the position that the ECU Board takes, or its recommendation, with respect to the Arrangement Resolution.
Management of Golden have entered into a similar voting agreement with ECU with respect to the Golden Share Issuance 
Proposal to be voted upon at the Golden Meeting, which agreement contains corresponding provisions relating to the voting 
of Golden Stock by those members of management.  Directors of Golden are expected to sign the voting agreement prior to 
the Meeting.

Opinion of the Fairness Advisor
As at the date of its opinion and based on the information and procedures described therein, and subject to the assumptions, 
limitations and qualifications set forth in its Fairness Opinion, the Fairness Advisor has concluded that the Consideration of 
0.05 shares of Golden Stock and Cdn$0.000394 in cash per ECU Share to be paid by Golden to holders of ECU Shares 
(other than Golden and its affiliates) pursuant to the terms of the Arrangement is fair, from a financial point of view, to the 
holders of ECU Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates).
See “The Arrangement – Opinion of the Fairness Advisor” and the Fairness Opinion, which is attached as Appendix D.
Private Placement
On June 24, 2011, Golden and ECU entered into the Subscription Agreement pursuant to which ECU issued to Golden, on 
July 13, 2011, Cdn$15.0 million principal amount of ECU Convertible Notes. The Private Placement is intended to provide 
ECU with interim financing of its operations pending consummation of the Arrangement. The ECU Convertible Notes will 
mature on June 30, 2012 (subject to extension as described below), and are convertible by Golden at any time prior to 5:00 
p.m. (Eastern Time) on June 29, 2012 into ECU Shares at a rate of 1,032 ECU Shares for each Cdn$1,000 in principal 
amount converted, consistent with the Exchange Ratio.  Upon the occurrence of certain specified fundamental changes, the 
ECU Convertible Notes may be redeemed or converted into ECU Shares at the option of Golden based on 102% of the 
outstanding principal amount of the ECU Convertible Notes. The ECU Convertible Notes are also redeemable by ECU at 
any time after the Record Date and prior to their maturity date at 100% of their face value plus accrued and unpaid interest.  
ECU may elect to extend the maturity of the ECU Convertible Notes to December 31, 2012 upon the making of a cash 
payment to Golden equal to 4% of the face value of the then outstanding ECU Convertible Notes, payable on the day the 
extension  option  is  exercised,  with  interest  accruing  on  the  ECU  Convertible  Notes  at  10%  per  annum  during  such 
extension period.
Under the terms of the ECU Convertible Notes, the proceeds of the Private Placement are held in an escrow account and 
may  only  be  used  by  ECU  for  specified  purposes,  including  (i) expenses  associated  with  development,  exploration, 
operating and general and administrative costs (including base salaries and employee benefits) relating to the development 
and  operating  activities  at  the  Velardeña  Property;  (ii) general  and  administrative  expenses,  including  base  salaries, 
employee benefits and the various expenses incurred in connection with the transactions contemplated by the Arrangement 
Agreement; (iii) regularly scheduled principal and interest payments on arm’s length indebtedness existing at the date of 
issuance of the ECU Convertible Notes; and (iv) such other expenditures as may be approved by Golden.  Bonus payments, 
severance payments, change of control payments or other termination payments are not permitted uses.  At the closing of 
the Private Placement, Cdn$2.85 million of the subscription proceeds  were released to ECU and the Cdn$12.15 million 
balance of the proceeds were placed in escrow.
Golden will have the right to vote the ECU Convertible Notes on the Arrangement Resolution at the Meeting together with 
the outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants voting as a single class. The ECU Convertible Notes shall 
be  entitled  to  such  number  of  votes  at  the  Meeting  as  is  equal  to  the  number  of  ECU  Shares  into  which  the  ECU 
Convertible Notes are convertible, currently being 15,480,000 votes.
See “The Arrangement – Private Placement”.
The Arrangement Agreement
The Arrangement will be carried out pursuant to the Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of Arrangement. The following 
is a summary of the principal terms of the Arrangement Agreement. See “The Arrangement Agreement” for more details.
On June 24, 2011, ECU and Golden entered into the Arrangement Agreement, pursuant to which ECU and Golden agreed 
that, subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Arrangement Agreement, the Parties would implement the Plan of 
Arrangement whereby Golden will acquire all of the issued and outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants, 
and the ECU Convertible Notes would be replaced by the ECU Replacement Notes. As a result of the Arrangement, each 
ECU  Shareholder  (other  than  Dissenting  Shareholders  and  Golden)  will  receive  0.05  of  a  share  of  Golden  Stock  and 
Cdn$0.000394  in  cash  for  each  ECU  Share  held;  each  ECU  Optionholder  and  ECU  Warrantholder  will  receive  Golden 
Replacement  Options  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants,  respectively,  for  their  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants, 
exercisable to acquire that number of shares of Golden Stock that such holders would have acquired if they had exercised
- 16 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
their  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants,  as  applicable,  immediately  prior  to  the  Effective  Time;  the  ECU  Convertible 
Noteholder  will  receive  ECU  Replacement  Notes  in  replacement  of  its  outstanding  ECU  Convertible  Notes;  and  the 
Shareholder Rights Plan will be terminated and all SRP Rights will expire. The terms of the Arrangement Agreement are 
the result of arm’s length negotiations between ECU and Golden and their respective advisors.

Adverse Recommendation Change; Superior Proposal; Right to Match or Respond
ECU  may  make  an  ECU  Board  Change  in  Recommendation  and  Golden  may  make  a  Golden  Board  Change  in 
Recommendation (i) following receipt of an Acquisition Proposal that it determines to be a Superior Proposal or (ii) solely 
in response to any Intervening Event, in each case if it determines in good faith, after consultation with its legal advisors, 
that the failure to take such action would be inconsistent with its fiduciary duties under applicable Law.
Upon payment of the ECU Termination Fee, the ECU Board may terminate the Arrangement Agreement in order to accept 
and enter into an agreement in respect of an Acquisition Proposal that the ECU Board in good faith, after consultation with 
its  financial  and  outside  legal  advisors,  has  determined  is  a  Superior  Proposal.  Golden  will  have  the  right,  but  not  the 
obligation, to amend the terms of the Arrangement upon notification by ECU of a Superior Proposal or Intervening Event, 
as applicable, within a five (5) Business Day response period. Within five (5) Business Days of receiving any such proposal 
by Golden to amend the terms of the Arrangement, the ECU Board shall review and determine whether the Acquisition 
Proposal  to  which  Golden  is  responding  would  continue  to  be  a  Superior  Proposal,  or  whether  the  Adverse 
Recommendation  Change  is  still  necessary,  when  assessed  in  light  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement as they are proposed by Golden to be amended. If the ECU Board determines that, in light of the proposed 
amendment  by  Golden,  the  Acquisition  Proposal  to  which  Golden  is  responding  would  not  continue  to  be  a  Superior 
Proposal, or the Adverse Recommendation Change would not be necessary, ECU is required to enter into an amendment to 
the  Arrangement  Agreement  to  give  effect  to  such  amendments  and  the  ECU  Board  must  promptly  reaffirm  its 
recommendation of the Plan of Arrangement.
Reciprocally, upon payment of the Golden Termination Fee, the Golden Board may terminate the Arrangement Agreement 
in order to accept and enter into an agreement in respect of an Acquisition Proposal that the Golden Board in good faith, 
after consultation with its financial and outside legal advisors, has determined is a Superior Proposal. ECU will have the 
right, but not the obligation, to amend the terms of the Arrangement upon notification by Golden of a Superior Proposal or 
Intervening  Event,  as  applicable,  within  a  five  (5)  Business  Day  response  period.  Within  five  (5)  Business  Days  of 
receiving any such proposal by ECU to amend the terms of the Arrangement, the Golden Board shall review and determine 
whether the Acquisition Proposal to which ECU is responding would continue to be a Superior Proposal, or whether the

(b)

document  which  is  agreed  to  in  writing  by  ECU  and  Golden  and  filed  with  the  Court  and,  if  made

Meeting, provided that Golden has consented to such amendment, modification or supplement, with or 
without  any  other  prior  notice  or  communication  and,  if  so  proposed  and  accepted  by  the  ECU 
Securityholders voting at the Meeting, such amendment, modification or supplement shall become part of 
the Plan of Arrangement for all purposes; and
any amendment, modification or supplement to the Plan of Arrangement that is approved by the Court 
following the Meeting shall be effective only if it is consented to in writing by ECU and Golden and, if 
required by the Court, is consented to by the ECU Securityholders.

Payment of Consideration
Following receipt of the Final Order and prior to the filing of the Articles of Arrangement with the Enterprise Registrar, 
Golden shall deposit with the Depositary in escrow, for the benefit of holders of ECU Securities, sufficient funds, shares of 
Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants in the aggregate amounts necessary to pay the Consideration required by 
the Plan of Arrangement.
Subject  to  surrender  to  the  Depositary  for  cancellation  of  a  holder’s  ECU  Share  certificate  or  ECU  Warrant  certificate, 
together with the duly completed and executed appropriate Letter of Transmittal (included with this Circular and printed on 
blue  paper  in  the  case  of  ECU  Shares  and  printed  on yellow  paper  in  the  case  of  ECU  Warrants)  and  such  additional 
documents  and  instruments  as  the  Depositary  may  reasonably  require,  following  the  Effective  Time  the  holder  of  such 
surrendered  certificate  shall  be  entitled  to  receive  the  Consideration  to  which  such  holder  is  entitled  under  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement, less any amounts required to be deducted and withheld under applicable Laws in respect of taxes, and any 
certificate so surrendered shall forthwith be cancelled.
Until  surrendered,  each  ECU  Share  certificate  or  ECU  Warrant  certificate  shall  be  deemed  after  the  Effective  Time  to 
represent only the right to receive, upon such surrender, the Consideration to which the holder thereof is entitled in lieu of 
such certificate under the Plan of Arrangement, less any amounts required to be deducted and withheld under applicable 
Laws in respect of taxes. Any such certificate formerly representing ECU Shares or ECU Warrants not duly surrendered on 
or before the sixth anniversary of the Effective Date shall cease to represent a claim by, or interest of, any former holder of 
ECU Shares or ECU Warrants of any kind or nature against or in ECU or Golden and be deemed to have been surrendered 
to Golden and shall be cancelled.
Any right or claim to payment pursuant to the Plan of Arrangement that remains outstanding on the sixth anniversary of the 
Effective Date shall cease to represent a right or claim of any kind or nature whatsoever and the right of the former ECU 
Securityholder  to  receive  the  Consideration  pursuant  to  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  shall  terminate  and  be  deemed  to  be 
surrendered and forfeited, for no consideration, to Golden.
No holder of ECU Securities shall be entitled to receive any consideration with respect to its ECU Securities other than the 
Consideration  in  accordance  with  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  and,  for  greater  certainty,  no  such  holder  will  be  entitled  to 
receive any interest, dividends, premium or other payment in connection therewith.
Withholding Rights
Golden, ECU and the Depositary, as applicable, shall be entitled to deduct and withhold from any Consideration payable or 
otherwise deliverable to any former holder of ECU Securities such amounts as they may be required to deduct and withhold 
therefrom under any provision of applicable Laws in respect of applicable taxes.  Any such deducted and withheld amounts 
shall be treated as having been paid to the person to whom such amounts would otherwise have been paid.
No Fractional Securities
No fractional shares of Golden Stock, fractional Golden Replacement Options or fractional Golden Replacement Warrants 
shall be issued to any person pursuant to the Plan of Arrangement.  Instead, the number of shares of Golden Stock or the 
number of Golden Replacement Options or Golden Replacement Warrants to be issued to any person shall be rounded up 
or down, as applicable, to the nearest whole share of Golden Stock. In calculating such fractional interests, all ECU Shares, 
ECU Options or ECU Warrants, as applicable, registered in the name of or beneficially held by an ECU Securityholder or 
its nominee shall be aggregated.
Letters of Transmittal
In order to receive shares of Golden Stock and the cash payment for their ECU Shares or Golden Replacement Warrants for 
their ECU Warrants, as the case may be, Registered Shareholders or Registered Warrantholders must complete and sign the 
appropriate Letter of Transmittal included with this Circular (printed on blue paper in the case of ECU Share and printed on 
yellow paper in the case of ECU Warrants) and deliver it, together with certificates representing their ECU Shares or ECU 
Warrants and the other required documents, to the Depositary in accordance with the instructions contained in the Letters of 
Transmittal  included  with  this  Circular.  The  Letters  of  Transmittal  contains  procedural  information  relating  to  the

Arrangement and should be reviewed carefully.  Copies of the Letters of Transmittal may be obtained by contacting the

ECU Options
No  certificates  representing  ECU  Options  have  been  issued;  accordingly,  there  are  no  ECU  Option  certificates  to  be

by or on behalf of Golden in respect of Golden Replacement Options as of the Effective Time in accordance with the steps 
of the Plan of Arrangement.  Golden will send each holder of Golden Replacement Options a notice confirming the details 
of such holder’s Golden Replacement Options following the Effective Date.
ECU Convertible Notes
The ECU Convertible Noteholder does not need to complete a Letter of Transmittal with respect to its ECU Convertible 
Notes.  Arrangements will be made by ECU and Golden following the Effective Date with respect to documentation related 
to the issuance of the ECU Replacement Notes.
Dissent Rights
Each  Registered  Shareholder  as  of  the  Record  Date  shall  be  entitled  to  exercise  Dissent  Rights  in  respect  of  the 
Arrangement  in  the  manner  set  out  in  Chapter  XIV  of  the  QBCA,  as  modified  by  the  Interim  Order  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement.  Any Registered Shareholder who exercises its Dissent Rights will be entitled to be paid by Golden the fair 
value of the ECU Shares held by such Dissenting Shareholder, as of the close of the offices of ECU on the day before the 
Arrangement Resolution is approved by the ECU Securityholders.  The Interim Order and the Plan of Arrangement provide 
that the fair value payable by Golden to a Dissenting Shareholder, may, at the option of Golden, be paid by way of issuance 
of shares of Golden Stock.  The Dissent Procedures must be strictly complied with in order for a Dissenting Shareholder to 
exercise Dissent  Rights, including that  such Dissenting Shareholder has exercised all of the  voting rights carried by  the 
ECU Shares held by such Dissenting Shareholder against the approval of the Arrangement Resolution.
To exercise the Dissent Right, a written Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights must be received by ECU at its registered 
office at 1116 ave. Granada, Rouyn-Noranda, Québec J9Y1G9 not later than 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on August 26, 2011, 
or two Business Days prior to the time of the reconvening of any adjournment or postponement of the Meeting.
ECU Shareholders who beneficially own ECU Shares that are registered in the name of an Intermediary (such as a broker, 
investment dealer, bank, trust company or trustee or other intermediary) or in some other name and who wish to exercise 
Dissent Rights should be aware that only a Registered Shareholder as of the Record Date is entitled to exercise Dissent 
Rights.    A  Beneficial  Shareholder  who  wishes  to  exercise  Dissent  Rights  should  communicate  with  the  Beneficial 
Shareholder’s  Intermediary  as  to  the  procedure  for  instructing  them  to  exercise  the  Dissent  Rights  on  the  Beneficial 
Shareholder’s behalf.
For  greater  certainty,  no  ECU  Optionholder,  ECU  Warrantholder  or  ECU  Convertible  Noteholder  shall  be  entitled  to 
Dissent Rights in respect of such holder’s ECU Options, ECU Warrants or ECU Convertible Notes.  Additionally, the right 
of  a  Dissenting  Shareholder  to  have  its  ECU  Shares  repurchased  and  to  be  paid  the  fair  value  therefor  pursuant  to  the 
exercise of Dissent Rights is subject to the Arrangement becoming effective.
See “Rights of Dissenting Shareholders”.

Certain Income Tax Considerations
ECU Shareholders, ECU Optionholders and ECU Warrantholders should consult their own tax advisors as to the 
Canadian  or  United  States  federal,  provincial,  state  and  local  tax  considerations  applicable  to  them  in  their 
particular circumstances.
Canadian Federal Income Tax Considerations
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Shareholder who is resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax Act, 
who  holds  ECU  Shares  as  capital  property  and  who  exchanges  such  ECU  Shares  for  Golden  Stock  and  cash  under  the 
Arrangement, will be considered to have disposed of the ECU Shares for proceeds of disposition equal to the aggregate of 
the  fair  market  value  at  the  Effective  Time  of  the  Golden  Stock  received  on  the  exchange  and  the  cash  consideration 
received on the exchange. Consequently, such ECU Shareholder should realize a capital gain (or a capital loss) to the extent 
that such proceeds of disposition exceed (or are less than) the aggregate of the ECU Shareholder’s adjusted cost base of the 
ECU Shares immediately before the exchange and any reasonable costs of disposition.
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Optionholder who is resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax Act, 
who holds ECU Options as capital property, who acquired such ECU Options pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan by 
virtue of being an employee, officer or director of ECU and  who exchanges the ECU  Options  for Golden Replacement 
Options and no other consideration at the Effective Time, should not recognize any taxable income or loss as a result of 
such exchange pursuant to the Arrangement.
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Warrantholder who is resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax Act, 
who holds ECU Warrants as  capital property and  who transfers such ECU Warrants to  Golden in exchange for Golden 
Replacement  Warrants  pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  should  be  considered  to  have  disposed  of  such  ECU  Warrants  for 
proceeds of disposition equal to the  fair  market  value at the Effective Time of such Golden Replacement Warrants. An 
ECU Warrantholder should realize a capital gain (or capital loss) to the extent the proceeds of disposition of such ECU 
Warrants, net of any reasonable costs of disposition, exceed (or are less than) the adjusted cost base to such holder of such 
ECU Warrants immediately prior to the transfer.
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Shareholder who is not resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax Act 
and  whose ECU  Shares are exchanged  for Golden Stock and cash  under the  Arrangement,  should not be subject to  tax 
under the Tax Act on any capital gain realized on such exchange unless the ECU Shares are “taxable Canadian property” 
(as defined in the Tax Act) to the ECU Shareholder at the Effective Time and the ECU Shares are not “treaty-protected 
property” (as defined in the Tax Act) of such ECU Shareholder at the time of the exchange.
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Optionholder who is not resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax 
Act, who acquired ECU Options pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan by virtue of employment with ECU in Canada and 
who  exchanges  such  ECU  Options  for  Golden  Replacement  Options  and  no  other  consideration  at  the  Effective  Time, 
should not recognize any taxable income or loss as a result of such exchange pursuant to the Arrangement.
For Canadian federal income tax purposes, an ECU Warrantholder who is not resident in Canada for purposes of the Tax 
Act and who transfers ECU Warrants to Golden for Golden Replacement Warrants pursuant to the Arrangement, should not 
be subject to income tax under the Tax Act in respect of any capital gain realized by such holder on such transfer at the 
Effective Time unless such ECU Warrants are “taxable Canadian property” (as defined in the Tax Act) to such holder at the 
time  of  the  transfer  and  the  ECU  Warrants  are  not  “treaty-protected  property”  (as  defined  in  Tax  Act)  of  such  ECU 
Warrantholder at the time of disposition.
- 27 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
The foregoing summary is qualified in its entirety by the more detailed summary of the principal Canadian federal income 
tax considerations under the Tax Act relating to the Arrangement set forth in this Circular under “Certain Canadian Federal 
Income Tax Considerations”.
United States Federal Income Tax Considerations
The exchange of ECU Shares for Golden  Stock and cash, and the exchange of ECU  Warrants for Golden  Replacement 
Warrants, pursuant to the Arrangement is intended to be treated as a taxable exchange for U.S. federal income tax purposes. 
Each U.S. Holder will recognize gain or loss equal to the difference between (a) the sum of the (i) U.S. dollar equivalent of 
the Canadian dollars received calculated by reference to the exchange rate in effect on the date of receipt and (ii) the fair 
market value of the Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants and (b) the U.S. Holder’s adjusted tax basis in its ECU 
Shares or ECU Warrants disposed of pursuant to the Arrangement.
ECU believes, and the discussion herein assumes, that it may be and may have been a passive foreign investment company 
in one or more years since its formation.
Under  the  tax  rules  for  PFICs,  any  gain  recognized  by  a  U.S.  Holder  who  disposes  of  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants 
pursuant to the Arrangement, and whose holding period for the ECU Shares or ECU Warrants includes any period during 
which ECU  was a PFIC,  will be allocated ratably to each day of the U.S. Holder’s holding period  with respect to such 
shares or warrants. Gain allocated to the year of disposition and to years before ECU became a PFIC will be treated as 
arising in the year of disposition and taxed at ordinary U.S. federal income tax rates. Gain allocated to each of the other 
years during which ECU was a PFIC will be taxed at the highest ordinary U.S. federal income tax rate in effect for each of 
those years, and interest will be added to the tax determined for each of those years.  Any gain recognized by a U.S. Holder 
whose holding period for the ECU Shares or ECU Warrants does not include any period during which ECU was a PFIC 
will be a capital gain, and a long-term capital gain if the U.S. Holder’s holding period with respect to its ECU Shares or 
ECU Warrants (as applicable) is more than one year at the time of the Arrangement.   Any loss recognized by a U.S. Holder 
will  generally  be  treated  as  capital  loss,  which  will  be  long-term  capital  loss  if  the  U.S.  Holder’s  holding  period  with 
respect to its ECU Shares or ECU Warrants is more than one year at the time of the Arrangement. The deductibility of 
capital loss is subject to limitations.
U.S. Holders that have made a valid “mark-to-market” election with respect to ECU Shares will be subject to rules different 
from the rules applicable to shareholders of PFICs described above.
Distributions  with  respect  to  Golden  Stock  will  be  treated  as  dividends  when  paid  to  the  extent  of  Golden’s  current  or 
accumulated earnings and profits as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes. Generally, distributions treated as 
dividends paid to a Non-U.S. Holder with respect to Golden Stock will be subject to a 30% U.S. withholding tax, or such 
lower rate as may be specified by an applicable income tax treaty.
A holder of Golden Replacement Warrants received in the exchange generally will not recognize gain or loss upon the cash 
exercise of a Golden Replacement Warrant.  A holder’s basis in the Golden Stock received upon the exercise of a Golden 
Replacement Warrant will equal the sum of the holder’s tax basis in the warrant plus the cash paid to exercise the warrant.  
Upon the sale or exchange of a Golden Replacement Warrant, U.S. Holders will generally recognize gain or loss equal to 
the difference between the amount realized on such sale or exchange and the U.S. Holder’s adjusted tax basis in the Golden 
Replacement Warrant.
A Non-U.S. Holder of Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants generally will not be subject to U.S. federal income 
tax (or any withholding thereof) with respect to gain recognized on a sale or other disposition of Golden Stock or Golden 
Replacement Warrants unless (i) the gain is effectively connected with a trade or business of the Non-U.S. Holder in the 
U.S. and, in cases in which certain tax treaties apply, is attributable to a U.S. permanent establishment or fixed base of the 
Non-U.S. Holder (collectively, “effectively connected gain”); or (ii) the Non-U.S. Holder is a non-resident alien individual 
who is present in the U.S. for 183 or more days during the taxable year of disposition and meets certain other requirements.
The foregoing summary is qualified in its entirety by the more detailed summary of the anticipated U.S. federal income tax 
consequences resulting from the Arrangement set forth in this Circular under “Certain United States Federal Income Tax 
Considerations”.

Securities Laws Information for Canadian ECU Securityholders
The issue of Golden Stock, Golden Replacement Options, Golden Replacements Warrants and ECU Replacement Notes 
pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  including  the  issue  of  Golden  Stock  on  the  exercise  of  Golden  Replacement  Options  and 
Golden  Replacement  Warrants,  will  constitute  distributions  of  securities  which  are  exempt  from  the  prospectus 
requirements of the Canadian Securities Laws. The Golden Stock, Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement 
Warrants  issued  pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  including  the  Golden  Stock  issuable  upon  the  exercise  of  the  Golden 
Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants, may be resold in any province or territory of Canada, provided: 
(i) that Golden is a reporting issuer in a jurisdiction of Canada for the four months immediately preceding the trade; (ii) the 
trade is not a “control distribution” as defined in NI 45-102, (iii) no unusual effort is made to prepare the market or create a 
demand for those securities, (iv) no extraordinary commission or consideration is paid in respect of that sale, and (v) if the 
selling security holder is an insider or officer of Golden, the insider or officer has no reasonable grounds to believe that 
Golden is in default of securities legislation (within the meaning of NI 45-102).  Following the closing of the Arrangement, 
Golden  will  apply  to  the  applicable  Canadian  Securities  Authorities  to  have  ECU  cease  to  be  a  reporting  issuer; 
accordingly,  the  ECU  Replacement  Notes  may  not  be  resold  within  Canada  except  pursuant  to  an  exemption  from  the 
prospectus requirements of applicable Canadian Securities Laws.
See “Securities Laws Considerations – Canadian Securities Laws”.
Securities Laws Information for United States ECU Securityholders
The issue of Golden Stock, Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacements Warrants pursuant to the Arrangement 
will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any state of the United States and will be issued 
in  reliance  on  the  Section  3(a)(10)  Exemption.  Persons  who  are  not  “affiliates”  of  Golden  after  completion  of  the 
Arrangement may sell the Golden Securities that they receive in connection with the Arrangement without restriction under 
the U.S. Securities Act.  The ECU Replacement Notes have not been registered under the U.S. Securities Act, and are being 
issued in reliance on the exemption from registration set forth in Section 3(a)(9) thereof. Such ECU Replacement Notes 
will bear the same legend restricting transfer as the ECU Convertible Notes currently contain.
See “Securities Laws Considerations – U.S. Securities Laws”.

general  changes  in  political,  economic,  currency  exchange,  securities,  commodity  market  or  financial 
conditions in Canada, the United States or Argentina;
any change in applicable Laws or regulations or in U.S. GAAP or in TSX or NYSE Amex rules;
any natural disaster;
conditions generally affecting, as a whole, the mining industry generally in jurisdictions in which Golden 
and its subsidiaries operate;
any  matter  that  has  been  disclosed  in  documents  or  information  filed  by  Golden  under  applicable 
Securities Laws and publicly available on SEDAR or EDGAR or has been communicated in writing to 
ECU as of the date of the Arrangement Agreement;
any change in the market price of silver; or
any decrease in the market price or any decline in the trading volume of Golden Stock on the TSX or 
NYSE Amex (it being understood, however, that any cause underlying such change in market price or 
trading volume may be taken into account in determining whether a Golden Material Adverse Effect has 
occurred) or any suspension of trading in securities generally on the TSX or NYSE Amex;
provided that, notwithstanding the foregoing, any change, effect, event, occurrence or state of facts described in clauses (b), 
(c),  (d),  (e)  and  (g)  above  shall  constitute  a  Golden  Material  Adverse  Effect  to  the  extent  that  any  such  change,  effect, 
event,  occurrence  or  state  of  facts  has  or  would  reasonably  be  expected  to  have,  individually  or  in  the  aggregate,  a 
disproportionate impact on the business, assets, capital, properties, liabilities, prospects, operations, results of operations or 
condition (financial or otherwise) of Golden and its subsidiaries  taken as a whole, relative to comparable entities operating 
in the industry in which Golden operates.
