SELECTED MINING TERMS
“base metal” means a classification of metals usually considered to be of low value and higher chemical activity when 
compared with the precious metals (gold, silver, platinum, etc.). This non-specific term generally refers to the high-volume, 
low-value metals copper, lead, tin and zinc.
“breccia” means rock consisting of fragments, more or less angular, in a matrix of finer-grained material or of cementing 
material.
- 44 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
“concentrates” means the clean product of ore or metal separated from its containing rock or earth by froth flotation or 
other methods of mineral separation.
“concession” means a grant or lease of a tract of land made by a government or other controlling authority in return for 
stipulated services or a promise that the land will be used for a specific purpose.
“core sample” means one or several pieces of whole or split parts of core selected as a sample for analysis or assay.
“cut-off grade” means the lowest grade of mineralized rock that qualifies as ore grade in a given deposit, and is also used 
as the lowest grade below which the mineralized rock currently cannot be profitably exploited. Cut-off grades vary between 
deposits depending upon the amenability of ore to gold extraction and upon costs of production.
“deposit” means an informal term for an accumulation of mineral ores.
“development”  means  underground  work  carried  out  for  the  purpose  of  opening  up  a  mineral  deposit,  including  shaft 
sinking, crosscutting, drifting and raising.
“drift” means a horizontal or nearly horizontal underground opening driven along a vein to gain access to the deposit.
“epithermal” means hydrothermal mineral deposit formed within one kilometre of the earth’s surface, in the temperature 
range of 50-200 degrees Celsius.
“feasibility study” means an engineering study designed to define the technical, economic and legal viability of a mining 
project with a high degree of reliability.
“formation” means a distinct layer of sedimentary rock of similar composition.
“g/t” means grams per metric tonne.
“grade” means the metal content of ore, usually expressed in troy ounces per ton (2,000 pounds) or in grams per ton or 
metric tonnes which contain 2,204.6 pounds or 1,000 kilograms.
“hydrothermal” means processes associated with heated or superheated water, especially mineralization or alteration.
“indicated mineral resource” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“inferred mineral resource” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“intrusive” means a body of igneous rock formed by the consolidation of intruded magma.
“measured mineral resource” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“metallurgy”  means  the  science  and  art  of  separating  metals  and  metallic  minerals  from  their  ores  by  mechanical  and 
chemical processes.
“metamorphic” means affected by physical, chemical and structural processes imposed by depth in the earth’s crust.
“mine” means an excavation beneath the surface of the ground from which mineral matter of value is extracted.
“mineralization” means the concentration of metals within a body of rock.
“mineral reserve” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“mineral resource” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
- 45 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
“Mineral Rights” means prospecting licences, exploration licences, mining leases, mining licences, mineral concessions 
and other  forms of  mineral tenure or other rights to  Minerals, or to  work  upon  lands for the purposes of exploring  for, 
developing or extracting Minerals under any  forms of  mineral title (or any interest therein) recognized under applicable 
Laws.
“Minerals”  means  all  ores,  doré,  concentrates  and  other  products  derived  therefrom,  of  precious,  base  and  industrial 
minerals, including diamonds, which may be lawfully explored for, mined and sold pursuant to Mineral Rights and other 
instruments of title.
“mining” means the process of extraction and beneficiation of mineral reserves to produce a marketable metal or mineral 
product. Exploration continues during the mining process and, in many cases, mineral reserves are expanded during the life 
of the mine operations as the exploration potential of the deposit is realized.
“net smelter return” means a payment made by a producer of metals based on the value of the gross metal production 
from the property, less deduction of certain limited costs including smelting, refining, transportation and insurance costs.
“open pit” means a mine working or excavation open to the surface.
“ore” means material containing minerals that can be economically extracted.
“outcrop” means that part of a geologic formation or structure that appears at the surface of the earth.
“oxide” means mineralized rock in which some of the original minerals have been oxidized (i.e., combined with oxygen).
“precious metal” means any of several relatively scarce and valuable metals, such as gold, silver and the platinum-group 
metals.
“probable mineral reserve” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“proven mineral reserve” has the meaning ascribed thereto in the CIM Standards, as per NI 43-101.
“pyrite” means a common, pale-bronze or brass-yellow mineral that is the most wide-spread and abundant of the sulfide 
minerals and occurs in all kinds of rocks.
“ramp” means an inclined underground tunnel which provides access for exploration or a connection between levels of a 
mine.
“reclamation” means the process of returning land to another use after mining is completed.
“recovery” means that portion of the metal contained in the ore that is successfully extracted by processing, expressed as a 
percentage.
“sampling” means selecting a fractional part of a mineral deposit for analysis.
“sediment” means solid fragmental material that originates from weathering of rocks and is transported or deposited by air, 
water  or  ice,  or  that  accumulates  by  other  natural  agents,  such  as  chemical  precipitation  from  solution  or  secretion  by 
organisms, and that forms in layers on the Earth’s surface at ordinary temperatures in a loose, unconsolidated form.
“sedimentary” means formed by the deposition of sediment.
“shaft”  means  a  vertical  passageway  to  an  underground  mine  for  moving  personnel,  equipment,  supplies  and  material 
including ore and waste rock.
- 46 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
“skarn”  means the  name  for the  metamorphic rocks surrounding an igneous intrusive  where it comes in contact  with a 
limestone or dolostone formation.
“stope” means an area in an underground mine where ore is mined.
“sulfide” means a compound of sulfur and some other element.
“vein” means a fissure, fault or crack in a rock filled by minerals that have traveled upwards from some deep source.
“waste” means rock lacking sufficient grade and/or other characteristics of ore.

Proxy Voting
All ECU Securities represented at the Meeting by properly completed and executed proxies will be voted on any ballot that 
may be called for and, where a choice with respect to any matter to be acted upon has been specified in the proxy, ECU 
Securities  represented  by  the  proxy  will  be  voted  in  accordance  with  such  instructions.  Registered  holders  of  ECU 
Securities will also be able to vote by calling a toll-free number or by using the internet, as provided for in the forms of 
proxy. In the absence of any such instruction, the persons whose names appear on the applicable printed forms of 
proxy will vote in favour of all the matters set out thereon. If any other business or amendments or variations to 
matters  identified  in  the  Notice  of  Special  Meeting  of  Securityholders  properly  come  before  the  Meeting,  then 
discretionary authority is conferred upon the persons appointed in the proxy to vote in the manner they see fit.
Advice to Beneficial Securityholders of ECU Securities
The information set forth in this section is of significant importance to many ECU Securityholders, as a number of ECU 
Shareholders  and  ECU  Warrantholders  do  not  hold  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants,  as  applicable,  in  their  own  names. 
Beneficial  Securityholders  of  ECU  who  do  not  hold  ECU  Securities  in  their  own  names  should  note  that  only  proxies 
deposited  by  Registered  Securityholders  whose  names  appear  on  the  records  of  ECU  as  the  registered  holders  of  ECU 
Securities can be recognized and acted upon at the Meeting. If ECU Securities are listed in an account statement provided 
to an ECU Securityholder by an Intermediary (such as a broker, investment dealer, bank, trust company, trustee or other 
intermediary), then in almost all cases those ECU Securities will not be registered in the ECU Securityholder’s name on the 
records  of  ECU.    Such  ECU  Securities  will  more  likely  be  registered  under  the  name  of  the  ECU  Securityholder’s 
Intermediary or an agent of the Intermediary. In Canada, the majority of such ECU Shares and ECU Warrants are registered 
under  the  name  of  CDS  &  Co.  (the  registration  name  for  CDS  Clearing  and  Depository  Services  Inc.,  which  acts  as 
nominee for many Canadian brokerage firms and other such Intermediaries). ECU Securities held by Intermediaries or their 
agents or nominees can only be voted (for or against resolutions) upon the instructions of the Beneficial Securityholder. 
Without specific instructions, Intermediaries and their agents and nominees are prohibited from voting ECU Securities for 
their clients. The directors and officers of ECU do not know for whose benefit the ECU Securities registered in the name of 
CDS & Co., or of other Intermediaries, are held. Therefore, Beneficial Securityholders should ensure that instructions 
respecting the voting of their ECU Securities are communicated to the appropriate person.
Applicable regulatory policy requires Intermediaries to seek voting instructions from Beneficial Securityholders in advance 
of  ECU  Securityholders’  meetings.  Every  Intermediary  has  its  own  mailing  procedures  and  provides  its  own  return 
instructions to clients, which should be carefully followed by Beneficial Securityholders in order to ensure that their ECU 
Securities are voted at the Meeting. The form of proxy supplied to a Beneficial Securityholder by its Intermediary (or the
- 49 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
agent of the Intermediary) is similar to the form of proxy provided to Registered Securityholders. However, its purpose is 
limited  to  instructing  the  Registered  Securityholder  (the  Intermediary  or  the  agent  of  the  Intermediary)  how  to  vote  on 
behalf  of  the  Beneficial  Securityholder.  The  majority  of  Intermediaries  now  delegate  responsibility  for  obtaining 
instructions from clients to Broadridge. Broadridge typically mails a scannable voting instruction form instead of the form 
of proxy. The Beneficial Securityholder is asked to complete the voting instruction form and return it to Broadridge by mail 
or facsimile. Alternatively, the Beneficial Securityholder may call a toll-free number or use the internet to vote the ECU 
Securities  held  by  the  Beneficial  Securityholder.  Broadridge  then  tabulates  the  results  of  all  instructions  received  and 
provides  appropriate  instructions  respecting  the  voting  of  ECU  Shares  to  be  represented  at  the  applicable  meeting.  A 
Beneficial Securityholder receiving a voting instruction form cannot use that voting instruction form to vote ECU 
Securities directly at the Meeting as the voting instruction form must be returned as directed by Broadridge well in 
advance of the Meeting in order to have the ECU Securities voted.
Although  a  Beneficial  Securityholder  may  not  be  recognized  directly  at  the  Meeting  for  the  purposes  of  voting  ECU 
Securities registered in the name of its Intermediary (or agent of the Intermediary), a Beneficial Securityholder may attend 
the  Meeting  as  proxyholder  for  the  Registered  Shareholder  and  vote  the  ECU  Securities  in  that  capacity.  Beneficial 
Securityholders who wish to attend the Meeting and indirectly vote their ECU Securities as proxyholders for Registered 
Securityholders should enter their own names in the blank spaces on the instruments of proxy provided to them and return 
the  same  to  their  Intermediary  (or  the  agent  of  the  Intermediary)  in  accordance  with  the  instructions  provided  by  such 
Intermediary (or agent), well in advance of the Meeting.
Quorum
In accordance with the Interim Order, a quorum for the Meeting is at least three (3) individuals present in person, each 
being an ECU Shareholder entitled to vote at the Meeting or being a duly appointed proxy for an absent ECU Shareholder 
so entitled, and holding or representing by proxy in the aggregate not less than ten percent (10%) of the total number of 
outstanding ECU Shares.

Background to the Arrangement
THE ARRANGEMENT
The Arrangement is the result of arm’s length negotiations conducted between representatives of ECU and Golden, and 
their respective legal and financial advisors.  The following is a summary of the background to the Arrangement.
On September 29, 2010, as part of its ongoing strategic planning process, ECU began to work with the Financial Advisor, 
which advised ECU in connection with potential strategic alternatives, including a range of potential transactions with a 
number of possible counterparties that would be identified by the Financial Advisor and agreed to by ECU.
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
The range of potential counterparties considered by ECU included both strategic and financial parties. Potential 
counterparties  were  identified  on  the  basis  of  their  ability  to  provide  ECU  with,  among  other  things,  enhanced 
liquidity  and  complementary  operational  competencies  including  mine  development  expertise.    In  addition, 
targeted strategic counterparties generally possessed an attractive, growth-oriented asset portfolio.
Over  the  months  that  followed,  ECU  met  with  a  number  of  potential  counterparties,  some  of  whom  executed 
confidentiality agreements and conducted various levels of due diligence, including site visits.
Based on Golden’s asset portfolio, balance sheet strength and management expertise, the Financial Advisor had 
identified Golden as a potential counterparty to a transaction with ECU.
On January 11, 2011, the Financial Advisor met in New York City with Golden, for which it had previously acted 
as an underwriter in connection with a public financing completed in March 2010, to discuss a range of issues, 
including  a  potential  strategic  investment  by  Golden  in  ECU  or  a  business  combination  between  the  two 
companies.
Subsequent to the January 2011 meeting with Golden, and in response to Golden’s request, the Financial Advisor 
provided Golden with certain publicly available information regarding ECU.
On  March  8,  2011,  at  the  Prospectors  and  Developers  Association  of  Canada  annual  conference  in  Toronto, 
representatives of the Financial Advisor had an additional informal discussion regarding ECU with a member of 
Golden’s management.
On April 4, 2011, Golden requested the Financial Advisor to arrange an introductory meeting with ECU.
- 51 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
!
!
!
!
!
!

On April 13, 2011, representatives of ECU, Golden and the Financial Advisor held an introductory meeting at the 
European  Gold  Forum  in  Zurich,  Switzerland.    Stephen  J.  Altmann,  President  of  ECU,  Jeffrey  Clevenger, 
Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Golden, and Jerry Danni, Executive Vice President of Golden, 
were in attendance. At this meeting, Messrs. Clevenger, Danni and Altmann provided general overviews of their 
companies based solely on publicly available information.  They discussed the possibility of a strategic business 
combination and whether each party was interested in pursuing further discussions.  Messrs. Clevenger, Danni and 
Altmann  concluded  the  meeting  with  an  agreement  to  continue  preliminary  discussions  and  to  enter  into  a 
confidentiality agreement in respect of the planned discussions.
Following the meeting in Zurich, Switzerland, Golden’s management and ECU’s management negotiated a mutual 
confidentiality agreement, which was executed on April 21, 2011.  The confidentiality agreement included a two 
year “standstill” agreement under which each of Golden and ECU agreed not to propose a takeover or business 
combination  transaction  to  the  other  or  its  shareholders  without  the  consent  of  the  other’s  board  of  directors.  
During this period, Mr. Clevenger and Mr. Altmann spoke by telephone and communicated by e-mail regarding 
the  coordination  of  initial  due  diligence  activities,  including  travel  to  ECU’s  Velardeña  District  Properties  in 
Mexico and Golden’s El Quevar Project in Argentina.
On April 27, 28 and 29, 2011, David Drips, Golden’s Project Director, Argentina, and Robert Blakestad, Senior 
Vice  President  and  Chief  Geologist  of  Golden,  conducted  on-site  due  diligence  at  ECU’s  Velardeña  District 
Properties and processing facilities. A representative of the Financial Advisor was also present.
On May 2, 2011, Golden was given electronic access to additional ECU technical data and corporate information.
On  May  10,  11  and  12,  2011,  Messrs.  Clevenger  and  Drips  conducted  additional  on-site  due  diligence  of  the 
Velardeña  District  Properties,  including  the  mines  and  processing  facilities.  In  addition,  on  May  11,  2011, 
Mr. Clevenger,  Mr. Altmann  and  Michel  Roy,  Chairman  and  Chief  Executive  Officer  of  ECU,  discussed  their 
views  regarding  the  potential  strategic  and  financial  benefits  of  a  business  combination  transaction  between 
Golden and ECU.  They agreed that a combined company would be stronger and better capitalized, and  would 
have better access to capital markets as a result of increased size and the combination of current silver and other 
metals production in Mexico, the El Quevar Project in Argentina, advanced exploration projects in Mexico and 
Peru,  and  a  pipeline  of  advanced  and  reconnaissance  exploration  projects.    They  agreed  that  ECU’s  producing 
operations in Mexico would benefit from the operations expertise and experience of Golden’s management, and 
that Golden’s exploration efforts would benefit from the participation of ECU management.  They also discussed 
the roles their respective management teams might have in the combined company, including the likelihood that 
Mr. Roy would serve as a consultant to the combined entity, and the potential for one of ECU’s directors to serve 
on the board of directors of the combined company.  They agreed that a business combination between the two 
companies  was  a  mutually  desirable  prospect  as  an  at-market  merger  of  equals,  although  no  specific  exchange 
ratio  was  discussed  at  that  time.    They  also  discussed  the  possibility  of  Golden  providing  financing  to  ECU 
pending completion of an agreed business combination transaction.  They agreed that Mr. Roy and members of his 
management would conduct a due diligence trip to Golden’s El Quevar Project during the week of May 23, 2011.  
They  further  agreed  that  it  would  be  desirable  for  the  two  companies  to  enter  into  an  exclusivity  agreement, 
pursuant to which they would agree to continue discussions and negotiations regarding a business combination, 
and not to hold such discussions with other parties, until June 30, 2011.
On  May  20,  2011,  ECU  received  a  non-binding  letter  of  intent  (the  “LOI”)  and  form  of  binding  exclusivity 
agreement (the “Exclusivity Agreement”) from Golden.  During the week of May 23, 2011, the parties and their 
legal and financial advisors discussed the structure of a potential transaction and negotiated the terms of the LOI 
and the Exclusivity Agreement.
On May 23, 24 and 25, 2011, ECU’s geological team, including Mr. Roy, Mr. Joaquin Rodriguez, Vice President 
of Exploration, and Mr. Jorge Lujan, Mine Manager, and  a representative of the Financial Advisor travelled to 
Argentina to conduct on-site due diligence on Golden’s asset, El Quevar.

On May 25, 2011, the ECU Board held a meeting to discuss the Golden proposal.  The Financial  Advisor and 
ECU’s  legal  counsel,  Blakes,  provided  the  ECU  Board  with  a  detailed  overview  of  the  key  terms  and 
considerations  of  the  LOI  and  the  Exclusivity  Agreement.    After  a  thorough  discussion  of  the  merits  and 
considerations of the proposed transaction, the ECU Board authorized Mr. Altmann to negotiate the terms of the 
LOI and the Exclusivity Agreement.
Mr. Altmann, along with the Financial Advisor and Blakes, negotiated the terms of the LOI and the Exclusivity 
Agreement for several days following the ECU Board meeting.
On May 31, 2011, ECU and Golden each executed the LOI and the Exclusivity Agreement pursuant to which the 
Parties agreed not to pursue a business combination transaction with any other party until June 30, 2011. The LOI 
did not provide for an agreed upon exchange ratio.
Following  the  execution  of  the  LOI  and  until  the  execution  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement,  representatives  of 
ECU  and  Golden  continued  their  due  diligence  investigations  and  interacted  regularly  as  the  Parties  sought  to 
reach agreement on the material terms of the Arrangement and the Private Placement and to draft the definitive 
documentation.
ECU continued to have intermittent conversations with a third party pursuant to the carve-out provisions of the 
Exclusivity Agreement. The third party was a partnership between a large private mining company and a private 
equity firm, both based in Europe. Discussions focused on a transaction whereby the third party would acquire a 
50% stake in the Velardeña Property and Chicago Property in exchange for an equity investment in ECU and a 
commitment  by  the  third  party  to  fund  development  and  construction  of  a  new  production  facility,  with  ECU 
retaining the remaining 50% stake in the form of a carried interest. The third party had conducted preliminary site 
due diligence; however, no confidentiality agreement had yet been signed. These discussions did not ultimately 
lead to the entering into of any agreements, whether binding or non-binding, between the parties.
Beginning on June 7, 2011, Golden sent additional personnel to conduct follow-up due diligence on the Velardeña 
District Properties and related processing facilities. Representatives of Sentient, which is a major shareholder of 
Golden and has a representative on the Golden Board, also visited the properties and facilities.
During the week of June 6, 2011, ECU and Golden each provided the other and their respective legal and financial 
advisors with access to an electronic data room containing non-public information responsive to the due diligence 
requests each had previously submitted to the other.  Golden, ECU and their respective legal and financial advisors 
conducted  due  diligence  reviews  of  materials  provided  until  the  date  definitive  transaction  agreements  were 
signed.
On  June  7,  2011,  Mr.  Altmann  met  with  Mr.  Clevinger  and  Mr.  W.  Durand  Eppler,  a  Director  of  Golden,  in 
Golden’s  offices  in  Golden,  Colorado  and  discussed  certain  management  issues  related  to  the  Combined 
Company, additional deal terms and mechanics.
ECU initially contacted the Fairness Advisor on June 9, 2011, and on June 10, 2011, ECU engaged the Fairness 
Advisor to prepare and, when required, provide an opinion as to the fairness to ECU Shareholders, from a financial 
point of view, of any transaction consideration in a contemplated transaction between Golden and ECU.
On June 10, 2011, Mr. Rodriguez of ECU travelled to Golden’s Zacatecas Project in Mexico to conduct additional 
detailed due diligence.  Each of ECU and Golden continued to conduct detailed technical, financial and legal due 
diligence during the weeks beginning June 13, 2011, and June 20, 2011.
Golden delivered the initial draft of the Arrangement Agreement to ECU on June 13, 2011.  From then until June 
24,  2011,  the  Parties,  their  legal  counsel    and  their  financial  advisors  negotiated  the  terms  of  the  arrangement 
agreement  and  related  documents,  including  a  term  sheet  for  a  convertible  debt  financing  contemplated  to  be 
provided by Golden to ECU, and exchanged drafts of the arrangement agreement and related documents.  During 
this period, Mr. Clevenger also discussed with Mr. Altmann and with members of the compensation committee of

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
the Golden Board regarding the terms on which Mr. Altmann would serve as President of the Combined Company, 
if a strategic combination were completed.
On June 13, 2011, the trading volume of the ECU Shares on the TSX was approximately 3.4 million shares and the 
share  price  closed  approximately  18%  over  the  June  10,  2011  closing  share  price.  The  TSX  contacted  Mr. 
Altmann regarding increased trading activity in the ECU Shares and, in response to questions, Mr. Altmann and a 
representative  of  Blakes  reported  that  ECU  was  in  discussions  with  Golden  regarding  a  potential  business 
combination transaction, but that no definitive agreements had been entered into and no exchange ratio had been 
agreed upon.
On the evening of June 21, 2011, the ECU Board held a meeting to discuss developments related to the proposed 
Arrangement and Private Placement. Representatives of the Financial Advisor and Blakes provided an update on 
the status of the proposed transaction, outstanding issues and key considerations.
On June 22, 2011, Messrs. Roy and Clevenger met in Denver, Colorado to discuss certain management matters 
relating to the Combined Company.
Over the evening of June 22, 2011 and through June 23, 2011, Mr. Clevenger and Mr. Altmann negotiated the 
final  terms  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement,  including  the  0.05  exchange  ratio,  and  Golden  and  ECU  and  their 
respective legal counsel and financial advisors worked to finalize the Arrangement Agreement, the terms of the 
Private Placement and related agreements.
On  the  evening  of  June  23,  2011,  the  Golden  Board  held  a  meeting  at  which  it  approved  the  proposed 
Arrangement and the Private Placement.
On the evening of June 23, 2011, the ECU Board convened a meeting to consider the proposed Arrangement and 
Private  Placement.  The  ECU  Board  was  joined  by  representatives  of  Blakes,  the  Financial  Advisor  and  the 
Fairness  Advisor.  At  this  meeting,  Mr.  Altmann  informed  the  ECU  Board  that  he  expected  the  Golden  Board 
would approve an exchange ratio of 0.05. On the basis of such exchange ratio, the Fairness Advisor provided its 
verbal  opinion  to  the  ECU  Board  that,  as  of  such  date,  and  subject  to  certain  assumptions,  limitations  and 
qualifications, the Arrangement is fair, from a financial point of view, to ECU Shareholders (other than Golden 
and its affiliates). The Fairness Advisor confirmed that it would provide its written Fairness Opinion soon after the 
Arrangement Agreement was executed. The terms of the Arrangement Agreement and the Subscription Agreement 
were thoroughly discussed among the ECU directors, the Financial Advisor and Blakes.
With  all  remaining  transaction  issues  having  been  settled  through  the  night,  the  ECU  Board  reconvened  its 
meeting early on the  morning of June 24, 2011, and unanimously approved the proposed Arrangement and the 
Private Placement.
ECU  and  Golden  executed  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  the  Subscription  Agreement  shortly  thereafter  and 
announced the Arrangement at approximately 10:00 a.m. (Eastern Time).

Recommendation of the ECU Board
ECU retained the Financial Advisor to act as its financial advisor and retained the Fairness Advisor to prepare the Fairness 
Opinion.  The Fairness Advisor has given an opinion, as of June 23, 2011, and based upon and subject to the scope of the 
review,  analysis  undertaken  and  various  assumptions,  limitations  and  qualifications  set  forth  in  its  opinion,  that  the 
Consideration to be paid by Golden to holders of ECU Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates) pursuant to the terms of 
the Arrangement is fair, from a financial point of view, to the holders of ECU Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates). 
The ECU Board, having taken into account such opinion of the Fairness Advisor and such other matters as it considered 
relevant,  has  unanimously  determined that  the  Arrangement  is  in  the  best  interest  of  ECU  and  is  fair  to  the  ECU 
Securityholders  from  a  financial  point  of  view.    Accordingly,  the  ECU  Board  unanimously  recommends  that  ECU 
Securityholders  (other  than  Golden  and  its  affiliates  for  which  no  recommendation  is  given)  vote  FOR  the 
Arrangement Resolution.

Reasons for the Arrangement
In  the  course  of  their  evaluation  of  the  Arrangement,  the  ECU  Board  consulted  with  ECU’s  senior  management,  legal
counsel, the Financial Advisor and the Fairness Advisor, reviewed a significant amount of information and considered a 
number of factors which show compelling business reasons for the Arrangement, including, among others, the following:
!
!
!
!
!
Review  of  Strategic  Alternatives.  The  Arrangement  was  arrived  at  following  an  extensive  review  of  strategic 
alternatives which was conducted with the assistance of the Financial Advisor, including considering a range of 
potential transactions with a number of possible counterparties identified by the Financial Advisor and agreed to 
by ECU.
The Arrangement creates a combined company with greater scale and financial strength and an enhanced capital 
markets profile:
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
the Combined Company is expected to have sufficient cash to advance expansion plans at the Velardeña 
District Properties and the continued development of the El Quevar Project; 
the  Combined  Company’s  basic  market  capitalization  will  be  over  US$600  million,  based  upon  the 
closing  trading  prices of  ECU  and  Golden  as  at  June  23,  2011,  with  an  expected  increased  liquidity 
profile on both the NYSE Amex and the TSX; and
the Combined Company’s increased scale is expected to improve access to global capital markets to assist 
future growth efforts.
The Arrangement combines complementary management teams with proven track records of success to enhance 
and expand the existing portfolio of combined assets:
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
Golden’s  management  team  has  strong  expertise  and  a  proven  track  record  in  mine  building  and 
operations,  which  can  be  leveraged  in  order  to  seek  to  optimize  and  potentially  expand  the  Velardeña 
District Properties mining operations;
ECU has an operations team totalling nearly 500 people that can operate mines and mills in Mexico as 
required by the planning team;
ECU’s exploration expertise is expected to further enhance exploration efforts at the El Quevar Project, 
the Zacatecas Project and other drill testing projects across South America; and
the Combined Company will have a large portfolio of projects which, combined with enhanced scale and 
broader reach, will create opportunities for growth in existing and new jurisdictions.

(cid:2)

ounces silver, 2 million ounces gold, 1 billion pounds lead and 1 billion pounds zinc; and
the Combined Company will have opportunities to expand its current resource base in Mexico, Argentina 
and Peru.

(Atlas); and
a large portfolio of approximately 40 exploration properties in the reconnaissance/target delineation stage 
located primarily in South America.

Exchange Ratio.  The following is a discussion of the Exchange Ratio in relation to trading prices of ECU Shares 
and Golden Stock on the Canadian Market and trading prices of Golden Stock on the TSX and on the U.S. Market. 
Whereas the Exchange Ratio represents a discount of 7% based on the closing trading prices of the ECU Shares 
and Golden Stock on the TSX on June 23, 2011, the last trading day prior to the date of announcement of the 
proposed Arrangement (6% if based on the closing trading prices of Golden Stock in the U.S. Market and the ECU 
Shares in the Canadian Market on such date), based on the VWAP for the 20 trading days ended June 23, 2011 in 
each case as indicated below, the Exchange Ratio represents a modest premium or an “at-market” transaction:
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
(cid:2)
the Exchange Ratio represents a premium of approximately 7% to the VWAP of the ECU Shares in the 
Canadian Market based on the June 23, 2011 closing trading price of Golden Stock in the U.S. Market 
(where most of Golden Stock trades);
the Exchange Ratio represents a premium of approximately 4% to the VWAP of the ECU Shares on the 
TSX based on the June 23, 2011 closing trading price of Golden Stock on the TSX; and
the Exchange Ratio represents an “at-market” transaction based on the VWAP of the ECU Shares in the 
Canadian Market and the VWAP of Golden Stock on the U.S. Market (or a 2% discount to the VWAP of 
the ECU Shares on the TSX, based on the VWAP of Golden Stock on the TSX).
The  Financial  Advisor  and  the  Fairness  Advisor.  The  ECU  Board  considered  the  financial  presentations  and 
advice of the Financial Advisor, as well as the Fairness Opinion of the Fairness Advisor delivered orally to the 
ECU Board on June 23, 2011, and subsequently confirmed in writing as of such date, as to the fairness, from a 
financial  point  of  view,  of  the  Consideration  to  be  received  by  ECU  Shareholders,  other  than  Golden  and  its 
affiliates, under the Arrangement.  The written Fairness Opinion is attached as Appendix D to this Circular.
Alternatives to the Arrangement.  The ECU Board will remain able to respond, in accordance with its fiduciary 
duties, to bona fide unsolicited written Acquisition Proposals that are more favourable to ECU Shareholders than 
the Arrangement and constitute Superior Proposals under the Arrangment Agreement.  Under such circumstances, 
subject to payment of the ECU Termination Fee in the amount of Cdn$10 million, ECU may, in accordance with 
the  Arrangement  Agreement,  terminate  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  approve  and  recommend  any  such 
Superior Proposal if Golden does not exercise its right to match such Superior Proposal in accordance with the 
Arrangement Agreement. The Golden Board has the same rights under the Arrangment Agreement, and Golden 
would be subject to payment of the Golden Termination Fee in the amount of Cdn$10 million if the Golden Board
wished  to  terminate  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  approve  and  recommend  any  Superior  Proposal  made  to 
Golden if ECU does not exercise its right to match such Superior Proposal in accordance with the Arrangement 
Agreement.
Intervening Events.  The ECU Board will also remain able to respond, in accordance with its fiduciary duties, to 
the  occurrence  of  any  Intervening  Event.  Under  such  circumstances,  ECU  may,  in  accordance  with  the 
Arrangement  Agreement,  change  its  recommendation  in  favour  of  the  approval  of  the  Arrangement  Resolution 
(subject to payment of the ECU Termination Fee if Golden elects to terminate the Arrangement Agreement as a 
result  of  such  change  of  recommendation)  if  Golden  does  not  exercise  its  right  to  respond  to  such  Intervening 
Event to the satisfaction of the ECU Board in accordance with the Arrangement Agreement.  The Golden Board 
will also be able to similary respond to any Intervening Event.
Termination Fee Reasonable. The ECU Board believes that the ECU Termination Fee payable to Golden in certain 
circumstances is reasonable and not preclusive of other proposals.

other than the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders, are free to support such Superior Proposal and vote against the 
Arrangement Resolution. In the event that the Arrangement Agreement is terminated by ECU or Golden to enable 
ECU to enter into an acquisition agreement  with a third party that  has  made a Superior Proposal and the ECU 
Termination Fee is paid, then the Voting Agreement to which the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders are party will 
also terminate and such securityholders will also be free to support such Superior Proposal.
Free  to  Support  Intervening  Event.  If  an  Intervening  Event  occurs,  ECU  Securityholders  other  than  the  ECU 
Locked-Up  Securityholders,  are  free  to  vote  against  the  Arrangement  Resolution.  In  the  event  that  the 
Arrangement Agreement is terminated by Golden as a result of ECU changing its recommendation in favour of the 
approval  of  the  Arrangement  Resolution  and  the  ECU  Termination  Fee  is  paid,  then  the  Voting  Agreement  to 
which the ECU Locked-Up Securityholders are party will also terminate and such securityholders will also be free 
to vote against the Arrangement Resolution.
Independent  Advice.  ECU  retained  independent  financial  and  legal  advisors  who  advised  ECU  throughout  the 
process as noted above.
Arm’s-length  Negotiations.  The  Arrangement  Agreement  is  a  result  of  arm’s-length  negotiations  between  ECU
and Golden.

Risk Factors of the Arrangement
In the course of its deliberations, the ECU Board also identified and considered a variety of risks and potentially negative 
factors in connection with the Arrangement, including, but not limited to, the following:
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
!
The Exchange Ratio is fixed and, as a result, the Golden Stock issued on closing of the Arrangement may have a 
market value different than at the time of announcement of the Arrangement.
The completion of the Arrangement is subject to several conditions that must be satisfied or waived.
The Arrangement Agreement may be terminated by ECU or Golden in certain circumstances, in which case the 
market price for ECU Shares may be adversely affected.
The  Combined  Company  will  incur  significant  transaction,  combination-related  and  restructuring  costs  in 
connection with the Arrangement.
The  Combined  Company  may  incur  significant  costs  related  to  contractual  arrangements  that  are  not  currently 
anticipated.
The exercise of Dissent Rights  may increase the consideration payable pursuant to the  Plan of  Arrangement or 
hinder the closing of the Arrangement.
The  directors  and  officers  of  ECU  may  have  interests  that  are  different  from  the  interests  of  other  ECU 
Securityholders.
The trading price of Golden Stock could be depressed by sales of shares of Golden Stock by ECU Securityholders 
or Golden Stockholders who sell their shares of Golden Stock.
The existence of a significant number of options and warrants may have a negative effect on the market price of 
Golden Stock.
The  ECU  Termination  Fee  provided  for  under  the  Arrangement  Agreement  may  discourage  other  parties  from 
attempting to acquire ECU. If ECU is required to pay the ECU Termination Fee and an alternative transaction is 
not completed, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
If ECU is required to pay the expense reimbursement fee contemplated by the Arrangement Agreement in certain 
circumstances, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
The Arrangement  will present challenges associated  with integrating operations, personnel and other aspects of 
ECU and Golden.
ECU  and  Golden  have  both  historically  incurred  operating  losses  and  operating  cash  flow  deficits  and  it  is 
expected that the Combined Company will continue to incur operating losses in the foreseeable future.
ECU’s and Golden’s properties may not contain mineral reserves.
The Combined Company is expected to continue to require substantial external financing to pay its operating and 
general and administrative expenses, continue the advancement of the Velardeña Property expansion and the El 
Quevar Project and fund its other exploration activities.
The  Combined  Company  will  be  subject  to  a  broad  range  of  Environmental  Laws  and  associated  costs  and 
liabilities.

if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.

!
!
The long-term cash flow and profitability of the Combined Company will be affected by changes in the prices of 
silver and other metals.
If the Combined Company is unable to obtain all of its required governmental permits or obtain property rights on 
favourable terms or at all, its operations could be negatively impacted.
The Combined Company may not meet key production or cost estimates.
See “Risk Factors”. Also see “The Arrangement – Opinion of the Fairness Advisor” and the financial statements of Golden 
incorporated by reference into this Circular.

The foregoing summary of the information and factors considered by the ECU Board is not intended to be exhaustive. In

the business, financial condition and prospects of ECU, and was also based on the advice of financial advisors and legal 
advisors to the ECU Board. In addition, individual  members of the ECU Board may  have assigned different  weights to 
different factors.

Terms of the Arrangement
The  purpose  of  the  Arrangement  is  to  effect  a  business  combination  between  ECU  and  Golden.  Pursuant  to  the 
Arrangement, Golden  will acquire all of the issued and outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants  and 
ECU will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Golden.  As a result of the Arrangement, ECU Shareholders (other than 
Dissenting Shareholders and Golden) will receive shares of Golden Stock for their ECU Shares at the Exchange Ratio plus 
a cash payment of Cdn$0.000394 for each ECU Share held, ECU Optionholders and ECU Warrantholders will receive in 
exchange for their ECU Options and ECU Warrants, respectively, Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement 
Warrants,  as  applicable,  adjusted  based  on  the  Exchange  Ratio,  and  the  ECU  Convertible  Noteholder  will  receive  ECU 
Replacement Notes  in exchange for its ECU  Convertible  Notes.   The Arrangement is to be carried out pursuant  to the 
Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of Arrangement.
At the Effective Time, the Plan of Arrangement (the full text of which is attached as Appendix C to this Circular) provides 
that  the  following  shall  occur  and  shall  be  deemed  to  occur  sequentially  in  the  following  order  without  any  further 
authorization, act or formality:
(a)

to ECU Shares occurring after the date of the Arrangement Agreement and prior to the Effective Time.
As  of  the  close  of  business  on  July  22,  2011,  the  number  of  issued  and  outstanding  ECU  Securities  was  as  follows:  
320,081,333 ECU Shares; 13,235,000 ECU Options; 44,365,826 ECU Warrants; and Cdn$15,000,000 principal amount of 
ECU Convertible Notes. Assuming no issuance of additional ECU Shares, ECU Options or ECU Warrants, Golden will 
issue approximately 16,004,066 shares of Golden Stock in exchange for ECU Shares and reserve approximately 2,880,042 
shares of Golden Stock for issuance on the exercise of Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants.
Upon the completion of the Arrangement: (a) former ECU Shareholders will own approximately 51% of the outstanding 
Golden Stock, assuming that no outstanding ECU Options and ECU Warrants are exercised before consummation of the 
Arrangement;  and  (b)  former  ECU  Securityholders  will  own  approximately  55%  of  the  outstanding  Golden  Stock if  all 
outstanding ECU Options and ECU Warrants are exercised before consummation of the Arrangement.
See the Plan of Arrangement attached as Appendix C for additional information.
Opinion of the Fairness Advisor
ECU  entered  into  an  engagement  letter  with  the  Fairness  Advisor  pursuant  to  which,  among  other  things,  the  Fairness 
Advisor  agreed  to  provide  ECU  with  its  opinion  as  to  the  fairness  of  the  Consideration  to  be  received  pursuant  to  the 
Arrangement,  from  a  financial  point  of  view,  to  ECU  Shareholders  other  than  Golden  and  its  affiliates.  Initially,  the 
Fairness Advisor orally delivered its opinion to the ECU Board that, as of June 23, 2011, the Consideration to be paid by 
Golden to holders of ECU Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates) pursuant to the terms of the Arrangement is fair, 
from a financial point of view, to the holders of ECU Shares (other than Golden and its affiliates). The Fairness Advisor 
subsequently delivered its written Fairness Opinion to the ECU Board which confirmed its oral opinion.
The full text of the Fairness Opinion, which sets forth the assumptions made, procedures followed, matters considered and 
limitations  and  qualifications  on  the  review  undertaken  in  connection  with  the  opinion,  is  attached  to  this  Circular  as 
Appendix D. The Fairness Advisor provided its opinion for the information and assistance of the ECU Board in connection 
with their consideration of the Arrangement. The Fairness Opinion addresses only the fairness of the Consideration to be 
received  by  the  ECU  Shareholders,  other  than  Golden  and  its  affiliates,  is  for  the  information  of  the  ECU  Board  in 
connection  with  its  consideration  of  the  proposed  Arrangement  only,  and  is  not  a  recommendation  as  to  how  any  ECU 
Securityholder should vote with respect to the Arrangement Resolution. ECU Securityholders are urged to read the entire 
Fairness  Opinion.  In  providing  the  Fairness  Opinion,  the  Fairness  Advisor  relied  upon,  and  assumed  the  completeness, 
accuracy and  fair representation of all  financial information,  forecasts and other information, data, advice, opinions  and 
representations obtained by it from public sources or provided by or on behalf of ECU. The terms of the  Arrangement, 
including the Exchange Ratio, were determined through negotiations between ECU and Golden and were not determined by 
the Fairness Advisor. The Fairness Opinion does not address the relative merits of the Arrangement as compared to any 
other business strategies or transactions that might be available to ECU, or the underlying decision of the ECU Board to 
recommend or effect the Arrangement. This summary of the Fairness Opinion is qualified in its entirety by reference to the 
full text of the Fairness Opinion and ECU Securityholders are urged to read the Fairness Opinion in its entirety.
The preparation of the Fairness Opinion by the Fairness Advisor involved various determinations as to the most appropriate 
and  relevant  assumptions  and  methods  of  financial  analysis  and  the  application  of  these  methods  to  the  particular 
circumstances and, therefore, the Fairness Opinion is not necessarily susceptible to partial analysis or summary description. 
Qualitative judgments were made based upon the Fairness Advisor’s assessment of the surrounding factual circumstances 
relating  to  the  Arrangement  and  its  analysis  of  such  factual  circumstances  in  its  best  judgment.  Any  attempt  to  select
- 65 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
portions of the Fairness Advisor’s analyses or of the factors considered, without considering all of the analyses employed 
and  factors  considered,  would  likely  create  an  incomplete  and  misleading  view  of  the  process  underlying  the  Fairness 
Opinion.
Under its engagement letter with the Fairness Advisor, ECU agreed to pay the Fairness Advisor a fee for the delivery of the 
Fairness  Opinion  and  ECU  also  agreed  to  indemnify  the  Fairness  Advisor  and  certain  related  persons  against  certain 
liabilities in connection with its engagement.
The  Fairness  Advisor  provides  independent  research,  Canadian  equity  sales  coverage,  trading  execution  and  investment 
banking  services  to  an  extensive  network  of  North  American  institutional  and  corporate  clients.  The  principals  of  the 
Fairness Advisor have been involved in a significant number of transactions involving fairness opinions and valuations of 
private and publicly-traded companies. The professionals involved in the preparation of the Fairness Opinion include senior 
officers and directors of the Fairness Advisor who are experienced in merger, acquisition and divestiture matters. The form 
and content of the Fairness Opinion were approved for release by the Management Committee of the Fairness Advisor.
The Fairness Advisor is not an insider, associate or affiliate of ECU or any of its respective associates or affiliates. Other 
than  its  engagement  in  connection  with  providing  the  Fairness  Option,  the  Fairness  Advisor  has  not  been  engaged  to 
provide any financial advisory services nor has it participated in any financings involving ECU or Golden or any of their 
respective associates or affiliates within the two years prior to the date of the Fairness Opinion.
Securityholder and Court Approvals
Securityholder Approval
Pursuant to the Plan of  Arrangement and the requirements of  Canadian Securities  Laws and  the TSX, the  Arrangement 
Resolution must be passed by: (a) at least 66 2/3% of the votes cast by ECU Shareholders present in person or represented 
by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to  vote; (b) at least  66 2/3% of the  votes cast by all ECU  Securityholders, voting 
together as a single class, present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to vote; and (c) a simple 
majority of the votes cast by ECU Shareholders present in person or represented by proxy at the Meeting and entitled to 
vote  after  excluding  the  votes  cast  in  respect  of  ECU  Shares  beneficially  owned  or  over  which  control  or  direction  is 
exercised by Mr. Michel Roy, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of ECU, and Mr. Stephen J. Altmann, President of 
ECU,  and  by  their  respective  related  parties  or  joint  actors.    See  “Securities  Law  Considerations  –  Canadian  Securities 
Laws – Requirement for Minority Approval under MI 61-101”.
Each  ECU  Security  that  is  voted  at  the  Meeting  will  vote  only  once  on  the  Arrangement  Resolution  but  three  separate 
tabulations  of  the  votes  will  be  conducted,  one  for  each  of  the  foregoing  required  approvals.    ECU  Shareholders,  ECU 
Optionholders and ECU Warrantholders are entitled to one vote for each ECU Share, ECU Option or ECU Warrant, as 
applicable, held by them, and the ECU Convertible Noteholder is entitled to such number of votes as is equal to the number 
of ECU Shares into which the ECU Convertible Notes held by it are convertible. The Arrangement Resolution must receive 
the required ECU Securityholder approval in order for ECU to seek the Final Order and implement the Arrangement on the 
Effective Date.

Court Approval of the Arrangement
The QBCA requires that the Court approve the Arrangement.
On  July  14,  2011,  ECU  obtained  the  Interim  Order  providing  for  the  calling  and  holding  of  the  Meeting  and  other 
procedural matters and filed a Notice of Hearing for a Final Order to approve the Arrangement. Copies of the Interim Order 
and the Notice of Hearing for a Final Order are attached as Appendix E and F, respectively, to this Circular.
The Court hearing in respect of the Final Order is expected to take place at 9:00 a.m. (Eastern Time), on August 31, 2011, 
or at any other date before or after August 31, 2011 (subject to ECU providing notification by news release, and serving 
notice on persons having filed a Notice of Appearance (defined below), of the new hearing date in accordance with the 
Interim Order), at the Quebec Courthouse located at 300 boulevard Jean-Lesage, Quebec City, Québec G1K 8K6, subject to 
obtaining the approval of the Arrangement Resolution at the Meeting. At the hearing, the Court will consider, among other 
things, the fairness of the terms and conditions of the Arrangement to those to whom securities will be issued.  The Court 
may approve the Arrangement in any manner the Court may direct, subject to compliance with such terms and conditions, 
if any, as the Court deems fit.  Prior to the hearing on the Final Order, the Court will be informed that the Final Order will 
also constitute the basis  for an exemption  from registration under the U.S. Securities  Act  for the Golden Stock, Golden 
Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants to be issued in the Arrangement to ECU Securityholders pursuant 
to the Section 3(a)(10) Exemption.
Under the terms of the Interim Order, each ECU Securityholder, as well as other interested persons, will have the right to 
appear and be heard at the hearing of the application for the Final Order, with a view to contesting the application for a 
Final Order or to make representations in relation thereto. Any person desiring to appear at the hearing of the application 
for the Final Order is required to file in the Court record and serve on ECU at the address set out below, at least five (5) 
clear juridical days prior to the hearing of the application for a Final Order, a notice of his, her or its intention to appear 
(“Notice  of  Appearance”),  including  his,  her  or  its  address  for  service,  together  with  a  written  contestation  or  written 
representations, as the case may be, supported, as to the facts, by affidavits and exhibits, if any, failing which such person 
shall not be permitted to contest the application for a Final Order. In the event that the application for a Final Order does 
not proceed on the date set forth in the Notice of Hearing for a Final Order, and is adjourned or postponed, only those 
persons who served and filed a Notice of Appearance in accordance with the Interim Order shall be given notice of the 
adjourned or postponed date of the Court hearing.
The Notice of Appearance and supporting materials must be served, within the time specified, on counsel for ECU at the 
following address:
Blake, Cassels & Graydon LLP
600 de Maisonneuve Blvd. West, Suite 2200
Montreal, Québec  H3A 3J2
Attention: Sébastien Guy
with a copy to counsel for Golden at the following address:
Fasken Martineau Dumoulin LLP
P.O. Box 242, Suite 3700
800 Victoria Square
Montreal, Québec  H4Z 1E9
Attention: Stéphanie Lapierre
ECU Securityholders who wish to appear and be heard or be represented at the Court hearing of the application for the 
Final Order should consult their legal advisors as to the necessary requirements.

Arrangement Mechanics
Payment of Consideration
Following receipt of the Final Order and prior to the filing of the Articles of Arrangement with the Enterprise Registrar, 
Golden shall deposit with the Depositary in escrow, for the benefit of holders of ECU Securities, sufficient funds, shares of 
Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants in the aggregate amounts necessary to pay the Consideration required by 
the Plan of Arrangement.  All money deposited or caused to be deposited shall be cash denominated in Canadian dollars in 
same day funds and shall not be used for any purpose except as provided in the Plan of Arrangement.
Subject  to  surrender  to  the  Depositary  for  cancellation  of  a  certificate  which  immediately  prior  to  the  Effective  Time 
represented outstanding ECU Shares or ECU Warrants, together with a duly completed and executed Letter of Transmittal 
and such additional documents and instruments as the Depositary may reasonably require, following the Effective Time the 
holder of such surrendered certificate shall be entitled to receive in exchange therefor, and the Depositary shall deliver to 
such holder, the Consideration to which such holder is entitled under the Plan of Arrangement, less any amounts described 
under “The Arrangement – Arrangement Mechanics – Withholding Rights” below, and any certificate so surrendered shall 
forthwith be cancelled.
Until surrendered, each certificate that immediately prior to the Effective Time represented ECU Shares or ECU Warrants 
shall be deemed after the Effective Time to represent only the right to receive, upon such surrender, the Consideration to 
which the holder thereof is entitled in lieu of such certificate under the Plan of Arrangement, less any amounts described 
under “Arrangement Mechanics – Withholding Rights” below. Any such certificate formerly representing ECU Shares or 
ECU Warrants not duly surrendered on or before the sixth anniversary of the Effective Date shall:
(i)
(ii)
cease to represent a claim by, or interest of, any former holder of ECU Shares or ECU Warrants of any 
kind or nature against or in ECU or Golden (or any successor to any of the foregoing); and
be deemed to have been surrendered to Golden and shall be cancelled.
Any right or claim to payment pursuant to the Plan of Arrangement that remains outstanding on the sixth anniversary of the 
Effective Date shall cease to represent a right or claim of any kind or nature whatsoever and the right of the former ECU 
Securityholder  to  receive  the  Consideration  to  which  such  holder  is  entitled  pursuant  to  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  shall 
terminate and be deemed to be surrendered and forfeited, for no consideration, to Golden (or any successor of Golden).
No holder of ECU Securities shall be entitled to receive any consideration with respect to such ECU Securities other than 
the Consideration to which such holder is entitled in accordance with the Plan of Arrangement and, for greater certainty, no 
such holder will be entitled to receive any interest, dividends, premium or other payment in connection therewith.
Withholding Rights
Golden, ECU and the Depositary, as applicable, shall be entitled to deduct and withhold from any Consideration payable or 
otherwise deliverable to any former holder of ECU Securities such amounts as Golden, ECU and the Depositary may be 
required to deduct and withhold therefrom under any provision of applicable Laws in respect of applicable taxes.  To the 
extent that such amounts are so deducted and withheld, such amounts shall be treated for all purposes hereof as having been 
paid to the person to whom such amounts would otherwise have been paid.  Golden, ECU or the Depositary, as applicable, 
may  sell  or  otherwise  dispose  of  such  portion  of  the  Consideration  otherwise  payable  to  such  holder  as  is  necessary  to 
provide sufficient  funds to enable Golden, ECU or the Depositary, as applicable, to comply  with such deduction and/or 
withholding requirements and Golden, ECU and the Depositary, as applicable, shall notify the holder thereof and remit any 
unapplied balance of the net proceeds of such sale.
No Fractional Securities will be issued
In accordance with the Plan of Arrangement, no fractional shares of Golden Stock, fractional Golden Replacement Options 
or fractional Golden Replacement Warrants shall be issued to any person pursuant to the Plan of Arrangement.  The number 
of shares of Golden Stock,  Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants to be issued to any person

if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
pursuant to this Plan of Arrangement shall be rounded up or down, as applicable, to the nearest  whole share of Golden 
Stock. For greater certainty, where such fractional interest is greater than or equal to 0.5, the number of shares of Golden 
Stock, Golden Replacement Options or Golden Replacement Warrants, as applicable, to be issued to any person will be 
rounded up to the nearest whole number and where such fractional interest is less than 0.5, the number of shares of Golden 
Stock, Golden Replacement Options or Golden Replacement Warrants, as applicable,  to be issued will be rounded down to 
the  nearest  whole  number.  In  calculating  such  fractional  interests,  all  ECU  Shares,  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants,  as 
applicable, registered in the name of or beneficially held by an ECU Securityholder or its nominee shall be aggregated.
Letters of Transmittal
Included  with  this  Circular  is  a  Letter  of  Transmittal  in  respect  of  ECU  Shares,  printed  on  blue  paper,  and  a  Letter  of 
Transmittal in respect of ECU Warrants, printed on yellow paper. In order to receive shares of Golden Stock and the cash 
payment for their ECU Shares or Golden Replacement Warrants for their ECU Warrants, as the case may be, Registered
Shareholders  or  Registered  Warrantholders  must  complete  and  sign  the  appropriate  Letter  of  Transmittal  and  deliver  it, 
together  with  certificates  representing  their  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants  and  the  other  required  documents,  to  the 
Depositary  in  accordance  with  the  instructions  contained  in  such  applicable  Letter  of  Transmittal  included  with  this 
Circular. The Letters of Transmittal contain procedural information relating to the Arrangement and should be reviewed 
carefully.  The  deposit  of  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants  pursuant  to  the  procedures  in  the  Letters  of  Transmittal  will 
constitute a binding agreement between the depositing ECU Shareholder or ECU Warrantholder, as applicable, and Golden 
upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in this Circular and the applicable Letter of Transmittal.
Copies of the Letters of Transmittal may be obtained by contacting the Depositary. The Letters of Transmittal will also be 
available on SEDAR at www.sedar.com under ECU’s profile.
Golden reserves the right to waive or not to waive any and all errors or other deficiencies in any Letter of Transmittal or 
other  document  and  any  such  waiver  or  non-waiver  will  be  binding  upon  the  affected  ECU  Shareholder  or  ECU 
Warrantholder. The granting of a waiver to one or more ECU Shareholders or ECU Warrantholders does not constitute a 
waiver for any other ECU Shareholder or ECU Warrantholder. Golden and the Depository reserve the right to demand strict 
compliance  with the terms of the Letters of Transmittal and the Arrangement. The method used to deliver the Letter of 
Transmittal and any accompanying certificates representing ECU Shares or ECU Warrants is at the option and risk of the 
holder surrendering them, and delivery will be deemed effective only when such documents are actually received by the 
Depositary. ECU recommends that the necessary documentation be hand delivered to the Depositary, and a receipt obtained 
therefor;  otherwise,  the  use  of  registered  mail  with  return  receipt  requested,  and  with  proper  insurance  obtained,  is 
recommended.
ECU Shareholders  whose ECU Shares, or ECU Warrantholders  whose ECU Warrants,  are registered in the name of an 
Intermediary (such as a broker, investment dealer, bank, trust company, trustee or other intermediary) or other nominee 
should contact that Intermediary or nominee for assistance in depositing their ECU Shares or ECU Warrants and should 
follow the instructions of such Intermediary or nominee in order to deposit their ECU Shares or ECU Warrants.
Lost, Stolen or Destroyed Certificates
In the event any certificate which immediately prior to the Effective Time represented one or more outstanding ECU Shares 
or ECU Warrants that are entitled to  Consideration pursuant to the Plan of  Arrangement shall  have been lost, stolen or 
destroyed,  the  Letter  of  Transmittal  should  be  completed  as  fully  as  possible  and  forwarded,  together  with  a  letter 
describing the loss, theft or destruction, to the Depositary.  Upon the making of an affidavit or statutory declaration of that 
fact  by  the  person  claiming  such  certificate  to  be  lost,  stolen  or  destroyed  and  who  was  listed  immediately  prior  to the 
Effective Time as the registered holder thereof on the ECU Share register or ECU Warrant register maintained by or on 
behalf  of  ECU,  as  applicable,  the  Depositary  will  deliver  in  exchange  for  such  lost,  stolen  or  destroyed  certificate  the 
Consideration that such holder is entitled to receive in exchange for such lost, stolen or destroyed certificate, provided that 
the  holder  to  whom  the  Consideration  is  to  be  delivered  shall,  as  a  condition  precedent  to  the  delivery,  give  a  bond 
satisfactory to Golden and the Depositary in such sum as Golden and the Depositary may direct (each acting reasonably), or 
otherwise  indemnify  Golden  and  the  Depositary  in  a  manner  satisfactory  to  Golden  and  the  Depositary  (each  acting 
reasonably) against any claim that may be made against Golden or the Depositary with respect to the certificate alleged to 
have been lost, stolen or destroyed.

Distributions with Respect to Unsurrendered Certificates
No dividend or other distribution declared or paid after the Effective Time with respect to Golden Stock shall be delivered 
to the holder of any certificate formerly representing ECU Shares unless and until the holder of such certificate shall have 
complied  with  the  provisions  of  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  in  respect  of  the  surrender  of  such  certificates.    Subject  to 
applicable Law and to the Plan of Arrangement, at the time of such compliance, there shall, in addition to the delivery of 
the Consideration to which such holder is thereby entitled, be delivered to such holder, without interest, the amount of any 
dividend or other distribution declared or made after the Effective Time with respect to the Golden Stock to which such 
holder is entitled in respect of such holder’s Consideration.
ECU Options
No  certificates  representing  ECU  Options  have  been  issued;  accordingly,  there  are  no  ECU  Option  certificates  to  be 
surrendered in connection with the Arrangement and ECU Optionholders do not need to complete a Letter of Transmittal 
with respect to their ECU Options.  The name of each ECU Optionholder shall be removed from the register of holders of 
ECU Options maintained by or on behalf of ECU as of the Effective Time and added to the register of holders maintained 
by or on behalf of Golden in respect of Golden Replacement Options as of the Effective Time in accordance with the steps 
of the Plan of Arrangement.  Golden will send each holder of Golden Replacement Options a notice confirming the details 
of their Golden Replacement Options following the Effective Date.
ECU Convertible Notes
The ECU Convertible Noteholder does not need to complete a Letter of Transmittal with respect to its ECU Convertible 
Notes.  Arrangements will be made by ECU and Golden following the Effective Date with respect to documentation related 
to the issuance of the ECU Replacement Notes.
Fees, Costs and Expenses of the Arrangement
Except as otherwise provided by the Arrangement Agreement in the event the Arrangement Agreement is terminated, all 
fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection  with the Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of Arrangement shall be 
paid by the party incurring the expenses.
ECU estimates that it will incur fees and related expenses in the aggregate amount of approximately Cdn$7.2 million if the 
Arrangement  is  completed  including,  without  limitation,  Fairness  Advisor  fees,  Financial  Advisors  fees,  legal  and 
accounting fees, filing fees, proxy solicitation fees and the costs of preparing, printing and mailing this Circular.
Interests of Directors and Officers of ECU in the Arrangement
In considering the recommendation of the ECU Board, ECU Securityholders should be aware that members of the ECU 
Board and the officers of ECU have interests in the Arrangement or may receive benefits that may differ from, or be in 
addition to, the interests of ECU Securityholders generally. These interests and benefits are described below.
All benefits received, or to be received, by directors or officers of ECU as a result of the Arrangement are, and will be, 
solely in connection with their services as directors or employees of ECU or the Combined Company.  No benefit has been, 
or  will  be,  conferred  for  the  purpose  of  increasing  the  value  of  consideration  payable  to  any  such  person  for  ECU 
Securities, nor is it, or will it be, conditional on the person supporting the Arrangement.

Severance and Change of Control Payments
Michel Roy.  Under the terms of a letter agreement dated May 31, 2011 between ECU and Mr. Michel Roy, Chairman and 
Chief Executive Officer of ECU, Mr. Roy is entitled to receive a Cdn$1,500,000 bonus payment if there is a “change of 
control” of ECU.  The Arrangement will result in a “change of control” for the purposes of such agreement with Mr. Roy;
accordingly, he will be entitled to a Cdn$1,500,000 bonus payment upon closing of the Arrangement. Mr. Roy has agreed 
with Golden to waive this payment and instead receive Cdn$1.5 million in shares of Golden Stock. The number of such 
shares of Golden Stock to be issued to Mr. Roy will be determined on the Effective Date based upon the VWAP of Golden 
Stock on the NYSE Amex for the five trading days immediately prior to the Effective Date. Based on the closing price of 
US$17.42 for Golden Stock on July 26, 2011 (and the currency exchange rate on such date), 91,128 shares of Golden Stock 
would be issued to Mr. Roy.
Stephen  J.  Altmann.    Under  the  terms  of  a  letter  agreement  dated  May  31,  2011  between  ECU  and  Mr.  Stephen  J. 
Altmann, President of ECU, Mr. Altmann is entitled to receive a Cdn$1,250,000 bonus payment if there is a “change of 
control”  of  ECU.  The  Arrangement  will  result  in  a  “change  of  control”  for  the  purposes  of  such  agreement  with  Mr.
- 71 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Altmann;  accordingly,  he  will  be  entitled  to  a  Cdn$1,250,000  bonus  payment  upon  closing  of  the  Arrangement.  In 
connection with the anticipated terms of Mr. Altmann’s intended employment with Golden following the Arrangement, as 
described  in  the  following  paragraph,  it  is  anticipated  that  Mr. Altmann  will  waive  the  benefit  of  the  change  of  control 
bonus payment and instead receive Cdn$1.25 million in restricted Golden Stock, of which 40%, 40% and 20% would vest 
on  the  first,  second  and  third  anniversaries,  respectively,  of  the  grant  date,  or  100%  would  vest  upon  termination  of 
Mr. Altmann’s employment with Golden for any reason. The number of such shares of restricted Golden Stock to be issued 
to Mr. Altmann will be determined on the Effective Date based upon the VWAP of Golden Stock on the NYSE Amex for 
the five trading days immediately prior to the Effective Date. Based on the closing price of US$17.42 for Golden Stock on 
July  26,  2011  (and  the  currency  exchange  rate  on  such  date),  75,940  shares  of  Golden  Stock  would  be  issued  to  Mr. 
Altmann.
The independent members of the ECU Board determined that ECU should enter into the May 31, 2011 letter agreements 
referred  to  above  with  each  of  Mr.  Roy  and  Mr.  Altmann  in  recognition  of  the  past,  and  anticipated  future,  significant 
efforts of these two senior officers in connection with the pursuit of strategic transactions for the benefit of ECU and its 
securityholders, and that the payments contemplated thereby were consistent with industry norms.
In addition with respect to Mr. Altmann, under the terms of the current employment agreement between Mr. Altmann and 
ECU, Mr. Altmann is entitled to receive a severance payment of Cdn$750,000 (being the sum of three years of current base 
salary and annual bonus) if he is terminated by ECU without cause or if he resigns following the sale or transfer of the 
assets or shares of ECU. However, in connection with the Arrangement, Golden intends to offer Mr. Altmann the position 
of President, with an annual salary of US$350,000, an annual target bonus equal to 50% of annual salary and an annual 
target equity award valued at 100% of annual salary. Accordingly, if Mr. Altmann is appointed to such position, he would 
not receive any severance payment pursuant to his current employment agreement with ECU.  In addition, Mr. Altmann 
will  be  offered  by  Golden  a  change  of  control  agreement  on  the  same  terms  as  the  change  of  control  agreements  with 
Golden’s  other  executive  officers,  including  an  enhanced  severance  payment  of  200%  of  target  salary  and  bonus  in  the 
event  of  termination  following  a  change  of  control,  and  will  be  eligible  to  participate  in  all  other  benefits  available 
generally to all salaried employees of Golden.
Dwight Walker.  Under the terms of the employment agreement between ECU and Mr. Dwight Walker, Chief Financial 
Officer of ECU, Mr. Walker is entitled to receive a severance payment of Cdn$450,000 (being the sum of three years of 
current  base  salary  and  annual  bonus)  if  he  is  terminated  by  ECU  without  cause  or  if  he  resigns  following  the  sale  or 
transfer  of  the  assets  or  shares  of  ECU.  Mr.  Walker  will  not  continue  as  an  employee  of  the  Combined  Company  and 
therefore, the Cdn$450,000 severance payment will be payable to him upon closing of the Arrangement.
Other Senior Management.  The ECU Board has also approved a discretionary pool of Cdn$500,000 to be paid, in the 
discretion of Mr. Roy and Mr. Altmann, to certain officers or employees of ECU upon consummation of the Arrangement. 
The recipients of the payments from this discretionary bonus pool have not been determined, but it is anticipated that Mr. 
Walker would receive a payment of Cdn$150,000. Neither Mr. Roy nor Mr. Altmann is eligible to receive payments from 
this discretionary bonus pool.
Any  change  of  control  bonus  payments  that  Mr.  Roy  and  Mr.  Altmann  are  entitled  to  receive  as  a  consequence  of  the 
Arrangement  are  considered  to  be  “collateral  benefits”  for  the  purposes  of  MI  61-101.  Accordingly,  Mr.  Roy  and  Mr. 
Altmann are considered to be “interested parties” to the Arrangement for the purposes of MI 61-101, and the votes attached 
to the ECU Securities owned or controlled by Mr. Roy and Mr. Altmann, and by their respective “related parties” or “joint
actors”  as  defined  under  MI-61-101,  will  be  excluded  in  determining  whether  minority  approval  of  the  Arrangement 
Resolution has been obtained at the Meeting.  For such purposes, Mr. Roy has confirmed that the only person  who  is a 
related party to him that owns or controls ECU Securities is his spouse, Lucie Larivière, and that he has no joint actors that 
own or control ECU Securities. Mr. Altmann has confirmed that he has no related parties or joint actors that own or control 
ECU Securities.
The  severance  payment  that  Mr.  Walker  is  expected  to  receive,  as  well  as  the  discretionary  bonus  payments  that  Mr. 
Walker  and  other  members  of  senior  management  (excluding  Mr.  Roy  and  Mr.  Altmann)  are  expected  to  receive,  as  a 
consequence of the Arrangement are excluded from the definition of “collateral benefits” under MI 61-101, because, among 
other  things,  at  the  time  the  Arrangement  Agreement  was  agreed  to,  none  of  the  intended  recipients  of  such  payments 
beneficially owned or exercised control or direction over 1% or more of the outstanding ECU Shares.
