See “Securities Law Considerations – Canadian Securities Laws – Requirement for Minority Approval under MI 61-101” 
for additional details.
Other Payments to Directors and Officers
In addition to the severance and change of control payments described above, the ECU Board has approved the payment of 
certain amounts to Mr. Roy and Mr. Altmann, as well as other members of ECU’s management team, as compensation for 
past services. The payments are in lieu of option awards that ECU planned to award to the individuals; ECU had previously 
concluded that such option awards were not advisable because of ECU’s ongoing review of strategic alternatives. The cash 
payments are equal to Cdn$175,000 for Mr. Roy, Cdn$150,000 for Mr. Altmann, and Cdn$100,000 in the aggregate for the 
remaining  members  of  ECU’s  management  team,  as  determined  in  the  discretion  of  Mr.  Roy  and  Mr.  Altmann.  It  is 
anticipated that ECU will make these payments prior to the consummation of the Arrangement. These payments are not 
contingent upon the completion of the Arrangement.
The ECU Board has also approved the payment of certain amounts to each of the two independent directors of ECU in 
consideration for past services. The cash payments for each are equal to Cdn$12,000 (representing Cdn$3,000 per quarter 
for the last four calendar quarters), plus an additional cash payment of Cdn$50,000. This Cdn$50,000 payment is in lieu of 
ECU Option awards that ECU planned to award to the directors. It is anticipated that ECU will make these payments prior 
to the consummation of the  Arrangement. Such payments are consistent  with ECU’s ordinary pay practices and are not 
contingent upon the completion of the Arrangement.
Indemnification of Directors and Officers
Under  the  Arrangement  Agreement,  Golden  agreed  that  it  shall  cause  ECU  and  its  subsidiaries  to  honour  all  rights  to 
expense reimbursement, indemnification or exculpation now existing in favour of present and former officers and directors 
of ECU and its subsidiaries as provided for in their respective articles and by-laws, and acknowledges that such rights shall 
survive the completion of the Plan of Arrangement and shall continue in full force and effect for a period of not less than 
six years from the Effective Date.
In addition, under the Arrangement Agreement, Golden agreed that it will either (a) purchase prepaid non-cancellable run-
off directors’ and officers’ liability insurance to be in effect without any reduction in scope or coverage for not less than six 
years from the Effective Date providing protection no less favourable than the protection provided by the policies currently 
maintained by ECU in favour of its directors and officers and providing protection in respect of claims arising from facts or 
events which occurred prior to the Effective Time or (b) purchase as an extension of the current insurance policies of ECU, 
prepaid non-cancellable run-off directors’ and officers’ liability insurance providing coverage comparable to that contained 
in the existing policies of ECU for six years from the Effective Time with respect to claims arising from or related to facts 
or events that occurred at or prior to the Effective Time, in each case subject to certain maximum purchase prices payable 
by Golden.
Private Placement
The following is a summary of the principal terms of the Private Placement. This summary does not purport to be complete 
and is qualified in its entirety by reference to the Subscription Agreement, the terms of the ECU Convertible Notes and 
related documents which have been filed by ECU on SEDAR at www.sedar.com under ECU’s profile.
On June 24, 2011, Golden and ECU entered into the Subscription Agreement pursuant to which ECU issued to Golden, on 
July 13, 2011, Cdn$15.0 million principal amount of ECU Convertible Notes. The Private Placement is intended to provide 
ECU with interim financing of its operations pending consummation of the Arrangement. The ECU Convertible Notes will 
mature on June 30, 2012 (subject to extension as described below), and are convertible by Golden at any time prior to 5:00 
p.m. (Eastern Time) on June 29, 2012 into ECU Shares at a rate of 1,032 ECU Shares for each Cdn$1,000 in principal 
amount converted, consistent with the Exchange Ratio.  Upon the occurrence of certain specified fundamental changes, the 
ECU Convertible Notes may be redeemed or converted into ECU Shares at the option of Golden based on 102% of the 
outstanding principal amount of the ECU Convertible Notes. The ECU Convertible Notes are also redeemable by ECU at 
any time after the Record Date and prior to their maturity date at 100% of their face value plus accrued and unpaid interest.  
ECU may elect to extend the maturity of the ECU Convertible Notes to December 31, 2012 upon the making of a cash
- 73 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
payment to Golden equal to 4% of the face value of the then outstanding ECU Convertible Notes, payable on the day the 
extension  option  is  exercised,  with  interest  accruing  on  the  ECU  Convertible  Notes  at  10%  per  annum  during  such 
extension period.
Under the terms of the ECU Convertible Notes, the proceeds of the Private Placement are held in an escrow account and 
may  only  be  used  by  ECU  for  specified  purposes,  including  (i) expenses  associated  with  development,  exploration, 
operating and general and administrative costs (including base salaries and employee benefits) relating to the development 
and  operating  activities  at  the  Velardeña  Property;  (ii) general  and  administrative  expenses,  including  base  salaries, 
employee benefits and the various expenses incurred in connection with the transactions contemplated by the Arrangement 
Agreement; (iii) regularly scheduled principal and interest payments on arm’s length indebtedness existing at the date of 
issuance of the ECU Convertible Notes; and (iv) such other expenditures as may be approved by Golden.  Bonus payments, 
severance payments, change of control payments or other termination payments are not permitted uses.  At the closing of 
the Private Placement, Cdn$2.85 million of the subscription proceeds  were released to ECU and the Cdn$12.15 million 
balance of the proceeds were placed in escrow.
Golden will have the right to vote the ECU Convertible Notes on the Arrangement Resolution at the Meeting together with 
the outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants voting as a single class. The ECU Convertible Notes shall 
be  entitled  to  such  number  of  votes  at  the  Meeting  as  is  equal  to  the  number  of  ECU  Shares  into  which  the  ECU 
Convertible Notes are convertible, currently being 15,480,000 votes.
THE ARRANGEMENT AGREEMENT
The Arrangement will be carried out pursuant to the Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of Arrangement. The following 
is a summary of the principal terms of the Arrangement Agreement. This summary does not purport to be complete and is 
qualified in its entirety by reference to the Arrangement Agreement, appended hereto as Appendix B, and which has been 
filed by ECU on SEDAR at www.sedar.com under ECU’s profile, and to the Plan of Arrangement, which is attached as 
Schedule A to the Arrangement Agreement and appended hereto as Appendix C.
The Arrangement Agreement contains representations and warranties made by ECU and Golden. These representations 
and warranties were made by and to the parties thereto for the purposes of the Arrangement Agreement and are subject to 
the limitations and qualifications agreed to by the parties in connection with negotiating and entering into the Arrangement 
Agreement.  In  addition,  certain  representations  and  warranties  were  made  as  of  specified  dates,  may  be  subject  to  a 
contractual standard of materiality different from what may be viewed as material to ECU Securityholders or may have 
been used for the purpose of allocating risk between the parties rather than for the purpose of establishing facts. Moreover, 
information concerning the subject matter of the representations and warranties may have changed since the date of the 
Arrangement Agreement.
On June 24, 2011, ECU and Golden entered into the Arrangement Agreement, pursuant to which ECU and Golden agreed 
that, subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Arrangement Agreement, the Parties would implement the Plan of 
Arrangement whereby Golden will acquire all of the issued and outstanding ECU Shares, ECU Options and ECU Warrants, 
and the ECU Convertible Notes would be replaced by the ECU Replacement Notes. As a result of the Arrangement, each 
ECU  Shareholder  (other  than  Dissenting  Shareholders  and  Golden)  will  receive  0.05  of  a  share  of  Golden  Stock  and 
Cdn$0.000394  in  cash  for  each  ECU  Share  held;  each  ECU  Optionholder  and  ECU  Warrantholder  will  receive  Golden 
Replacement  Options  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants,  respectively,  for  their  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants, 
exercisable to acquire that number of shares of Golden Stock that such holders would have acquired if they had exercised 
their  ECU  Options  or  ECU  Warrants,  as  applicable,  immediately  prior  to  the  Effective  Time;  the  ECU  Convertible 
Noteholder  will  receive  ECU  Replacement  Notes  in  replacement  of  its  outstanding  ECU  Convertible  Notes;  and  the 
Shareholder Rights Plan will be terminated and all SRP Rights will expire. The terms of the Arrangement Agreement are 
the result of arm’s length negotiations between ECU and Golden and their respective advisors.

Adverse Recommendation Change; Superior Proposal; Right to Match or Respond
ECU  may  make  an  ECU  Board  Change  in  Recommendation  and  Golden  may  make  a  Golden  Board  Change  in 
Recommendation (in each case, an “Adverse Recommendation Change”) (i) following receipt of an Acquisition Proposal 
that it determines to be a Superior Proposal or (ii) solely in response to any Intervening Event, in each case if it determines 
in good faith, after consultation with its legal advisors, that the failure to take such action would be inconsistent with its 
fiduciary duties under applicable Law.
Upon payment of the ECU Termination Fee, the ECU Board may terminate the Arrangement Agreement in order to accept 
and enter into an agreement in respect of an Acquisition Proposal that the ECU Board in good faith, after consultation with 
its  financial  and  outside  legal  advisors,  has  determined  is  a  Superior  Proposal.  Golden  will  have  the  right,  but  not  the 
obligation, to amend the terms of the Arrangement upon notification by ECU of a Superior Proposal or Intervening Event, 
as applicable, within a five (5) Business Day response period. Within five (5) Business Days of receiving any such proposal 
by Golden to amend the terms of the Arrangement, the ECU Board shall review and determine whether the Acquisition 
Proposal  to  which  Golden  is  responding  would  continue  to  be  a  Superior  Proposal,  or  whether  the  Adverse 
Recommendation  Change  is  still  necessary,  when  assessed  in  light  of  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement as they are proposed by Golden to be amended. If the ECU Board determines that, in light of the proposed 
amendment  by  Golden,  the  Acquisition  Proposal  to  which  Golden  is  responding  would  not  continue  to  be  a  Superior 
Proposal, or the Adverse Recommendation Change would not be necessary, ECU is required to enter into an amendment to 
the  Arrangement  Agreement  to  give  effect  to  such  amendments  and  the  ECU  Board  must  promptly  reaffirm  its 
recommendation of the Plan of Arrangement.
Reciprocally, upon payment of the Golden Termination Fee, the Golden Board may terminate the Arrangement Agreement 
in order to accept and enter into an agreement in respect of an Acquisition Proposal that the Golden Board in good faith, 
after consultation with its financial and outside legal advisors, has determined is a Superior Proposal. ECU will have the 
right, but not the obligation, to amend the terms of the Arrangement upon notification by Golden of a Superior Proposal or 
Intervening  Event,  as  applicable,  within  a  five  (5)  Business  Day  response  period.  Within  five  (5)  Business  Days  of
- 78 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
receiving any such proposal by ECU to amend the terms of the Arrangement, the Golden Board shall review and determine 
whether the Acquisition Proposal to which ECU is responding would continue to be a Superior Proposal, or whether the 
Adverse Recommendation Change is still necessary, when assessed in light of the Arrangement Agreement and the Plan of 
Arrangement as they are proposed by ECU to be amended. If the Golden Board determines that, in light of the proposed 
amendment by ECU, the Acquisition Proposal to which ECU is responding would not continue to be a Superior Proposal, 
or the Adverse Recommendation Change would not be necessary, Golden is required to enter into an amendment to the 
Arrangement  Agreement  to  give  effect  to  such  amendments  and  the  Golden  Board  must  promptly  reaffirm  its 
recommendation of the Plan of Arrangement.

RISK FACTORS
In assessing the Arrangement, ECU Securityholders should carefully consider the risks described in the Golden Annual 
Report and the ECU AIF, each of which is incorporated by reference in this Circular and is filed on SEDAR, together 
with  the  other  information  contained  in  or  incorporated  by  reference  into  this  Circular.    Additional  risks  and 
uncertainties, including those currently unknown to or considered to be not material by ECU, may also adversely affect 
the business of the Combined Company or any one or more of Golden, ECU and the Combined Company.  Risks related 
to Golden are set out under “Information Concerning Golden – Risk Factors Related to Golden” in this Circular.  No 
relative weight or importance has been assigned to the following risk factors, and no meaning should be inferred from 
the order in which the risk factors have been presented in this Circular.
The Arrangement and the operations of the Combined Company are subject to certain risks including the following:
Risks Related to the Arrangement
The Exchange Ratio is fixed and, as a result, the Golden Stock issued on closing of the Arrangement may have a market 
value different than at the time of announcement of the Arrangement.
Pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  each  ECU  Shareholder  will  be  entitled  to  receive  0.05  shares  of  Golden  Stock  and 
Cdn$0.000394 in cash for each ECU Share held. The Exchange Ratio will not be adjusted to reflect any changes in the 
market  value  of  Golden  Stock  or  the  ECU  Shares  at  the  Effective  Time.  The  market  value  of  the  Golden  Stock  at  the 
Effective Time may vary significantly from the market value of the Golden Stock immediately prior to the announcement 
of  the  Arrangement  and  at  the  date  of  this  Circular.  If  the  market  value  of  Golden  Stock  declines,  the  value  of  the 
consideration  received  by  ECU  Securityholders  will  decline  as  well.  Variations  may  occur  as  a  result  of  changes  in,  or 
market  perceptions  of  changes  in,  the  business,  operations  or  prospects  of  Golden,  ECU  and  the  Combined  Company,
- 83 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
regulatory considerations, general market and economic conditions, changes in metal prices and other factors over which 
neither ECU nor Golden has control.
The Completion of the Arrangement is subject to several conditions that must be satisfied or waived.
Completion of the Arrangement is conditional upon certain conditions being satisfied or waived.  There can be no certainty 
that these conditions will be satisfied or waived.
In  addition,  the  Arrangement  is  conditional  on  receiving  certain  third  party  approvals  or  consents  that  are  beyond  the 
control of ECU or Golden, including, but not limited to, ECU Securityholder approval, Golden Stockholder approval, TSX 
approval of the listing of the Golden Stock and Golden Replacement February 2009 Warrants to be issued in connection 
with  the  Arrangement,  NYSE  Amex  approval  of  the  listing  of  the  Golden  Stock  to  be  issued  in  connection  with  the 
Arrangmement, and other third party approvals and consents.
If for any reason the conditions to the Arrangement are not satisfied or waived and the Arrangement is not completed, the 
market price of ECU Shares may be adversely affected.
The Arrangement Agreement may be terminated by ECU or Golden in certain circumstances, in which case the market 
price for ECU Shares may be adversely affected.
Each of ECU and Golden has the right to terminate the Arrangement  Agreement in certain circumstances. Accordingly, 
there  is  no  certainty  that  the  Arrangement  Agreement  will  not  be  terminated  by  either  ECU  or  Golden  before  the 
completion of the Arrangement.
If the Arrangement Agreement is terminated, there is no assurance that the ECU Board will be able to find a party willing to 
pay  an  equivalent  or  a  more  attractive  price  for  ECU  Shares  than  the  price  to  be  paid  pursuant  to  the  terms  of  the 
Arrangement Agreement.
If the Arrangement Agreement is terminated, ECU will need to raise money to refinance existing indebtedness and fund 
operations. There is no assurance that ECU will be able to arrange financing on attractive terms or at all.
The Combined Company will incur significant transaction, combination-related and restructuring costs in connection 
with the Arrangement.
Golden and ECU expect to incur transaction fees and other expenses related to the Arrangement totalling approximately 
US$12.0 million, including financial advisors’ fees, filing fees, legal and accounting fees, soliciting fees, regulatory fees 
and  mailing  costs.    ECU  expects  to  incur  costs  for  executive  bonuses  and  change  of  control  payments  related  to  the 
Arrangement  totalling  approximately  Cdn$4.0  million  (some  of  which  are  expected  to  be  paid  in  Golden  Stock).    The 
Combined Company also expects to incur significant costs associated with combining the operations of the two companies. 
It is difficult to predict the amount of these costs before the integration process begins.  The Combined Company may incur 
additional unanticipated costs as a consequence of difficulties arising from efforts to integrate the operations of the two 
companies. Although ECU expects that the elimination of duplicative costs, as well as the realization of other efficiencies 
related to the integration of the businesses, can offset incremental transaction, combination-related and restructuring costs 
over time, ECU cannot assure that this net benefit will be achieved in the near term, or at all.
The  Combined  Company  may  incur  significant  costs  related  to  contractual  arrangements  that  are  not  currently 
anticipated.
The Combined Company may incur significant costs related to contractual arrangements that are not currently anticipated.  
For  example,  if  the  Arrangement  is  completed,  under  certain  circumstances  ECU’s  term  loan  lender  may  terminate  its 
contractual arrangements with ECU.  Although ECU is attempting to obtain the consent of ECU’s term loan lender to the 
Arrangement, ECU may not be successful in these efforts. If the Arrangement is completed without the consent of ECU’s 
term loan lender, the Combined Company may be required, in certain circumstances, to immediately repay the full amount 
borrowed under the term loan facility (expected to be approximately US$16.0 million on the Effective Date), plus certain 
other amounts.  There may be other agreements with similar provisions, contracts with respect to which there are disputes
- 84 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
and contractual obligations of which management is not currently aware, any of which could impose unanticipated costs on 
the  Combined  Company  following  completion  of  the  Arrangement.    If  these  events  were  to  occur,  the  additional 
expenditures  in  connection  with  repayment  of  the  term  loan  or  other  unanticipated  costs  would  significantly  reduce  the 
amount  of  cash  currently  expected  to  be  available  for  deployment  at  the  El  Quevar  Project,  the  Velardeña  District 
Properties, or other properties in the Combined Company’s exploration portfolio on the schedule currently anticipated.
The exercise of Dissent Rights may increase the Consideration payable pursuant to the Plan of Arrangement or hinder 
the closing of the Arrangement.
The  exercise  of  Dissent  Rights  by  Registered  Shareholders  may  increase  the  Consideration  payable  to  such  Registered 
Shareholders. While Golden and ECU believe that the value of the Consideration to be paid to ECU Shareholders pursuant 
to the Arrangement is equal to or exceeds the fair value of the ECU Shares, there can be no assurance that a court would 
agree  with  this  assessment  and  consequently  the  amount  any  Dissenting  Shareholders  receive  could  be  higher  than  the 
Consideration to which those Registered Shareholders would have been entitled under the Arrangement Agreement.
Furthermore, if more than 5% of the Registered Shareholders exercise Dissent Rights, Golden has the option to not proceed 
with the Arrangement.
The directors and officers of ECU may have interests that are different from the interests of other ECU Securityholders.
ECU  will  make  bonus  payments  for  successful  completion  of  the  Arrangement  to  certain  of  its  officers  totalling 
approximately Cdn$3.3 million (some of which are expected to be paid in Golden Stock) and severance payments shall be 
made  to  certain  of  its  officers  upon  closing  the  Arrangement  totalling  approximately  Cdn$0.7 million.    See  “The 
Arrangement – Interests of Directors and Officers of ECU in the Arrangement”.
These  payments  and  potential  benefits  give  the  directors  and  management  of  ECU  an  interest  in  the  Arrangement  that 
differs from the interest of other ECU Securityholders.
The trading price of Golden Stock could be depressed by sales of shares of Golden Stock by ECU Securityholders or 
Golden Stockholders who sell their shares of Golden Stock.
Some ECU Securityholders may intend not to hold Golden Stock and some Golden Stockholders may decide to sell their 
shares of Golden Stock following the Arrangement, particularly if the market reaction to the Arrangement is not favourable. 
If a significant number of Golden Stockholders or former ECU Securityholders seek to sell their shares of Golden Stock 
following completion of the Arrangement, the trading price of Golden Stock may be adversely affected.  A decrease in the 
trading price of the Golden Stock could impair the Combined Company’s ability to raise capital through future sales of 
common stock.
The existence of a significant number of options and warrants may have a negative effect on the market price of Golden 
Stock.
ECU currently has outstanding ECU Options and ECU Warrants to purchase ECU Shares, which will, in the Arrangement, 
be  replaced  by  the  Golden  Replacement  Options  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  to  purchase  Golden  Stock.    The 
Golden  Replacement  Options  will  consist  of  employee  options  to  purchase  661,750  shares  of  Golden  Stock  at  exercise 
prices ranging from Cdn$16.00 to Cdn$31.80, and expiring between September 2011 and October 2014, and the Golden 
Replacement  December  2009  Warrants  and  Golden  Replacement  February  2009  Warrants  will  consist  of  warrants  to 
purchase  386,363  and  1,831,929  shares  of  Golden  Stock,  respectively,  at  exercise  prices  of  Cdn$18.00  and  Cdn$19.00, 
respectively, expiring in December 2011 and February 2014, respectively.  The existence of securities available for exercise 
and resale is referred to as an “overhang”, and, particularly if such options and warrants are “in the money”, the anticipation 
of potential sales could exert downward pressure on the market price of Golden Stock.

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
The  ECU  Termination  Fee  provided  for  under  the  Arrangement  Agreement  may  discourage  other  parties  from 
attempting to acquire ECU. If ECU is required to pay the ECU Termination Fee and an alternative transaction is not 
completed, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
Under the Arrangement Agreement, ECU is required to pay the ECU Termination Fee in the event that the Arrangement is 
terminated in certain circumstances related to a possible alternative transaction to the Arrangement.  The ECU Termination 
Fee  may discourage other parties  from attempting to acquire the ECU Shares, even if those parties  would otherwise be 
willing to offer greater value to ECU Shareholders than that offered by Golden under the Arrangement. Moreover, if ECU 
is required to pay the ECU Termination Fee under the Arrangement Agreement and ECU does not enter into or complete an 
alternative transaction, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.  See “The Arrangement Agreement 
– Termination of the Arrangement Agreement” in this Circular. Additionally, ECU will still have a Cdn$15 million debt 
owing to Golden pursuant to the ECU Convertible Notes.
If  ECU  is  required  to  pay  the  expense  reimbursement  fee  contemplated  by  the  Arrangement  Agreement  in  certain 
circumstances, ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected.
If the Arrangement Agreement is terminated by Golden as a result of a breach of any representation or warranty or failure 
to perform a covenant by ECU that would cause any of the conditions precedent in favour of Golden not to be satisfied, or
if the Meeting has not occurred by the date provided for in the Arrangment Agreement, ECU shall be required to pay to 
Golden Cdn$2,500,000 in respect of the fees, costs and expenses incurred by Golden in connection with the transactions 
contemplated  by  the  Arrangement  Agreement  and  the  Plan  of  Arrangement.    If  ECU  is  required  to  pay  such  expense 
reimbursement to Golden, in circumstances where ECU has not entered into an alternative transaction to the Arrangement, 
ECU’s financial condition will be materially adversely affected. Additionally, ECU will still have a Cdn$15 million debt 
owing to Golden pursuant to the ECU Convertible Notes.
Risks Related to the Operations of the Combined Company
After the completion of the Arrangement, the business of the Combined Company, as well as the price of Golden Stock, 
will be subject to numerous risks currently affecting the businesses of Golden and ECU.
The Arrangement will present challenges associated with integrating operations, personnel and other aspects of ECU 
and Golden.
The Arrangement will subject ECU to any environmental, contractual or other obligations and liabilities of Golden, some of 
which  may  be  unknown  to  management  of  ECU.  While  ECU  and  its  legal  and  financial  advisors  have  conducted  due 
diligence  on  Golden  and  its  business,  there  can  be  no  assurance  that  ECU  is  aware  of  all  obligations  and  liabilities  of 
Golden. These liabilities, and any additional risks and uncertainties related to Golden’s business and to the Arrangement 
not currently known to ECU or that ECU may currently be aware of, but that prove to be more significant than assessed or 
estimated  by  ECU,  could  negatively  impact  the  business,  financial  condition  and  results  of  operations  of  the  Combined 
Company following consummation of the Arrangement.
In  addition,  the  results  of  the  Combined  Company  following  the  Arrangement  will  depend  in  part  upon  the  Combined 
Company’s  ability  to  integrate  the  businesses  of  ECU  and  Golden  in  an  efficient  and  effective  manner.  The  attempt  to 
integrate  two  companies  that  have  previously  operated  independently  may  result  in  significant  challenges,  and  the
Combined Company may be unable to accomplish the integration smoothly or successfully. In particular, the necessity of 
coordinating  geographically  dispersed  organizations  and  addressing  possible  differences  in  corporate  cultures  and 
management  philosophies  may  increase  the  difficulties  of  integration.  ECU  has  operated  as  a  Québec  corporation,  with 
substantially all of its personnel and operations in Mexico, and Golden has not previously conducted mining operations in 
Mexico. The integration will require the dedication of significant management resources, which may temporarily distract 
management’s  attention  from  the  day-to-day  operations  of  the  businesses  of  the  Combined  Company.  In  addition,  the 
Combined Company may adjust the way in which ECU has conducted its operations and utilized its properties, which may 
require  retraining  and  development  of  new  procedures  and  methodologies.  The  process  of  integrating  operations  and 
making such adjustments after the Arrangement could cause an interruption of, or loss of momentum in, the activities of 
one or more of the Combined Company’s businesses and the loss of key personnel. Employee uncertainty, lack of focus or
- 86 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
turnover  during  the  integration  process  may  also  disrupt  the  businesses  of  the  Combined  Company.  Any  inability  of 
management  to  integrate  the  operations  of  Golden  and  ECU  successfully  could  have  a  material  adverse  effect  on  the 
business and financial condition of the Combined Company.
ECU and Golden have both historically incurred operating losses and operating cash flow deficits and it is expected that 
the Combined Company will continue to incur operating losses in the foreseeable future.
ECU and Golden have a history of operating losses and it is expected that the Combined Company will continue to incur 
operating losses unless and until such time as ECU’s Velardeña Properties in Central Mexico, Golden’s El Quevar Project 
in  Argentina,  or  another  of  the  exploration  properties  generates  sufficient  revenue  to  fund  continuing  operations  of  the 
Combined  Company.  None  of  Golden’s  properties  is  currently  in  commercial  production.    While  ECU  is  currently  in 
production at its Velardeña District Properties, ECU is still considered to be a development stage company, as ECU has not 
determined that a sufficient portion of its  mineral resources are economically exploitable and, accordingly, ECU has no 
mineral reserves.  It is not expected that revenues generated by production at ECU’s properties will exceed the expenses of 
the Combined Company for at least the next few years. It is expected that the Combined Company’s operating expenses, 
capital  expenditures  and  other  expenses  will  increase  in  future  years  as  it  advances  exploration,  development  and 
commercial production of the Combined Company’s properties and any other properties that it may acquire. The amounts 
and timing of expenditures will depend on the progress of efforts to expand production at the Velardeña District Properties, 
advance the El Quevar Project and continue exploration at these and other properties, the results of consultants’ analyses 
and recommendations, the rate at which operating losses are incurred, the execution of any joint venture agreements with 
strategic  partners,  if  any,  and  potential  future  acquisition  of  additional  properties,  in  addition  to  other  factors,  many  of 
which  will  be  beyond  control  of  management.  It  is  expected  that  the  advancement  or  development  of  the  Combined 
Company’s properties and any other properties it may acquire will require the commitment of substantial resources. There 
can be no assurance that the Combined Company will continue to generate revenues or will ever achieve profitability.
ECU’s and Golden’s properties may not contain mineral reserves.
None of the El Quevar Project, the Velardeña District Properties or any of Golden’s or ECU’s other properties, has been 
shown  to  contain  proven  or  probable  mineral  reserves.  Expenditures  made  in  the  exploration  and  advancement  of  the 
properties of the Combined Company may not result in discoveries of commercially recoverable quantities of ore. Most 
exploration projects do not result in the discovery of commercially mineable ore deposits and there is no assurance that any 
mineral deposit identified will qualify as an ore body that can be legally and economically exploited or that any particular 
level of recovery of silver from discovered mineralization will in fact be realized.
MICON has completed technical reports on Golden’s El Quevar Property, which indicated the presence of indicated and 
inferred resources and on ECU’s Velardeña District Properties, which indicated the presence of measured, indicated and 
inferred resources.  Measured, indicated and inferred resource figures based on estimates made by geologists are inherently 
imprecise  and  depend  on  geological  interpretation  and  statistical  inferences  drawn  from  drilling  and  sampling  that  may 
prove to be unreliable or inaccurate. There is no assurance that these estimates will be accurate or that proven and probable 
mineral  reserves  will  be  identified  at  the  El  Quevar  Property,  the  Velardeña  District  Properties  or  any  of  Golden’s  and 
ECU’s other properties.  Even if the presence of reserves is established at a project, the economic viability of the project 
may  not  justify  exploitation.  Management  of  the  Combined  Company  plans  to  spend  significant  amounts  on  the 
advancement  of  the  El  Quevar  Project  and  the  expansion  of  the  Velardeña  District  Properties  prior  to  establishing  the 
economic viability of the project in a technical report compliant with NI 43-101.
Estimates  of  reserves,  mineral  deposits  and  production  costs  can  also  be  affected  by  such  factors  as  governmental 
regulations and requirements, fluctuations in metals prices or costs of essential materials or supplies, environmental factors, 
unforeseen technical difficulties and unusual or unexpected geological formations. In addition, the grade of ore ultimately 
mined  may  differ  from  that  indicated  by  drilling  results,  sampling,  feasibility  studies  or  technical  reports.    Short-term 
factors relating to reserves, such as the need for orderly development of ore bodies or the processing of new or different 
grades,  may also have an adverse effect on  mining operations and on the results of operations. Silver or other  minerals 
recovered in small scale laboratory tests may not be duplicated in large scale tests under on-site production conditions.
- 87 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
The  Combined  Company  is  expected  to  continue  to  require  substantial  external  financing  to  pay  its  operating  and 
general and administrative expenses, continue the advancement of the Velardeña Property expansion and the El Quevar 
Project and fund its other exploration activities.
The  Combined  Company  will  be  required  to  continue  to  raise  substantial  funds  from  external  sources  in  order  to  pay 
operating and general and administrative expenses, advance the Velardeña Property expansion and the El Quevar Project, 
maintain other exploration properties and continue exploration activities, as it is not expected that cash generated by the 
Velardeña  mining  operations  will  be  sufficient  to  fund  these  activities.    If  the  Velardeña  Property  expansion  or  the  El 
Quevar Project proceeds to development and construction, it is anticipated that the Combined Company would need to raise 
additional  capital  during  2011.    The  size  and  capital  cost  for  the  Velardeña  Property  expansion  or  a  possible  mine  and 
processing  facilities  at  the  El  Quevar  Project  have  not  been  determined  and  would  depend,  among  other  things,  on  the 
results of ongoing efforts to further define the Yaxtché deposit.  There is no credit agreement in place that would finance 
development of either the Velardeña Property expansion or the El Quevar Project, and securing credit for these projects 
may be difficult  given Golden’s limited history and the continuing  volatility in global credit markets.   Access to public 
financing  has  been  negatively  impacted  by  the  volatility  in  the  credit  markets,  which  may  impact  the  ability  of  the 
Combined Company to obtain equity or debt financing in the future and, if obtained, to do so on favourable terms.  There 
can be no assurance that the Combined Company will be able to obtain the necessary financing for the Velardeña Property 
expansion or the El Quevar Project on favourable terms or at all. Failure to obtain sufficient financing may also result in the 
delay or indefinite postponement of exploration activities at other properties.
The Combined Company will be subject to a broad range of Environmental Laws and associated costs and liabilities.
ECU and Golden are subject to a broad range of Environmental Laws and regulations in each jurisdiction in which they 
operate.  These  Laws  and  regulations,  as  interpreted  by  relevant  agencies  and  the  courts,  impose  increasingly  stringent 
environmental  protection  standards  regarding,  among  other  things,  air  emissions,  wastewater  storage,  treatment  and 
discharges,  the  use  and  handling  of  hazardous  or  toxic  materials,  waste  disposal  practices  and  the  remediation  of 
environmental  contamination.  The  costs  of  complying  with  these  Laws  and  regulations,  including  participation  in 
assessments and remediation  of sites, could be significant. In addition, these standards  can create the risk of substantial 
environmental liabilities, including liabilities associated with divested assets and past activities.
The existence of secured indebtedness at ECU may limit the flexibility of the Combined Company to obtain additional 
financing and pursue certain opportunities.
Prior  to  the  Arrangement,  Golden  had  no  indebtedness.  At  June  30,  2011,  ECU  had  approximately  US$17.0  million  of 
outstanding  term  loan  indebtedness,  bearing  interest  at  an  effective  rate  of  12.8%  and  requiring  30  monthly  principal 
repayments  of  $553,951,  commencing  July  31,  2011  through  maturity  on  December  31,  2013. The  presence  of  secured 
indebtedness,  particularly  in  a  company  with  limited  revenues,  has  important  consequences  to  the  Combined  Company, 
including  (i)  making  it  more  difficult  to  obtain  additional  financing,  (ii)  subjecting  it  to  the  risk  that  its  assets  may  be 
foreclosed  upon  if  it  is  unable  to  make  required  principal  and  interest  payments,  (iii)  reducing  cash  flows  available  for
development of properties, and (iv) making the Combined Company more vulnerable than competitors without debt to a 
downturn in business, the economy or commodity prices.  The Combined Company’s ability to service its debt will depend 
on its operating performance, which is affected by prevailing economic conditions that are outside of its control.  If it is 
unable to support debt service from revenues from ECU’s mining operations, the Combined Company may be forced to 
divert resources from the development of its other properties, which may have material adverse effects on its growth and 
future prospects.
The long-term cash flow and profitability of the Combined Company will be affected by changes in the prices of silver 
and other metals.
The ability of the Combined Company to establish reserves and develop its exploration properties, and its profitability and 
long-term  viability,  depend,  in  large  part,  on  the  market  prices  of  silver,  zinc,  lead,  gold,  copper  and  other  metals.  The 
market prices for these metals are volatile and are affected by numerous factors beyond the Combined Company’s control, 
including:

Future weakness in the global economy could increase volatility in metals prices or depress metals prices, which could in 
turn  reduce  the  cash  flow  generated  by  the  Velardeña  District  Properties,  or  make  it  uneconomical  for  the  Combined 
Company to continue its mining or exploration activities. Volatility or sustained price declines may also adversely affect 
the ability of the Combined Company to build its business.
If  the Combined  Company  is  unable  to  obtain  all  of  its  required  governmental  permits  or  obtain  property  rights  on 
favourable terms or at all, its operations could be negatively impacted.
Future  operations  of  the  Combined  Company,  including  the  new  tailings  facility  at  and  potential  expansion  of  the
Velardeña District Properties, the advancement of the El Quevar Project, and other exploration and potential development 
activities, will require additional permits from various governmental authorities.  Operations of the Combined Company are 
and  will  continue  to  be  governed  by  Laws  and  regulations  governing  prospecting,  development,  mining,  production, 
exports, taxes, labour standards, occupational health, waste disposal, toxic substances, land use, environmental protection, 
mine safety, mining royalties and other matters.  The Combined Company may also be required to obtain certain property 
rights  to  access  or  use  its  properties.  Obtaining  or  renewing  licenses  and  permits,  and  acquiring  property  rights,  can  be 
complex and time-consuming processes.  There can be no assurance that the Combined Company will be able to acquire all 
required licenses, permits or property rights on reasonable terms or in a timely manner, or at all, and that such terms will 
not be adversely changed, that required extensions will be granted, or that the issuance of such licenses, permits or property 
rights will not be challenged by third parties. Delays in obtaining or a failure to obtain any licenses, permits or property 
rights or any required extensions; challenges to the issuance of licenses, permits or property rights, whether successful or 
unsuccessful;  changes  to  the  terms  of  licenses,  permits  or  property  rights;  or  a  failure  to  comply  with  the  terms  of  any 
licenses, permits or property  rights that  have been obtained, could have a material adverse effect on the business of the 
Combined Company by delaying or preventing continued operations or by or making continued operations economically 
unfeasible.
The Combined Company may not meet key production or cost estimates.
The  level  of  production  and  capital  and  operating  costs  estimates  relating  to  development  projects,  which  are  used  in 
establishing mineral reserve and mineral resource estimates for obtaining financing and other purposes, are based on certain 
assumptions  and  are  inherently  subject  to  significant  uncertainty.    Actual  results  for  the  Combined  Company’s  projects 
could  differ  from  current  estimates  and  assumptions,  and  these  differences  may  be  material.    In  addition,  development 
activities or processing operations  may identify  new or unexpected conditions  which could reduce production below, or 
increase capital or operating costs above, current estimates. If actual results are less favourable than currently estimated, the 
results of operations, profitability and financial results of the Combined Company could be materially adversely affected.
RIGHTS OF DISSENTING SHAREHOLDERS
ECU  Shareholders  who  wish  to  dissent  should  take  note  that  strict  compliance  with  the  Dissent  Procedures  is 
required.
The  following  description  of  the  Dissent  Procedures  is  not  a  comprehensive  statement  of  the  procedures  to  be 
followed by a Dissenting Shareholder and is qualified entirely by reference to the full text of the Interim Order and 
the Plan of Arrangement. The Interim Order, which is attached to this Circular as Appendix E, expressly provides 
Registered Shareholders with the Dissent Rights in respect of the Arrangement on substantially the same terms and 
conditions as set out in Chapter XIV—Right to Demand Repurchase of Shares (sections 372 to 397) of the QBCA, 
the  text  of  which  is  reproduced  in  Appendix  G  to  this  Circular,  with  modifications  to  the  provisions  of  such 
sections 372 to 397 in accordance with the Interim Order and Article 5 of the Plan of Arrangement.
- 89 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Dissent Rights
Any  Registered  Shareholder  as  of  the  Record  Date  who  exercises  Dissent  Rights  with  respect  to  the  Arrangement  in 
compliance  with  Chapter  XIV  of  the  QBCA  (as  modified  by  the  Interim  Order  and  the  Plan  of  Arrangement)  will  be 
entitled, in the event that the Arrangement becomes effective, to be paid by Golden the fair value of the ECU Shares held 
by  that  Dissenting  Shareholder  determined  as  of  the  close  of  the  offices  of  ECU  on  the  day  before  the  Arrangement 
Resolution  is  approved  and  adopted  by  the  ECU  Securityholders  at  the  Meeting.  The  Interim  Order  and  the  Plan  of 
Arrangement provide that the fair value payable by Golden to a Dissenting Shareholder, may, at the option of Golden, be 
paid by way of issuance of shares of Golden Stock.
No ECU Optionholder, ECU Warrantholder or ECU Convertible Noteholder shall be entitled to Dissent Rights in respect of 
such holder’s ECU Options, ECU Warrants or ECU Convertible Notes.
Registered  Shareholders  who  renounce,  or  are  deemed  to  renounce,  their  right  to  demand  the  repurchase  of  their  ECU 
Shares pursuant to the Dissent Rights shall be deemed to have participated in the Arrangement, as of the Effective Time, 
and shall be entitled to receive the Consideration to which ECU Shareholders who have not exercised Dissent Rights are 
entitled under the Plan of Arrangement.  For greater certainty, in addition to any other restrictions in Chapter XIV of the 
QBCA, no ECU Shareholder who has failed to exercise all the voting rights carried by the ECU Shares held by such ECU 
Shareholder  against  the  Arrangement  Resolution  shall  be  entitled  to  exercise  Dissent  Rights  with  respect  to  the 
Arrangement.
Without  limiting  the  generality  of  the  other  provisions  in  this  Circular  describing  the  Dissent  Rights  and  the  exercise 
thereof, a Dissenting  Shareholder  will, at the Effective Time, and  notwithstanding any provision of  Chapter XIV of the 
QBCA,  be  deemed  to  have  directly  transferred  and  assigned  each  ECU  Share  held  by  such  Dissenting  Shareholder  to 
Golden (free and clear of all Liens) and such Dissenting Shareholder shall cease to be the holder of such ECU Shares and to 
have any rights as a holder or former holder of such ECU Shares other than the right to be paid the fair value for such ECU 
Shares by Golden in accordance with its Dissent Rights in accordance with the provisions of the QBCA as modified by the 
Interim Order and the Plan of Arrangement. In no case shall Golden, ECU or any other person be required to recognize any 
holder of ECU Shares who exercises Dissent Rights as a holder of ECU Shares after the Effective Time.
If the Arrangement is not implemented for any reason, Dissenting Shareholders will not be entitled to be paid the fair value 
for their ECU Shares under the Dissent Rights, and their ECU Shares will not be deemed to be transferred to Golden.
Dissent Procedures
Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights
A Registered Shareholder as of the Record Date who wishes to exercise Dissent Rights must deliver a written notice of 
intent to exercise the right to demand the repurchase of ECU Shares contemplated by Section 376 of the QBCA (“Notice of 
Exercise of Dissent Rights”) which must be received by ECU not later than 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on August 26, 2011, 
or two Business Days prior to the reconvening of any adjournment or postponement of the Meeting.  ECU’s address for 
such purpose is its registered office at 1116 ave. Granada, Rouyn-Noranda, Québec J9Y 1G9.  A Dissenting Shareholder 
must dissent  with respect to  all ECU Shares  in  which the holder holds a beneficial  interest.  The Notice of Exercise of 
Dissent Rights must set out:
(i)
(j)
the full number of ECU Shares held by the Registered Shareholder; and
if the Registered Shareholder delivering the Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights is acting on the instruction of a 
Beneficial Shareholder, the identity of the Beneficial Shareholder who intends to demand a repurchase of its ECU 
Shares and the number of such ECU Shares.
The giving of a Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights does not deprive a Dissenting Shareholder of the right to vote the ECU 
Shares for which such notice was given. A vote either in person or by proxy against the Arrangement Resolution does not 
constitute a Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights. However, should any ECU Shares of a Dissenting Shareholder not be 
voted against the Arrangement Resolution, or should a Dissenting Shareholder abstain from voting any its ECU Shares in
- 90 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
respect of the Arrangement Resolution, the Dissent Rights of such Dissenting Shareholder will be terminated with respect 
to all of its ECU Shares.
Terms of Repurchase of Dissenting Shareholders’ ECU Shares
Promptly  after  the  Effective  Time,  Golden  is  required  to  give  notice  (the  “Repurchase  Notice”)  to  each  Dissenting 
Shareholder, which notice shall mention (i) the repurchase price being offered for the ECU Shares held by all Dissenting 
Shareholders and an explanation of how such price was determined and (ii) whether Golden intends to pay such repurchase 
price by way of issuance of shares of Golden Stock or by cash payment or by some combination of the two. Within 30 days 
after  receiving  the  Repurchase  Notice,  each  Dissenting  Shareholder  is  required,  if  the  Dissenting  Shareholder  wishes  to 
proceed with exercising its Dissent Rights, to deliver to Golden a written statement:
(a)
(b)
confirming that the Dissenting Shareholder wishes to exercise its Dissent Rights and have all of its ECU Shares 
repurchased  at  the  repurchase  price  indicated  in  the  Repurchase  Notice  (in  such  case,  a  “Notice  of 
Confirmation”); or
that the Dissenting Shareholder contests the repurchase price indicated in the Repurchase Notice and demands an 
increase in the repurchase price offered (in such case, a “Notice of Contestation”).
Additionally, if it has not been done previously, all certificate(s) representing the ECU Shares pursuant to which the Dissent 
Rights were exercised, together with the completed and executed applicable Letter of Transmittal, should be delivered with 
the Notice of Confirmation or the Notice of Contestation.
A Dissenting Shareholder who fails to send Golden, within the required timeframe, a Notice of Confirmation or a Notice of 
Contestation,  shall  be  deemed  to  have  renounced  its  Dissent  Rights  and  will  be  deemed  to  have  participated  in  the 
Arrangement on the same basis as ECU Shareholders who did not exercise Dissent Rights.
Upon  receiving  a  Notice  of  Confirmation  within  the  required  timeframe,  Golden  shall  pay  the  Dissenting  Shareholder, 
within 10 days of receiving the confirmation, the repurchase price indicated in the Repurchase Notice for all of its ECU 
Shares.
Upon receiving a Notice of Contestation within the required timeframe, Golden may propose an increased repurchase price 
within  30  days  of  receiving  the  contestation,  which  increased  repurchase  price  must  be  the  same  for  all  Dissenting 
Shareholders who duly submitted a Notice of Contestation.  If (a) Golden does not follow up on a Dissenting Shareholder’s
contestation within 30 days after receiving its Notice of Contestation or (b) the Dissenting Shareholder contests the increase 
in the repurchase price offered by Golden, such Dissenting Shareholder may ask the Court to determine the increase in the 
repurchase price.  However, any such application to the Court must be made within 90 days after receiving the Repurchase 
Notice. As soon as any such application is filed with the Court by any Dissenting Shareholder, Golden must notify this fact 
(a “Notice of Application”) to all the other Dissenting Shareholders who are still contesting the repurchase price, or the 
increase in the repurchase price, offered by Golden.
All Dissenting Shareholders who received the Notice of Application are bound by the judgment of the Court hearing the 
application as to the fair value of the ECU Shares (which Court may entrust the appraisal of the fair value to an expert). 
Within 10 days after the Court judgement, Golden must pay the repurchase price determined by the Court to all Dissenting 
Shareholders  who  received  the  Notice  of  Application,  and  pay  the  increase  in  the  repurchase  price  to  all  Dissenting 
Shareholders who submitted a Notice of Contestation but did not contest the increase in the repurchase price offered by 
Golden.  However, if Golden is unable to pay the full increase in the repurchase price because there are reasonable grounds 
for believing that it is or would be unable to pay its liabilities as they become due,  Golden would only be required to pay 
the maximum amount it may legally pay the relevant Dissenting Shareholder. In such a case, such Dissenting Shareholders 
remain creditors of Golden for the unpaid balance of the repurchase price and are entitled to be paid as soon as Golden is 
legally able to do so or, in the event of the liquidation of Golden, are entitled to be collocated after the other creditors but by 
preference over the other shareholders of Golden.

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Beneficial Shareholders
Persons who are Beneficial Shareholders of ECU Shares registered in the name of an Intermediary, custodian, nominee or 
in some other name, who wish to exercise Dissent Rights should be aware that only the Registered Shareholder as of the 
Record  Date  is  entitled  to  exercise  Dissent  Rights.    A  Beneficial  Shareholder  may  give  instructions  to  the  Registered 
Shareholder  in  whose  name  the  ECU  Shares  over  which  it  has  a  beneficial  interest  are  registered  as  to  the  exercise  of 
Dissent Rights attaching to its ECU Shares.  The Registered Shareholder must inform ECU of the identity of the Beneficial 
Shareholder who intends to exercise Dissent Rights, and of the number of ECU Shares over which the Dissent Rights are 
being exercised, within the prescribed period for giving a Notice of Exercise of Dissent Rights (see “Rights of Dissenting 
Shareholders  –  Dissent  Procedures”  above).    A  Registered  Shareholder  who  demands  the  repurchase  of  ECU  Shares 
pursuant to Dissent Rights in accordance with the instructions of a Beneficial Shareholder may demand the repurchase of 
part of the ECU Shares to which such Dissent Rights are attached.
A Beneficial Shareholder who wishes to exercise Dissent Rights should communicate with the Intermediary, custodian or 
nominee in whose name the ECU Shares over which it has a beneficial interest are registered as of the Record Date as to the 
procedure for instructing such Registered Shareholder to exercise the Dissent Rights on the Beneficial Shareholder’s behalf.
Note that sections 393 to 397 of the QBCA, the text of which is included in Appendix G to this Circular, set forth special 
provisions which must be followed with respect to the exercise of Dissent Rights by Beneficial Shareholders.
The discussion above is only a summary of the Dissent Procedures  which are technical procedures and are complex. A 
Registered Shareholder who intends to exercise Dissent Rights should carefully consider and comply with the provisions of 
Chapter XIV of the QBCA, as modified by the Interim Order and the Plan of Arrangement. It is suggested that any ECU 
Shareholder wishing to avail itself of Dissent Rights seek its own legal advice as failure to comply strictly with the 
applicable provisions of the QBCA, the Interim Order and the Plan of Arrangement may prejudice the availability 
of Dissent Rights. Dissenting Shareholders should note that the exercise of Dissent Rights can be a complex, time 
consuming and expensive process.
CERTAIN CANADIAN FEDERAL INCOME TAX CONSIDERATIONS
The  following  summary  fairly  describes,  as  of  the  date  of  this  Circular,  the  principal  Canadian  federal  income  tax 
considerations under the Tax Act relating to the Arrangement generally applicable to an ECU Securityholder who, at all 
relevant times, for the purposes of the Tax Act: (i) deals at arm’s length with ECU and Golden; (ii) is not affiliated with 
ECU or Golden; and (iii) holds ECU Securities, and will hold all Golden Securities acquired on the Arrangement, as capital 
property (each such securityholder in this section, a “Holder”). A Holder’s ECU Securities and Golden Securities generally 
will be considered to be capital property of the Holder unless the Holder holds such securities in the course of carrying on a 
business  of  buying  and  selling  securities  or  acquired  such  securities  in  a  transaction  considered  to  be  an  adventure  or 
concern in the nature of trade. Certain Holders who are residents of Canada for the purposes of the Tax Act and whose ECU 
Shares might not otherwise be capital property may, in certain circumstances, be entitled to make an irrevocable election 
under subsection 39(4) of the Tax Act to have the ECU Shares and every other “Canadian security” (as defined in the Tax 
Act) owned by such Holder in the taxation year in which the election is made and in all subsequent taxation years deemed 
to be capital property. Such Holders should consult their own tax advisors regarding whether an election under subsection 
39(4) is available and advisable in their particular circumstances.
This summary is based upon the current provisions of the Tax Act, the regulations thereunder (the “Tax Regulations”), and 
counsel  to  ECU’s  understanding  of  the  current  published  administrative  practices  and  policies  of  the  Canada  Revenue 
Agency  (the  “CRA”).  This  summary  also  takes  into  account  all  specific  proposals  to  amend  the  Tax  Act  and  Tax 
Regulations (the “Proposed Amendments”) announced by or on behalf of the Minister of Finance (Canada) prior to the 
date hereof, and assumes that all Proposed Amendments will be enacted in their present form. However, there can be no 
assurance  that  the  Proposed  Amendments  will  be  enacted  in  the  form  proposed,  or  at  all.  Except  for  the  Proposed 
Amendments,  this  summary  does  not  take  into  account  or  anticipate  any  changes  in  Law,  whether  by  legislative, 
governmental  or  judicial  action  or  decision,  nor  does  it  take  into  account  provincial,  territorial  or  foreign  income  tax 
considerations, which may differ from the Canadian federal income tax considerations discussed below.
- 92 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
This summary is not applicable to a Holder that is a “financial institution” as defined in the Tax Act for the purposes of the 
“mark-to-market  property”  rules  or  a  “specified  financial  institution”  as  defined  in  the  Tax  Act,  nor  does  it  apply  to  a 
Holder,  an  interest  in  which  is  a  “tax  shelter  investment”  as  defined  in  the  Tax  Act,  or  to  a  Holder  that  has  made  a 
functional currency reporting election for purposes of the Tax Act. In addition, this summary does not address all issues 
relevant  to  Holders  who  acquired  their  ECU  Shares  on  the  exercise  of  an  employee  stock  option.  Such  Holders  should 
consult their own tax advisors.
In  general,  amounts  relevant  to  the  computation  of  income  under  the  Tax  Act  are  reported  in  Canadian  dollars.    Any 
amount that is expressed or denominated in a currency other than Canadian dollars, including dividends, adjusted cost base 
and proceeds of disposition, must be converted into Canadian dollars, generally based on the exchange rate quoted by the 
Bank of Canada at noon on the date each such amount arises.
This  summary  is  of  a  general  nature  only  and  is  not  exhaustive  of  all  possible  Canadian  federal  income  tax 
considerations. This summary is not, and should not be construed as, legal, business or tax advice to any particular 
Holder and no representations with respect to the tax consequences to any particular Holder are made. Accordingly, 
all Holders should consult their own tax advisors regarding the Canadian federal income tax consequences of the 
Arrangement applicable to their particular circumstances.
Holders Resident in Canada
This portion of the summary only applies to a Holder who, at all relevant times, is or is deemed to be a Canadian Resident 
(a “Resident Holder”).
Exchange of ECU Shares under the Arrangement
A Resident Holder whose ECU Shares are exchanged for Golden Stock and cash under the Arrangement will be considered 
to  have  disposed  of  the  ECU  Shares  for  proceeds  of  disposition  equal  to  the  aggregate  of  the  fair  market  value  at  the 
Effective Time of the Golden Stock received on the exchange and the cash consideration received on the exchange. As a 
result,  the  Resident  Holder  will,  in  general,  realize  a  capital  gain  (or  a  capital  loss)  to  the  extent  that  such  proceeds  of 
disposition  exceed  (or  are  less  than)  the  aggregate  of  the  Resident  Holder’s  adjusted  cost  base  of  the  ECU  Shares 
immediately  before  the  exchange  and  any  reasonable  costs  of  disposition.  See  “Certain  Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax 
Considerations – Holders Resident in Canada –-Taxation of Capital Gains and Capital Losses” below.
The cost to the Resident Holder of the Golden Stock acquired on the exchange will equal the fair market value of such 
Golden Stock at the Effective Time and will, for the purpose of determining the Resident Holder’s adjusted cost base of 
such Golden Stock, be averaged with the adjusted cost base to the Resident Holder of any other Golden Stock held at the 
Effective Time as capital property.
Exchange of ECU Options by Resident Employee ECU Optionholders
Resident Holders of ECU Options who: (i) acquired their ECU Options pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan by virtue of 
being an employee, officer or director of ECU; and (ii) exchange their ECU Options for Golden Replacement Options and 
no other consideration at the Effective Time, should not recognize any taxable income or loss as a result of such exchange 
pursuant to the Arrangement.
To the extent the above-described conditions are satisfied, a Golden Replacement Option will be deemed to be the same 
option and a continuation of the ECU Option. Further, the provisions of the Tax Act providing for the deduction of one-half 
of any resulting employee benefit should, if otherwise applicable, continue to apply if at the time of the exchange of the 
ECU Option for a Golden Replacement Option the exercise price was not less than the fair market value of an ECU Share 
at the time of grant of the ECU Option and all other applicable conditions specified in the Tax Act are satisfied.
Exchange of ECU Options by Resident Non-Employee ECU Optionholders
This summary does not address other Resident Holders of ECU Options, including consultants and independent contractors. 
Resident Holders of ECU Options who received their ECU Options otherwise than in respect of being an employee, officer

if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
or director of ECU should obtain their own tax advice regarding the tax consequences to them of exchanging their ECU 
Options for Golden Replacement Options pursuant to the Arrangement.
Exchange of ECU Warrants by Resident ECU Warrantholders
A Resident Holder who transfers its Warrants to Golden in exchange for Golden Replacement Warrants pursuant to the 
Arrangement will be considered to have disposed of such ECU Warrants for proceeds of disposition equal to the fair market 
value at the Effective Time of such Golden Replacement Warrants. Such Resident Holder will, in general, realize a capital 
gain  (or  capital  loss)  to  the  extent  the  proceeds  of  disposition  of  such  ECU  Warrants,  net  of  any  reasonable  costs  of 
disposition, exceed (or are less than) the adjusted cost base to such Resident Holder of such ECU Warrants immediately 
prior to the transfer. See “Certain Canadian Federal Income Tax Considerations – Holders Resident in Canada –-Taxation 
of  Capital  Gains  and  Capital  Losses”  below.  The  cost  to  such  Resident  Holder  of  the  Golden  Replacement  Warrants 
acquired  on  such  transfer  will  be  equal  to  the  fair  market  value  of  such  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  at  the  Effective 
Time.
Taxation of Capital Gains and Capital Losses
Generally, a Resident Holder will be required to include in computing the holder’s income for a taxation year one-half of 
the  amount  of  any  capital  gain  (a  “taxable  capital  gain”)  realized  by  the  holder  in  that  year.  A  Resident  Holder  will 
generally be entitled to deduct one-half of the amount of any capital loss (an “allowable capital loss”) realized in a taxation 
year from taxable capital gains realized by the holder in that year. Allowable capital losses in excess of taxable capital gains 
for a taxation year may be carried back to any of the three preceding taxation years or carried forward to any subsequent 
taxation year and deducted against net taxable capital gains realized in such years, subject to the detailed rules contained in 
the Tax Act.
A capital loss realized on the disposition of an ECU Share by a Resident Holder that is a corporation may, to the extent and 
under the circumstances specified by the Tax Act, be reduced by the amount of dividends received or deemed to have been 
received by the corporation on such shares (or on a share for which such share is substituted or exchanged). Similar rules 
may apply where shares are owned by a partnership or trust of which a corporation, trust or partnership is a member or 
beneficiary. Resident Holders to whom these rules may be relevant should consult their own advisors.
A Resident Holder that is a “Canadian-controlled private corporation” (as defined in the Tax Act) may be required to pay 
an additional 62/3% refundable tax on certain investment income, which includes taxable capital gains.
Dividends on Golden Stock
Dividends  received  or  deemed  to  be  received  by  a  Resident  Holder  on  Golden  Stock  must  be  included  in  the  Resident 
Holder’s income for purposes of the Tax Act.
Such dividends received by a Resident Holder who is an individual will not be subject to the gross-up and dividend tax 
credit rules in the Tax Act.
Such dividends received by a Resident Holder that is a corporation generally will not entitle such corporate holder to deduct 
the amount of such dividends in computing its taxable income.
Such dividends received by a Resident Holder that is a  “Canadian-controlled private corporation”  may be subject to  an 
additional refundable tax of 62/3%.
Generally,  a  Resident  Holder  who  receives  a  dividend  in  respect  of  its  ownership  of  Golden  Stock  will  be  required  to 
include the amount of such dividend in income as discussed herein above and will be subject to a United States withholding 
tax of 15% as a result of application of the Canada-U.S. Treaty. However, there may be circumstances where a corporation 
resident  in  Canada  that  is  controlled  by  non-resident  persons  will  not  benefit  from  the Canada-U.S.  Treaty and  will  be 
subject to a withholding tax of 30%.
- 94 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
A person  may claim the  withholding tax as a  tax credit against Canadian  income tax payable in respect of certain U.S. 
investment income in accordance with detailed rules pertaining to the calculation of such tax credit. Any withholding tax 
not deductible against Canadian income tax may be deducted in computing the person’s income subject to the detailed rules 
in the Tax Act.
Disposition of Golden Stock
A Resident Holder that disposes or is deemed to dispose of Golden Stock in a taxation year will realize a capital gain (or a 
capital loss) equal to the amount by which the proceeds of disposition of the Golden Stock exceed (or are exceeded by) the 
aggregate  of  the  Resident  Holder’s  adjusted  cost  base  of  such  Golden  Stock,  determined  immediately  before  the 
disposition, and any reasonable costs of disposition. The Resident Holder will be required to include any resulting taxable 
capital  gain  in  income,  or  be  entitled  to  deduct  any  resulting  allowable  capital  loss,  in  accordance  with  the  usual  rules 
applicable  to  capital  gains  and  capital  losses.  See  “Certain  Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  –  Holders 
Resident in Canada –-Taxation of Capital Gains and Capital Losses”.
Alternative Minimum Tax
A capital gain realized, or a dividend received, if any, by a Resident Holder who is an individual (including certain trusts) 
may give rise to liability for alternative minimum tax under the Tax Act.
Eligibility for Investment of Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants
Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants will be a qualified investment under the Tax Act for a trust governed by a 
registered  retirement  savings  plan,  registered  retirement  income  fund,  deferred  profit  sharing  plan,  registered  education 
savings plan, registered disability savings plan or a tax-free savings account (a “TFSA”) (each a “Deferred Plan”), at any 
particular time, provided that, at that time, (i) in the case of Golden Stock, the Golden Stock is listed on a “designated stock 
exchange”  (as  defined  in  the  Tax  Act),  which  currently  includes  the  TSX;  (ii)  in  the  case  of  the  Golden  Replacement 
Warrants, the Golden Replacement Warrant is listed on a designated stock exchange, or each person who is an annuitant, a 
beneficiary,  an  employer  or  a  subscriber  under,  or  a  holder  of,  the  applicable  Deferred  Plan  deals  at  arm’s  length  with 
Golden within the meaning of the Tax Act and the stock that may be acquired upon exercise of the Golden Replacement 
Warrant is a qualified investment for such Deferred Plan as described above.
Notwithstanding that Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants may be qualified investments for a TFSA, a holder of 
a TFSA will be subject to a penalty tax with respect to Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants held in the TFSA if 
such stock or warrant is a “prohibited investment” for the TFSA (within the meaning of the Tax Act). Golden Stock or 
Golden Replacement Warrants will not be a prohibited investment for a TFSA provided the holder of the TFSA deals at 
arm’s length with Golden for purposes of the Tax Act and does not have a “significant interest” (within the meaning of the 
Tax Act) in Golden or in any corporation, partnership or trust with which Golden does not deal at arm’s length for purposes 
of the Tax Act.
The 2011 federal budget proposes to extend the concept of “prohibited investment” to registered retirement savings 
plans and registered retirement income funds. Resident Holders should consult their tax advisors in this regard.
Dissenting Resident Holders
A  Resident  Holder  who  validly  exercises  Dissent  Rights  and  is  a  Dissenting  Shareholder  (a  “Resident  Dissenter”)  and 
consequently is paid the fair value of the Resident Dissenter’s ECU Shares by Golden in accordance with the Arrangement 
will realize a capital gain (or a capital loss) equal to the amount by which the payment (other than interest) exceeds (or is 
exceeded by) the aggregate of the Resident Holder’s adjusted cost base of the ECU Shares determined immediately before 
the Effective Time and any reasonable costs of disposition. The Resident Dissenter will be required to include any resulting 
taxable capital gain in income, or be entitled to deduct any resulting allowable capital loss, in accordance with the usual 
rules applicable to capital gains and losses. See “Certain Canadian Federal Income Tax Considerations – Holders Resident 
in Canada –-Taxation of Capital Gains and Capital Losses”.
A Resident Dissenter must include in computing its income any interest awarded to it by a court.

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Foreign Property Information Reporting
In  general,  a  “specified  Canadian  entity”,  as  defined  in  the  Tax  Act,  whose  total  cost  amount  of  “specified  foreign 
property”, as defined in the Tax Act, at any time in the taxation year or fiscal period exceeds Cdn$100,000, is required to 
file an information return for the year or period disclosing prescribed information, including the cost amount, any dividends 
received in the year, and any gains or losses realized in the year, in respect of such property.  Subject to certain exceptions, 
a taxpayer resident in Canada in the year will be a specified Canadian entity.  Specified foreign property is defined in the 
Tax Act to include shares of the capital stock of a non-resident corporation and property that, under the terms or conditions 
thereof or any agreement related thereto, is convertible into, exchangeable for or confers a right to acquire, property that is a 
share of the capital of a non-resident corporation.
Golden Stock is, and Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants will be, specified foreign property. 
As a result, if the aggregate cost amount of any specified foreign property held by a Resident Holder that is a specified 
Canadian entity at any time in a taxation year or fiscal period exceeds Cdn$100,000, the Resident Holder will be required to 
file an information return for the year as described hereinabove. Resident Holders are encouraged to consult their own 
tax advisors as to whether they must file an information return under these rules.
Holders not Resident in Canada
This portion of the summary applies to a Holder who, at all relevant times, for the purposes of the Tax Act, is not, and is 
not  deemed  to  be,  a  Canadian  Resident  and  does  not  use  or  hold,  and  is  not  deemed  to  use  or  hold,  ECU 
Securities or Golden Securities in connection with carrying on a business in Canada (a “Non-Resident Holder”). Special 
rules, which are not discussed in this summary, may apply to a Holder that is an insurer carrying on business in Canada and 
elsewhere.
Exchange of ECU Shares under the Arrangement and Subsequent Disposition of Golden Stock
A Non-Resident Holder whose ECU Shares are exchanged for Golden Stock and cash under the Arrangement will not be 
subject  to  tax  under  the  Tax  Act  on  any  capital  gain  realized  on  such  exchange  unless  the  ECU  Shares  are  “taxable 
Canadian property” (as defined in the Tax Act) to the Non-Resident Holder at the Effective Time and the ECU Shares are 
not “treaty-protected property” (as defined in the Tax Act) of the Non-Resident Holder at the time of the exchange.
Based upon the current provisions of the Tax Act, generally, an ECU Share will not be taxable Canadian property to a Non-
Resident Holder at a particular time provided that such share is listed on a “designated stock exchange” (as defined in the 
Tax Act), which includes the TSX, unless at any time during the 60 month period immediately preceding the disposition (i) 
the Non-Resident Holder, persons with whom the Non-Resident Holder did not deal at arm’s length, or the Non-Resident 
Holder together with all such persons, owned 25% or more of the issued shares of any class or series of shares of the capital 
stock of ECU and (ii) more than 50% of the fair market value of the particular share was derived directly or indirectly from 
one or any combination of real or immovable property situated in Canada, Canadian resource properties (as defined in the 
Tax Act), timber resource properties (all within the meaning of the Tax Act), and/or options in respect of, or interests in, or 
for civil law rights in, any of the foregoing properties (whether or not such property exists). Notwithstanding the foregoing, 
an ECU Share may also be deemed to be taxable Canadian property to a Non-Resident Holder in certain circumstances 
specified in the Tax Act.
Even if an ECU Share is taxable Canadian property to a Non-Resident Holder, such share will be treaty protected property 
of  the  Non-Resident  Holder  at  the  time  of  disposition  (which  time  includes  an  exchange  of  an  ECU  Share  under  the 
Arrangement)  for  purposes  of  the  Tax  Act  if  the  capital  gain  from  the  disposition  of  that  share  would,  because  of  an 
applicable income tax convention  to  which  Canada is a  signatory, be exempt  from tax under the Tax  Act. Many of the 
income tax treaties to  which  Canada is a  signatory, including  the  Canada-U.S. Treaty,  provide that Canada reserves the 
right to tax (i.e., does not exempt from Canadian tax) gains on the sale of real property situated in Canada, which for these 
purposes  may  include  (and  under  the  Canada-U.S.  Treaty,  does  include)  a  share  of  the  capital  stock  of  a  corporation 
resident  in  Canada,  the  value  of  whose  shares  is  derived  principally  from  real  property  or  resource  property  situated  in 
Canada. Non-Resident Holders should consult their own tax advisors in this regard.
