In the event an ECU Share is taxable Canadian property to a Non-Resident Holder at the time of disposition and is not 
treaty-protected property of the Non-Resident Holder at that time, the tax consequences described above under “Certain 
Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  – Holders  Resident  in  Canada  –  Exchange  of  ECU  Shares  under  the 
Arrangement”  and  “Certain  Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  –  Holders  Resident  in  Canada  –  Taxation  of 
Capital Gains and Capital Losses” will generally apply. Non-Resident Holders should consult their own tax advisors 
with respect to the Canadian tax consequences of disposing of such shares.
Disposition of Golden Stock
Any capital gain realized by a Non-Resident Holder on a disposition or deemed disposition of Golden Stock acquired under 
the Arrangement will not be subject to tax under the Tax Act unless the Golden Stock is taxable Canadian property to the 
Non-Resident Holder at the time of the disposition and the shares are not treaty-protected property of the Non-Resident 
Holder at the time of disposition.
Exchange of ECU Options by Non-Resident Employee ECU Optionholders
Non-Resident Holders of ECU Options who: (i) acquired their ECU Options pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan by 
virtue of employment with ECU in Canada; and (ii) exchange their ECU Options for Golden Replacement Options and no 
other consideration at the Effective Time, should not recognize any taxable income or loss as a result of such exchange 
pursuant to the Arrangement.
To the extent the above-described conditions are satisfied, a Golden Replacement Option will be deemed to be the same 
option and a continuation of the ECU Option. Further, the provisions of the Tax Act providing for the deduction of one-half 
of any resulting employee benefit should, if otherwise applicable, continue to apply if at the time of the exchange of the 
ECU Option for a Golden Replacement Option the exercise price was not less than the fair market value of an ECU Share 
at the time of grant of the ECU Option and all other applicable conditions specified in the Tax Act are satisfied.
Exchange of ECU Options by Non-Resident Non-Employee ECU Optionholders
This  summary  does  not  address  other  Non-Resident  Holders  of  ECU  Options,  including  consultants  and  independent 
contractors. Non-Resident Holders of ECU Options who received their ECU Options otherwise than in respect of being an 
employee,  officer  or  director  of  ECU  should  obtain  their  own  tax  advice  regarding  the  tax  consequences  to  them  of 
exchanging their ECU Options for Golden Replacement Options.
Exchange of ECU Warrants by Non-Resident ECU Warrantholder
A  Non-Resident  Holder  who  transfers  its  ECU  Warrants  to  Golden  for  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  pursuant  to  the 
Arrangement will not generally be subject to income tax under the Tax Act in respect of any capital gain realized by such 
holder on such transfer at the Effective Time unless such ECU Warrants are taxable Canadian property (as discussed above 
under “Certain Canadian Federal Income Tax Considerations – Holders not Resident in Canada – Exchange of ECU Shares 
under the Arrangement and Subsequent Disposition of Golden Stock”) to such holder at the time of the transfer and the 
ECU Warrants are not treaty-protected property (as discussed above under the heading “Certain Canadian Federal Income 
Tax  Considerations  – Holders  Resident  in  Canada  –  Exchange  of  ECU  Shares  under  the  Arrangement”  and  “Certain 
Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  –  Holders  Resident  in  Canada  –  Taxation  of  Capital  Gains  and  Capital 
Losses” and “Certain Canadian Federal Income Tax Considerations – Holders not Resident in Canada – Exchange of ECU 
Shares under the Arrangement and Subsequent Disposition of Golden Stock”) of the Non-Resident Holder at the time of 
disposition.
Even  if  an  ECU  Warrant  is  taxable  Canadian  property  to  a  Non-Resident  Holder,  such  ECU  Warrant  will  be  treaty 
protected property  of  the  Non-Resident  Holder  at  the  time  of  disposition  (which  time  includes  an  exchange  of  an  ECU 
Warrant under the Arrangement) for purposes of the Tax Act if the capital gain from the disposition of that ECU Warrant 
would, because of an applicable income tax convention to which Canada is a signatory, be exempt from tax under the Tax 
Act. Non-Resident Holders should consult their own tax advisors in this regard.

Dissenting Non-Resident Holders
A Non-Resident Holder who has validly exercised Dissent Rights and that is a Dissenting Shareholder (a “Non-Resident 
Dissenter”) and consequently is paid the fair value for the Non-Resident Dissenter’s ECU Shares by Golden may realize a 
capital  gain  or  capital  loss  as  discussed  above  under  “Certain  Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  –  Holders 
Resident  in  Canada  –  Dissenting  Resident  Holders”.  As  discussed  above  under  “Certain  Canadian  Federal  Income  Tax 
Considerations  –  Holders  Not  Resident  in  Canada  -  Exchange  of  ECU  Shares  under  the  Arrangement  and  Subsequent 
Disposition of Golden Stock”, any resulting capital gain would only be subject to tax under the Tax Act if the ECU Shares 
are taxable Canadian property to the Non-Resident Holder at the Effective Time and are not treaty-protected property of the 
Non-Resident Holder at that time.
An amount paid in respect of interest awarded by the court to a Non-Resident Dissenter will not be subject to Canadian 
withholding tax.
CERTAIN UNITED STATES FEDERAL INCOME TAX CONSIDERATIONS
The following summary describes certain U.S. federal income tax consequences generally applicable to U.S. Holders (as 
defined below) of ECU Shares and ECU Warrants relating to the exchange of ECU Shares for Golden Stock and cash, and 
the exchange of ECU Warrants for Golden Replacement Warrants, pursuant to the Arrangement, and certain U.S. federal 
income tax consequences generally applicable to Non-U.S. Holders of the ownership and disposition of Golden Stock and 
Golden Replacement Warrants received pursuant to the Arrangement. This summary addresses only holders who hold the 
ECU  Shares  and  ECU  Warrants  and  Golden  Stock  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  as  “capital  assets”  within  the 
meaning of Section 1221 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the “U.S. Tax Code”) (generally, assets held 
for investment purposes). This summary is for general information purposes only and does not purport to be a complete 
analysis of all potential U.S. federal income tax considerations that may be relevant to particular holders in light of their 
particular  circumstances,  nor  does  it  deal  with  persons  subject  to  special  treatment  under  the  U.S.  Tax  Code,  such  as 
brokers,  dealers  or  traders  in  securities,  banks  and  other  financial  institutions,  mutual  funds,  holders  subject  to  the 
alternative minimum tax, tax-exempt organizations, passive foreign investment companies, persons that have a functional 
currency  other  than  the  United  States  dollar,  qualified  retirement  plans,  individual  retirement  accounts  and  other  tax-
deferred  accounts,  insurance  companies,  real  estate  investment  trusts,  regulated  investment  companies,  persons  holding 
ECU Shares, ECU Warrants, Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants as part of a straddle, hedge or conversion 
transaction  or  as  part  of  a  synthetic  security  or  other  integrated  transaction,  persons  that  elect  to  use  a  mark-to-market 
method  of  accounting  for  their  securities  holdings  or  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants  or  Golden  Replacement  Warrants, 
Dissenting Shareholders, persons deemed to sell ECU Shares under the constructive sale provisions of the U.S. Tax Code, 
persons who actually or constructively own or have owned (including through attribution) 10% or more of ECU Shares or 
Golden Stock by vote or value, U.S. expatriates, and persons that acquired ECU Shares or ECU Warrants or Golden Stock 
in a compensation transaction. In addition, this summary does not address persons that hold an interest in a partnership or 
other pass-through entity that holds ECU Shares or ECU Warrants or Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants, or 
tax  considerations  arising  under  the  Laws  of  any  state,  local,  or  non-U.S.  jurisdiction  or  other  U.S.  federal  tax 
considerations (e.g., estate or gift tax) other than those pertaining to the income tax. Holders and persons listed above are 
urged to consult their own tax advisors as to the tax considerations applicable to them.
The  following  is  based  upon  the  U.S.  Tax  Code,  Treasury  regulations  promulgated  thereunder,  judicial  authorities, 
published  positions  of  the  IRS  and  other  applicable  authorities,  all  as  in  effect  on  the  date  hereof  and  all  of  which  are 
subject to change or differing interpretations (possibly with retroactive effect).
No rulings have been or will be sought from the IRS, and ECU has not received any legal opinion, regarding any of the tax 
consequences discussed herein. Accordingly, no assurance can be given that the IRS would not assert, or that a court would 
not sustain, a position contrary to any of the tax considerations set forth below.
As used herein, the term “U.S. Holder” means a beneficial owner of ECU Shares, ECU Warrants, Golden Stock or Golden 
Replacement Warrants, as applicable, that is (i) a citizen or individual resident of the U.S., (ii) a corporation (or an entity 
classified as a corporation for U.S. federal income tax purposes) created or organized in or under the Laws of the U.S. or 
any political subdivision thereof, (iii) an estate, the income of which is subject to U.S. federal income taxation regardless of 
its source, or (iv) a trust if (A) a U.S. court is able to exercise primary supervision over its administration and one or more

U.S.  persons,  within  the  meaning  of  Section  7701(a)(30)  of  the  U.S.  Tax  Code,  have  authority  to  control  all  of  its 
substantial decisions or (B) it has properly elected under applicable Treasury regulations to be treated as a U.S. person.
As used herein, the term “Non-U.S. Holder” means a beneficial owner of ECU Shares, ECU Warrants, Golden Stock or

U.S. Federal Income Tax Characterization of the Arrangement
The exchange of ECU Shares for Golden  Stock and cash, and the exchange of ECU  Warrants for Golden  Replacement 
Warrants, pursuant to the Arrangement is intended to be treated as a taxable exchange for U.S. federal income tax purposes, 
and the following discussion  assumes that the transaction  contemplated by the  Arrangement  will be treated as a taxable 
exchange for U.S. federal income tax consequences. However, there is no assurance that the IRS  would agree  with this 
characterization,  and  no  opinion  of  legal  counsel  or  ruling  from  the  IRS  concerning  the  U.S.  federal  income  tax 
consequences of the transactions contemplated by the Arrangement has been obtained, and none will be requested.
Passive Foreign Investment Company Considerations
The U.S. federal income tax consequences to a U.S. Holder with respect to the Arrangement depend on whether ECU is 
treated as a PFIC during any year in which a U.S. Holder owned ECU Shares or ECU Warrants. In general, a non-U.S. 
corporation will be treated as a PFIC for any taxable year during which either (i) 75% or more of the non-U.S. corporation’s 
gross income is passive income (the “income test”), or (ii) 50% or more of the average value of the non-U.S. corporation’s 
assets produce or are held for the production of passive income (the “asset test”).
ECU believes, and the following discussion assumes, that it may be and may have been a PFIC in one or more years since 
its formation.
Exchange of ECU Shares for Golden Stock and Cash, and Exchange of ECU Warrants for Golden Replacement 
Warrants, Pursuant to the Arrangement
U.S. Holders
Gain or Loss Recognition Generally
As discussed below, the U.S. income tax treatment of gain recognized in the Arrangement by a U.S. Holder will depend on 
whether ECU is or has been a PFIC at any time during the U.S. Holder’s holding period in ECU Shares or ECU Warrants, 
and (if ECU was a PFIC at any such time) on whether the U.S. Holder has made certain U.S. income tax elections with 
respect to the ECU Shares.
- 99 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Each U.S. Holder will recognize gain or loss equal to the difference between (a) the sum of the (i) U.S. dollar equivalent of 
the Canadian dollars received calculated by reference to the exchange rate in effect on the date of receipt and (ii) the fair 
market value of the Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants received and (b) the U.S. Holder’s adjusted tax basis in 
its ECU Shares or ECU Warrants disposed of pursuant to the Arrangement.
Under  proposed  Treasury  Regulations  (the  “Proposed  Treasury  Regulations”),  a  U.S.  Holder  who  has  an  option  to 
acquire stock of a PFIC is considered to own stock of a PFIC for purposes of applying the rules governing the taxation of 
gain  recognized  upon  the  disposition  of  stock  of  a  PFIC.    Under  the  Proposed  Treasury  Regulations,  holders  of  ECU 
Warrants who exchange such warrants for Golden Replacement Warrants pursuant to the Arrangement will be treated as 
having  disposed  of  the  stock  of  a  PFIC  if  they  held  ECU  Warrants  during  any  period  in  which  ECU  was  a  PFIC.  
Accordingly, any gain realized upon the exchange will be subject to tax under the “excess distribution” regime described 
below.
Gain Recognized by Non-PFIC Shareholders and Non-PFIC Warrantholders
Any gain recognized by a U.S. Holder whose holding period in ECU Shares or ECU Warrants does not include any period 
during which ECU was a PFIC will be treated as a capital gain, and as a long-term capital gain if the U.S. Holder’s holding 
period with respect to its ECU Shares or ECU Warrants is more than one year at the time of the Arrangement.
PFIC Warrantholders and Non-Electing PFIC Shareholders
Any  gain  recognized  by  a  U.S.  Holder  whose  holding  period  for  the  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants  include  any  period 
during which ECU was a PFIC will be taxed under the PFIC “excess distribution” regime (assuming, with respect to ECU 
Shares, that the U.S. Holder has not made the “mark-to-market” election described below) . Under that regime, gain, if any, 
realized  by  a  U.S.  Holder  who  disposes  of  ECU  Shares  or  ECU  Warrants  pursuant  to  the  Arrangement  will  (except  as 
described in the section that follows) be allocated ratably to each day of the U.S. Holder’s holding period with respect to 
such ECU Shares or ECU Warrants. Gain allocated to the year of disposition and to any year before ECU became a PFIC 
will be treated as arising in the year of disposition and taxed at ordinary U.S. federal income tax rates. Gain allocated to 
each of the other years will be taxed at the highest ordinary U.S. federal income tax rate in effect for each of those years, 
and interest will be added to the tax determined for each of those years. The sum of the taxes and interest calculated for all 
other years will be an addition to the tax for the year in which the disposition of the ECU Shares or ECU Warrants occurs. 
A U.S. Holder that is not a corporation must treat the interest as non-deductible personal interest.
Any loss recognized by a U.S. Holder will generally be treated as capital loss, which will be long-term capital loss if the 
U.S. Holder’s holding period with respect to its ECU Shares or ECU Warrants is more than one year at the time of the 
Arrangement, subject to the special rules described in the section that follows. The deductibility of capital loss is subject to 
limitations. For U.S. foreign tax credit purposes, any such gain or loss recognized by a U.S. Holder generally will be treated 
as gain or loss from sources within the United States
PFIC Shareholders who have made a “Market-to-Market” Election
If a U.S. Holder of ECU Shares has made a valid election to recognize any gain or loss on its ECU Shares on a mark-to-
market basis at the end of each taxable year, then any gain on the exchange of the ECU Shares in the Arrangement will be 
treated as ordinary income.  Any loss on the exchange pursuant to the Arrangement will be treated as ordinary loss to the 
extent of the U.S. Holder’s prior net mark-to-market gains.  Any remaining losses will generally be treated as capital losses, 
and as long-term capital losses if the U.S. Holder’s holding period in the shares exceeded one year.  The mark-to-market 
election is not available for ECU Warrants.
Under the Proposed Treasury Regulations, if ECU is a PFIC and owns shares of another PFIC (a “lower-tier PFIC”), a 
shareholder of ECU is treated as an indirect owner of the shares of the lower-tier PFIC, and must account for gains from the 
indirect  disposition  of  the  lower-tier  PFIC  as  an  excess  distribution  separately.    ECU  believes  that  one  or  more  of  its 
subsidiaries may have been a PFIC in one or more years.  The Proposed Treasury Regulations provide for corresponding 
basis adjustments of the stock through which ownership of the lower-tier PFIC is attributed.   A mark-to-market election 
generally may not be made for stock of a lower-tier PFIC.

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Basis and Holding Period in Golden Stock
A U.S. Holder will have an initial tax basis in the Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants received pursuant to the 
Arrangement  equal  to  the  fair  market  value  of  such  shares  and  warrants  at  the  time  of  their  receipt.  The  U.S.  Holder’s 
holding period for such Golden Stock or Golden Replacement Warrants will commence on the day after the date of receipt.
Cash Consideration Received Pursuant to the Arrangement
Any cash consideration paid in Canadian dollars pursuant to the Arrangement will be taken into account in determining the 
taxable gain or loss recognized by a U.S. Holder of ECU Shares in a U.S. dollar amount calculated by reference to the 
exchange rate in effect on the date of receipt by such U.S. Holder, regardless of whether the cash consideration is in fact 
converted into U.S. dollars. Such Canadian dollars received by a U.S. Holder will have a tax basis equal to their U.S. dollar 
value at the time such proceeds are received. If such Canadian dollars are converted into U.S. dollars on the date of receipt, 
the U.S. Holder generally should not be required to recognize foreign currency gain or loss. The amount of gain or loss 
recognized  on  a  subsequent  sale  or  other  disposition  of  such  Canadian  dollars  will  equal  the  difference  between  (i)  the 
amount of U.S. dollars, or the fair market value in U.S. dollars of other property received, in such sale or other disposition, 
and (ii) the U.S. Holder’s tax basis in such Canadian dollars. Any  such  gain or loss  generally  will be treated as United 
States source ordinary income or loss.
PFIC Information Reporting
U.S. Holders whose holding period in the ECU Shares or ECU Warrants include any period during which ECU was a PFIC 
must report certain information to the IRS on Form 8621 with their U.S. federal income tax return.  U.S. Holders are urged 
to consult with their own tax advisors concerning such reporting requirements.
Status of Proposed Treasury Regulations
The Proposed Treasury Regulations state that they are to be effective for transactions occurring on or after April 11, 1992. 
If the Proposed Treasury Regulations are adopted in their current form, the tax consequences to a U.S. Holder should be as 
set forth in the preceding paragraphs.  However, because the Proposed Treasury Regulations have not yet been adopted in 
final form, they are not currently effective and there is no assurance they will be finally adopted in the form and with the 
effective date proposed.  Nevertheless, the IRS has announced that, in the absence of final Treasury Regulations, taxpayers 
may apply reasonable interpretations of Code provisions applicable to PFICs and that it considers the rules set forth in the 
Proposed Treasury Regulations to be reasonable interpretations of those Code provisions.
The rules governing the taxation of the disposition of securities of a PFIC are complex, and holders of ECU Shares 
or ECU Warrants are urged to consult their own tax advisors as to the tax considerations applicable to them.
Non-U.S. Holders
A Non-U.S. Holder generally will not be subject to U.S. federal income tax (or any withholding thereof) with respect to any 
gain recognized on the exchange of ECU Shares for cash and Golden Stock, or ECU Warrants for Golden Replacement 
Warrants, unless (i) the gain is effectively connected with a trade or business of the Non-U.S. Holder in the U.S. and, in 
cases in which certain tax treaties apply, is attributable to a U.S. permanent establishment or fixed base of the Non-U.S. 
Holder (collectively, “effectively connected gain”); or (ii) the Non-U.S. Holder is a non-resident alien individual who is 
present in the U.S. for 183 or more days during the taxable year of disposition and meets certain other requirements.
Information Reporting and Backup Withholding
In general, information reporting will apply with respect to cash proceeds received on the disposition of ECU Shares that 
are  paid  to  a  U.S.  Holder  within  the  United  States  (and,  in  certain  cases,  outside  of  the  United  States),  unless  the  U.S. 
Holder establishes that it is an exempt recipient, such as a corporation.  Backup withholding (currently imposed at a rate of 
28%)  may  apply  to  such  payments  if  the  U.S.  Holder  fails  to  timely  provide  a  taxpayer  identification  number  or 
certification of exempt status or has failed to report in full dividend and interest income in prior taxable years.
- 101 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Payments to Non-U.S. Holders through certain U.S.-related financial intermediaries will generally be subject to information 
reporting,  and  depending  on  the  circumstances  backup  withholding,  unless  the  Non-U.S.  Holder,  or  beneficial  owner 
thereof,  as  applicable,  certifies  that  it  is  a  Non-U.S.  Holder  on  Form  W-8BEN  (or  other  applicable  form),  or  otherwise 
establishes an exemption and the payor does not have actual knowledge or reason to know the holder is a U.S. person, as 
defined under the Code, that is not an exempt recipient.  Copies of the information returns reporting any such payments and 
withholding may also be made available to the tax authorities in the country in which the Non-U.S. Holder resides under 
the provisions of an applicable income tax treaty
Backup withholding is not an additional tax.  Any amounts withheld under the backup withholding rules may be allowed as 
a refund or a credit against such holder’s federal income tax liability, provided the required information is timely furnished 
to the IRS.
Ownership and Disposition of Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants Received Pursuant to the 
Arrangement
U.S. Holders
Exercise of Golden Replacement Warrants
A U.S. Holder generally will not recognize gain or loss for U.S. federal income tax purposes upon the cash exercise of a 
Golden  Replacement  Warrant.  A  U.S.  Holder’s  tax  basis  in  the  Golden  Stock  received  on  a  cash  exercise  of  a  Golden 
Replacement Warrant will equal the sum of the U.S. Holder’s tax basis in the Golden Replacement Warrant plus the cash 
paid to exercise the Golden Replacement Warrant. The holding period of the Golden Stock received on the cash exercise of 
a Golden Replacement Warrant should begin on the date of exercise.
The  tax  treatment  of  a  cashless  exercise  of  a  Golden  Replacement  Warrant,  if  available,  (i.e.,  where  a  portion  of  the 
holder’s Golden Replacement Warrants are surrendered as the exercise price for other Golden Replacement Warrants) is 
uncertain. A cashless exercise may, for example, be treated as a tax-free “recapitalization,” in which case a holder’s tax 
basis in  the  stock received  would equal the tax basis in the surrendered Golden Replacement Warrants.  Alternatively, a 
cashless exercise may be treated similarly to a cash exercise. It is also possible that a cashless exercise could be treated as a 
taxable exchange in which gain or loss should be recognized.
The holding period for Golden Stock acquired in a cashless exercise will depend on the United States federal income tax 
treatment of a cashless exercise. The holding period for a share of Golden Stock acquired in a cashless exercise may include 
the  holder’s  holding  period  for  the  exercised  Golden  Replacement  Warrant  if  the  cashless  exercise  is  treated  as  a 
recapitalization, or the holding period may begin on the date the Golden Replacement Warrant is exercised if the cashless 
exercise is treated similarly to a cash exercise, or the holding period may begin on the day following the date of exercise if 
the cashless exercise is treated as a taxable exchange. Due to the absence of authority on the United States federal income 
tax  treatment  of  a  cashless  exercise,  there  can  be  no  assurance  which,  if  any,  of  the  alternative  tax  consequences  and 
holding periods described above would be adopted by the IRS or a court of law. Accordingly, holders are urged to consult 
their tax advisors as to the tax consequences of a cashless exercise.
Adjustment to Golden Replacement Warrants
Adjustments to the exercise price or the number of shares to be received upon exercise of a Golden Replacement Warrant 
may  in  some  circumstances  result  in  a  deemed  dividend  to  a  U.S.  Holder  to  the  extent  of  the  Golden’s  current  or 
accumulated earnings and profits, as determined under U.S. federal income tax principles, if such change has the effect of 
increasing the U.S. Holder’s proportionate interest in the earnings and profits of Golden.
Sale or Exchange of Golden Replacement Warrants
Upon the sale or exchange of a Golden Replacement Warrant, a U.S. Holder will generally recognize gain or loss equal to 
the difference between the amount realized on such sale or exchange and the U.S. Holder’s adjusted tax basis in the Golden 
Replacement Warrant.  The gain or loss will generally be capital gain or loss, and will be long-term capital gain or loss if
- 102 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
the U.S. Holder’s holding period in the Golden Replacement Warrant exceeds one year at the time of such sale or exchange. 
The deductibility of capital losses is subject to limitations.
Expiration of Golden Replacement Warrants
Upon the expiration of a Golden Replacement Warrant, a U.S. Holder will recognize a capital loss equal to its adjusted tax 
basis in the Golden Replacement Warrant.  The loss will be a long-term capital loss if the U.S. Holder’s holding period in 
the Golden Replacement Warrant exceeded one year at the time of the expiration.  The deductibility of capital losses is 
subject to limitations.
Non-U.S. Holders
Distributions on Golden Stock
Distributions  with  respect  to  Golden  Stock  will  be  treated  as  dividends  when  paid  to  the  extent  of  Golden’s  current  or 
accumulated earnings and profits as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes. Generally, distributions treated as 
dividends paid to a Non-U.S. Holder with respect to Golden Stock will be subject to a 30% U.S. withholding tax, or such 
lower rate as may be specified by an applicable income tax treaty. Distributions that are effectively connected with such 
Non-U.S. Holder’s conduct of a trade or business in the United States (and, if a tax treaty applies, are attributable to a U.S. 
permanent establishment of such holder) are generally subject to U.S. federal income tax on a net income basis and are 
exempt from the 30% withholding tax (assuming compliance with certain certification requirements). Any such effectively 
connected  distributions  received  by  a  Non-U.S.  Holder  that  is  a  corporation  may  also,  under  certain  circumstances,  be 
subject to an additional “branch profits tax” at a 30% rate or such lower rate as may be applicable under an income tax 
treaty.
For purposes of obtaining a reduced rate of withholding under an income tax treaty, a Non-U.S. Holder will generally be 
required to provide a U.S. taxpayer identification number as well as certain information concerning the holder’s country of 
residence and entitlement to tax treaty benefits.  A Non-U.S. Holder can  generally  meet the certification requirement by 
providing a properly executed IRS Form W-8BEN (if the holder is claiming the benefits of an income tax treaty) or Form 
W-8ECI (if the dividends are effectively connected with a trade or business in the United States) or suitable substitute form.
If a distribution exceeds Golden’s current and accumulated earnings and profits, the excess  will be treated as a tax-free 
return of the Non-U.S. Holder’s investment to the extent of the Non-U.S. Holder’s adjusted tax basis in its Golden Stock.  
Any remaining excess will be treated as capital gain from a sale or disposition of such stock.  A Non-U.S. Holder will have 
an initial tax basis in the Golden Stock received pursuant to the Arrangement equal to the fair market value of such shares 
at the time of their receipt.
Sale or Exchange of Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants
A Non-U.S. Holder generally will not be subject to U.S. federal income tax (or any withholding thereof) with respect to 
gain  recognized  on  a  sale  or  other  disposition  of  Golden  Stock  or  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  unless  (i)  the  gain  is 
effectively connected with a trade or business of the Non-U.S. Holder in the U.S. and, in cases in which certain tax treaties 
apply, is attributable to a U.S. permanent establishment or fixed base of the Non-U.S.  Holder (collectively, “effectively 
connected gain”); or (ii) the Non-U.S. Holder is a non-resident alien individual who is present in the U.S. for 183 or more 
days during the taxable year of disposition and meets certain other requirements.
Exercise of Golden Replacement Warrants.
The U.S. federal income tax treatment of a Non-U.S. Holder upon the exercise of a Golden Replacement Warrant will be 
the same as that of U.S. Holder, as described above under “Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations –
Ownership and Disposition of Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants Received Pursuant to the Arrangement --
U.S. Holders - Exercise of Golden Replacement Warrants” (except if a cashless exercise results in the recognition of gain or 
loss to the Non-U.S. Holder), which will be treated in the same manner as described above under “Certain United States 
Federal  Income  Tax  Considerations  –  Ownership  and  Disposition  of  Golden  Stock  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants

if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Received Pursuant to the Arrangement Non-U.S. Holders - Sale or Exchange of Golden Stock and Golden Replacement 
Warrants”.
Adjustments to Golden Replacement Warrants.
To the extent that an adjustment to the exercise price or the number of shares of Golden Stock to be received upon exercise 
of a Golden Replacement Warrant results in a deemed dividend to a Non-U.S. Holder, such dividend will be treated in the 
same manner as an actual dividend paid with respect to Golden Stock (as described above).
Expiration of Golden Replacement Warrants.
If gain on the sale or exchange of a Golden Replacement Warrant would be treated as U.S. trade or business income to a 
Non-U.S.  Holder,  the  U.S.  federal  income  tax  consequences  to  such  Non-U.S.  Holder  upon  expiration  of  the  Golden 
Replacement Warrant will be the same as those to a U.S. Holder, as described above.
Information Reporting and Backup Withholding
In general, information reporting will also apply with respect to the amount of dividends paid to holders of Golden Stock 
and the tax withheld with respect to such dividends, regardless of whether withholding was required.  Backup withholding 
(currently  imposed  at  a  rate  of  28%)  will  generally  apply  to  such  dividends  paid  to  a  Non-U.S.  Holder  unless  proper 
certification  of  non-U.S.  status  (usually  on  an  IRS  Form  W-8BEN)  is  provided,  and  the  payor  does  not  have  actual 
knowledge or reason to know that the beneficial owner is a U.S. person, as defined under the Code.
Payment  of  the  proceeds  of  a  sale  of  Golden  Stock  within  the  United  States  or  conducted  through  certain  U.S.-related 
financial  intermediaries  is  subject  to  information  reporting  and,  depending  on  the  circumstances,  backup  withholding, 
unless the Non-U.S. Holder, or beneficial owner thereof, as applicable, certifies that it is a Non-U.S. Holder on Form W-
8BEN (or other applicable form), or otherwise establishes an exemption and the payor does not have actual knowledge or 
reason to know the holder is a U.S. person, as defined under the Code, that is not an exempt recipient.
Copies of the information returns reporting any of the foregoing payments and withholding may also be made available to 
the tax authorities in the country in which the Non-U.S. Holder resides under the provisions of an applicable income tax 
treaty.
Any amounts withheld under the backup withholding rules may be allowed as a refund or a credit against such Non-U.S. 
Holder’s U.S. federal income tax liability, provided the required information is timely furnished to the IRS.
Recently Enacted Withholding and Information Reporting Legislation Applicable to U.S. and Non-U.S. Holders
Recently  enacted  legislation  will  require,  after  December  31,  2012,  withholding  at  a  rate  of  30  percent  on  dividends  in 
respect of, and gross proceeds from the sale of, Golden Stock and Golden Replacement Warrants held by or through certain 
foreign  financial  institutions  (including  investment  funds),  unless  such  institution  enters  into  an  agreement  with  the 
Secretary of the Treasury to report, on an annual basis, information with respect to shares in the institution held by certain 
U.S. persons and by certain non-U.S. entities that are wholly or partially owned by U.S. persons. Accordingly, the entity 
through  which  Golden  Stock  and  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  are  held  will  affect  the  determination  of  whether  such 
withholding is required. Similarly, dividends in respect of, and gross proceeds from the sale of, Golden Stock and Golden 
Replacement Warrants  held by an investor that is a non-financial non-US entity will be subject to withholding at a rate of 
30 percent, unless such entity either (i) certifies that such entity does not have any “substantial United States owners” or (ii) 
provides certain information regarding the entity’s “substantial United States owners,” which will in turn be provided to the 
Secretary  of  the  Treasury.  U.S.  Holders  and  Non-U.S.  Holders  are  encouraged  to  consult  with  their  own  tax  advisors 
regarding  the  possible  implications  of  the  legislation  on  their  ownership  of  Golden  Stock  and  Golden  Replacement 
Warrants.

SECURITIES LAWS CONSIDERATIONS
The  following  is  a  brief  summary  of  the  securities  law  considerations  applicable  to  the  Arrangement  and  transactions 
contemplated thereby.
Canadian Securities Laws
Status under Canadian Securities Laws
ECU  is  a  reporting  issuer  in  all  of  the  provinces  of  Canada.  ECU  Shares  currently  trade  on  the  TSX  under  the  symbol 
“ECU” and the February 2009 Warrants currently trade on the TSX under the symbol “ECU.WT”. Following the closing of 
the Arrangement, the ECU Shares and the February 2009 Warrants will be delisted from the TSX, and Golden will apply to 
the applicable Canadian Securities Authorities to have ECU cease to be a reporting issuer.
Golden is a reporting issuer in the provinces of Alberta, British Columbia and Ontario. Golden Stock is listed on the TSX 
under the symbol “AUM” and on the NYSE Amex under the symbol “AUMN”. It is a condition of the Arrangement that 
the shares of Golden Stock issued to ECU Shareholders pursuant to the Arrangement, and which are reserved for issue upon 
exercise of the Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants, be conditionally listed on the TSX and the 
NYSE Amex, and that the Golden Replacement February 2009 Warrants issued to ECU Warrantholders pursuant to the 
Arrangement be conditionally listed on the TSX.
Distribution and Resales of Securities
The issue of Golden Stock, Golden Replacement Options, Golden Replacements Warrants and ECU Replacement Notes 
pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  including  the  issue  of  Golden  Stock  on  the  exercise  of  Golden  Replacement  Options  and 
Golden  Replacement  Warrants,  will  constitute  distributions  of  securities  which  are  exempt  from  the  prospectus 
requirements of the Canadian Securities Laws. The Golden Stock, Golden Replacement Options and Golden Replacement 
Warrants  issued  pursuant  to  the  Arrangement,  including  the  Golden  Stock  issuable  upon  the  exercise  of  the  Golden 
Replacement Options and Golden Replacement Warrants, may be resold in any province or territory of Canada, provided 
that: (i) Golden is a reporting issuer in a jurisdiction of Canada for the four months immediately preceding the trade; (ii) the 
trade is not a “control distribution” as defined in NI 45-102, (iii) no unusual effort is made to prepare the market or create a 
demand for those securities, (iv) no extraordinary commission or consideration is paid in respect of that sale, and (v) if the 
selling security holder is an insider or officer of Golden, the insider or officer has no reasonable grounds to believe that 
Golden is in default of Canadian Securities Laws.  As Golden will apply to have ECU cease to be a reporting issuer within 
Canada  after  the  Arrangement,  the  ECU  Replacement  Notes  may  not  be  resold  within  Canada  except  pursuant  to  an 
exemption from the prospectus requirements of applicable Canadian Securities Laws.
Each ECU Securityholder is urged to consult the holder’s professional advisors with respect to restrictions applicable to 
trades in Golden Stock under Canadian Securities Laws.
Requirement for Minority Approval under MI 61-101
ECU is a reporting issuer (or the equivalent) under securities legislation in each of the provinces of Canada and is, among 
other things, subject to MI 61-101. MI 61-101 is intended to regulate insider bids, issuer bids, business combinations and 
related party transactions to ensure that all securityholders are treated in a manner that is fair and perceived to be fair by 
requiring, among other things, enhanced disclosure, review and approval processes. It is expected that Mr. Michel Roy, 
Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of ECU, and Mr. Stephen J. Altmann, President  of ECU,  will receive change of 
control bonus payments in connection with the Arrangement as described under “The Arrangement – Interests of Directors 
and  Officers  of  ECU  in  the  Arrangement”  in  this  Circular.  Such  payments  will  constitute  a  “collateral  benefit”  under
- 105 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
MI 61-101.  Accordingly,  the  Arrangement  constitutes  a  “business combination”  for  the  purposes  of  MI 61-101,  thereby 
requiring ECU to obtain “minority approval” of the Arrangement from ECU Shareholders.
Pursuant to MI 61-101, in determining whether minority approval for the Arrangement has been obtained, ECU is required 
to exclude the votes attaching to the ECU Shares beneficially owned or controlled by “interested parties” (being Mr. Roy 
and Mr. Altmann) and their “related parties” and “joint actors”, all as defined in MI 61-101. Accordingly, the Arrangement 
Resolution must be passed by a simple majority of the votes cast thereon by ECU Shareholders, excluding the votes cast in 
respect  of  ECU  Shares  beneficially  owned  or  over  which  control  or  direction  is  exercised  by  Mr.  Michel  Roy  and  Mr. 
Stephen J. Altmann and their respective related parties or joint actors.
MI  61-101  excludes  certain  benefits  from  the  meaning  of  “collateral  benefit”,  including,  among  others,  a  benefit  to  a 
director or senior officer where (i) the benefit is not conferred for the purpose, in whole or in part, of increasing the value of 
the consideration paid to the director or senior officer for securities relinquished under the transaction; (ii) the benefit is not, 
by its terms, conditional on the director or senior officer supporting the transaction in any manner; (iii) full particulars of 
the benefit are disclosed in the disclosure document for the transaction; and (iv) at the date of the transaction was entered 
into the director or senior officer and his or her associated entities beneficially own, or exercise control or direction over, 
less than 1% of the outstanding securities of each class of equity securities of the issuer.
To the knowledge of ECU, Mr. Roy and Mr. Altmann are the only directors or senior officers  who, together  with their 
associated entities, beneficially owned or exercised control or direction over more than 1% of the ECU Shares as calculated 
in accordance with MI 61-101 (which included such number of ECU Shares that would be issuable if the ECU Options held 
by  Mr.  Roy  or  Mr.  Altmann  were  fully  exercised)  outstanding  as  at  June  24,  2011,  being  the  date  the  Arrangement 
Agreement was entered into. As noted under the heading “The Arrangement – Interests of Directors and Officers of ECU in 
the Arrangement” in this Circular, Mr. Roy, together with his associated entities, holds, directly or indirectly, or exercises 
control  or  direction  over,  2,960,826  ECU  Shares  and  4,370,000  ECU  Options,  and  Mr.  Altmann,  together  with  his 
associated entities, holds, directly or indirectly, or exercises control or direction over, 42,500 ECU Shares and 4,800,000
ECU Options.
U.S. Securities Laws
The  following  discussion  is  a  general  overview  of  certain  requirements  of  U.S.  federal  and  state  securities  laws 
applicable to ECU Securityholders.  All ECU Securityholders are urged to consult with their own legal advisors to 
ensure that the resale of Golden Securities issued to them under the Arrangement complies with applicable federal 
and state securities laws. Further information applicable to U.S. Securityholders is disclosed in this Circular under 
“Note to United States Securityholders”.
Exemption from the Registration Requirements of the U.S. Securities Act
The Golden Securities to be issued by Golden pursuant to the Arrangement will not be registered under the U.S. Securities 
Act  or  the  securities  laws  of  any  state  of  the  United  States  and  will  be  effected  in  reliance  on  the  Section  3(a)(10) 
Exemption and exemptions provided under the securities laws of each state of the United States. Section 3(a)(l0) of the U.S. 
Securities Act exempts from registration securities which are issued in exchange for outstanding securities where the terms 
and conditions of such issue and exchange are approved, after a hearing upon the fairness of such terms and conditions at 
which  all  persons  to  whom  it  is  proposed  to  issue  securities  in  such  exchange  have  the  right  to  appear,  by  a  court  or 
governmental  authority  expressly  authorized  by  Law  to  grant  such  approval.  The  SEC  generally  recognizes  exchanges 
effected under a Canadian plan of arrangement as qualifying for the Section 3(a)(10) Exemption. Accordingly, the Final 
Order, if granted, will constitute a basis for the exemption from the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act with 
respect to the Golden Securities issued in connection with the Arrangement.
Resales of Golden Stock Issued to ECU Shareholders
The restrictions on resale of the Golden Stock issued to ECU Shareholders imposed by the U.S. Securities Act will depend 
on whether the ECU Shareholder is an “affiliate” of Golden within 90 days prior to the Effective Time. As defined in Rule 
144 under the U.S. Securities Act, an “affiliate” of an issuer is a person that directly or indirectly through one or  more 
intermediaries,  controls,  or  is  controlled  by,  or  is  under  common  control  with,  the  issuer.  Typically,  persons  who  are
- 106 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
executive officers, directors or 10% or greater shareholders of an issuer are considered to be its “affiliates”. The resale rules 
applicable to ECU Shareholders are summarized below. ECU Shareholders who are not affiliates of Golden within 90 days 
before the Effective Time and who will not be affiliates of Golden after the Effective Time may resell the Golden Stock 
issued to them upon closing of the Arrangement in the United States without restriction under the U.S. Securities Act.
ECU  Shareholders  who  are  or  have  been  affiliates  of  Golden  within  90  days  before  the  Effective  Time  or  who  will  be 
affiliates of Golden after the Effective Time will be subject to restrictions on resale imposed by the U.S. Securities Act with 
respect to Golden Stock issued at the Effective Time. These affiliates may not resell their Golden Stock unless such shares 
are  registered  under  the  U.S.  Securities  Act  or  an  exemption  from  registration  is  available.  Affiliates  may  resell  their 
Golden Stock in accordance with the provisions of Rule 144 under the U.S. Securities Act, including compliance with the 
current public information requirements, the applicable holding period, and the volume and manner of sale limitations.
Resales of Golden Replacement Warrants  Issued to ECU Warrantholders
The  restrictions  on  resale  of  the  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  issued  to  ECU  Warrantholders  imposed  by  the  U.S. 
Securities  Act  will  depend  on  whether  the  ECU  Warrantholder  is  an  “affiliate”  of  Golden  within  90  days  prior  to  the 
Effective Time. As defined in Rule 144 under the U.S. Securities Act, an “affiliate” of an issuer is a person that directly or 
indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, or is controlled by, or is under common control with, the issuer. 
Typically, persons who are executive officers, directors or 10% or greater shareholders of an issuer are considered to be its 
“affiliates”. The resale rules applicable to ECU Warrantholders are summarized below. ECU Warrantholders who are not 
affiliates of Golden within 90 days before the Effective Time and who will not be affiliates of Golden after the Effective 
Time may resell the Golden Replacement Warrants issued to them upon closing of the Arrangement in the United States 
without restriction under the U.S. Securities Act.
ECU Warrantholders who are or have been affiliates of Golden within 90 days before the Effective Time or who will be 
affiliates of Golden after the Effective Time will be subject to restrictions on resale imposed by the U.S. Securities Act with 
respect  to  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  issued  at  the  Effective  Time.  These  affiliates  may  not  resell  their  Golden 
Replacement  Warrants  unless  such  Golden  Replacement  Warrants  are  registered  under  the  U.S.  Securities  Act  or  an 
exemption from registration is available. Affiliates may resell their Golden Replacement Warrants in accordance with the 
provisions  of  Rule  144  under  the  U.S.  Securities  Act,  including  compliance  with  the  current  public  information 
requirements, the applicable holding period, and the volume and manner of sale limitations.
Resales of Golden Replacement Options after the Completion of the Arrangement
The Golden Replacement Options issuable in connection  with the  Arrangement are not transferable, in accordance  with 
their terms, other than by will or the Laws of succession and distribution.
Issuance and Resale of Golden Stock Upon Exercise of Golden Replacement Securities
The  Golden  Stock  issuable  upon  exercise  of  the  Golden  Replacement  Securities  has  not  been  registered  under  the  U.S. 
Securities  Act  or  under  applicable  state  securities  laws.    As  a  result,  the  Golden  Replacement  Securities  may  not  be 
exercised by or on behalf of a person in the United States or a U.S. Person, and the Golden Stock issuable upon exercise 
thereof in the United States or by a U.S. Person may not be offered or resold unless such securities have been registered 
under the U.S. Securities Act and the securities laws of all applicable states of the United States or an exemption from such 
registration requirements is available. Golden has agreed that on or prior to the Effective Time, it shall use commercially 
reasonable efforts to (i) prepare and file with the SEC a registration statement on Form S-8 (or amended Form S-8) with 
respect to the shares of Golden Stock issuable upon exercise or settlement, from time to time, of the Golden Replacement 
Options  and  (ii)  file  a  shelf  registration  statement  (or  amend  an  existing  shelf  registration  statement)  with  the  SEC 
registering under the U.S. Securities Act the issuance of the Golden Stock upon exercise, from time to time, of the Golden 
Replacement Warrants and have such registration statement (or amended registration statement) declared effective.

DESCRIPTION OF SECURITIES INVOLVED IN THE ARRANGEMENT
ECU Shares
ECU’s authorized share structure consists of an unlimited number of ECU Shares without par value. The holders of ECU 
Shares are entitled to one vote per share at all meetings of ECU Shareholders, except for meetings at which only the holders 
of shares of another class or of a particular series are entitled to vote separately as a class or series.
The holders of ECU Shares are entitled to receive dividends if, as and when declared by the ECU Board. In the event of the 
dissolution, liquidation, winding-up or other distribution of ECU’s assets, such holders are entitled to receive on a pro rata 
basis all of ECU’s assets remaining after payment of all  of ECU’s liabilities. The ECU Shares carry no pre-emptive or 
conversion rights.
Provisions as to the modification, amendment or variation of the rights attached to the ECU Shares are contained in the 
QBCA.    Generally,  all  changes  to  the  authorized  share  structure  require  an  amendment  to  the  articles  of  ECU  that  is 
authorized  pursuant  to  a  resolution  approved  by  at  least  two-thirds  of  the  votes  cast  at  a  meeting  of  ECU  Shareholders
entitled to vote on the resolution.
The transfer agent and registrar for the ECU Shares is Computershare at its principal offices in Montreal, Québec, Canada.
The ECU Shares are listed for trading on the TSX under the symbol “ECU”. The closing price of the ECU Shares on the 
TSX  on  July  28,  2011  was  Cdn$0.72,  and  the  closing  price  of  the  ECU  Shares  on  the  TSX  on  June  23,  2011,  the  last 
trading day prior to the date of announcement of the proposed Arrangement, was Cdn$1.04.
Dividends
Since January 1, 2008, ECU has not declared or paid any dividends or made any distributions on the ECU Shares.
Golden Stock
Golden’s  authorized  capital  stock  consists  of  50,000,000  shares  of  Golden  Stock,  par  value  US$0.01  per  share,  and 
10,000,000  shares  of  preferred  stock,  par  value  US$0.01  per  share.    Golden  is  seeking  the  approval  of  the  Golden 
Stockholders  at  the  Golden  Meeting  to  increase  the  number  of  shares  of  its  authorized  Golden  Stock  from  50,000,000 
shares to 100,000,000 shares pursuant to the Golden Charter Amendment Proposal.
Each  holder  of  Golden  Stock  is  entitled  to  one  vote  per  share.  Subject  to  the  rights  of  the  holders  of  any  outstanding 
preferred stock, all voting rights are vested in the holders of shares of Golden Stock. Holders of shares of Golden Stock 
have  non-cumulative  voting  rights,  meaning  that  the  holders  of  more  than  50%  of  the  shares  voting  for  the  election  of 
directors  will  be  able  to  elect  100%  of  the  directors,  and  the  holders  of  the  remaining  shares  voting  for  the  election  of 
directors will not be able to elect any directors.
Holders  of  Golden  Stock  are  entitled  to  receive  dividends  when,  as  and  if  declared  by  the  Golden  Board,  out  of  funds 
legally available for their payment, subject to the rights of holders of any outstanding preferred stock.
In the event of Golden’s voluntary or involuntary liquidation, dissolution or winding up, the holders of Golden Stock will 
be entitled to share equally in any of assets available for distribution after the payment in full of all debts and distributions 
and after the holders of outstanding preferred stock, if any, have received their liquidation preferences in full.
Under  Delaware  law,  a  stockholder  is  not  entitled  to  pre-emptive  rights  to  subscribe  for  additional  issuances  of  Golden 
Stock or any other class or series of Golden Stock or any security convertible into such stock in proportion to the shares that 
are owned unless there is a provision to the contrary in the certificate of incorporation. Golden’s Amended and Restated 
Certificate of Incorporation does not provide its stockholders with any pre-emptive or similar rights.
The transfer agent and registrar for Golden Stock is Computershare, at its offices in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
Golden  Stock  is  listed  for  trading  on  the  TSX  under  the  symbol  “AUM”  and  on  the  NYSE  Amex  under  the  symbol 
“AUMN”. The closing price of Golden Stock on the TSX on July 28, 2011 was Cdn$13.93, and the closing price of the 
Golden  Stock  on  the  TSX  on  June  23,  2011,  the  last  trading  day  prior  to  the  date  of  announcement  of  the  proposed

of the TSX and the NYSE Amex, respectively.
Dividends
Golden  has  never  declared  or  paid  any  cash  dividends  on  the  Golden  Stock  and  does  not  anticipate  paying  any  cash 
dividends on the Golden Stock in the foreseeable future. Golden currently intends to retain all future earnings, if any, to 
fund the development and growth of its business. The Golden Board’s ability to declare a dividend is also subject to limits 
imposed by Delaware corporate law.
ECU Options
ECU has adopted the ECU Stock Option Plan pursuant to which the ECU Board can distribute ECU Options to acquire 
ECU  Shares  to  its  directors,  officers,  employees  and  consultants.  The  conditions  and  the  exercise  price  of  every  ECU 
Option are determined by the members of the ECU Board.
Pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan, ECU has reserved an aggregate of 14,252,398 ECU Shares for issuance pursuant to 
the exercise of ECU Options. The ECU Stock Option Plan provides that (i) the maximum number of ECU Shares which 
may be reserved for issuance pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan to any one beneficiary in any 12-month period may 
not exceed 5% of the number of ECU Shares then issued and outstanding, and (ii) the maximum number of ECU Shares 
which  may be reserved, in the aggregate,  for issuance pursuant to  the ECU  Stock Option Plan to beneficiaries  who  are 
conducting  investor  relations  activities  in  any  12-month  period  may  not  exceed  2%  of  the  number  of  ECU  Shares  then 
issued and outstanding. The exercise price of ECU Options granted under the ECU Stock Option Plan is not permitted to be 
less than the closing price of the ECU Shares on the day preceding the grant of the ECU Options, less any discount allowed 
by applicable securities legislation. ECU Options granted pursuant to the ECU Stock Option Plan must have an exercise 
period of no more than 10 years, or such lesser period as may be imposed by applicable securities legislation.
Holders of ECU Options do not have any voting or other rights which a holder of ECU Shares would have, except that such 
holders will have the right to vote at the Meeting in respect of the Arrangement. See “The Arrangement – Securityholder 
and Court Approvals – Securityholder Approval”.
Golden Replacement Options
The  Golden  Replacement  Options  will  be  issued  pursuant  to  the  Golden  Replacement  Option  Plan.  Pursuant  to  the 
Arrangement,  ECU  Optionholders  will  receive  Golden  Replacement  Options  in  replacement  of  their  outstanding  ECU 
Options, in respect of which the number of underlying shares of Golden Stock, the expiry date and the exercise price shall 
be  determined  in  accordance  with  the  Plan  of  Arrangement  (see  “The  Arrangement  –  Terms  of  the  Arrangement”  for 
details).    The  terms  and  conditions  otherwise  applicable  to  Golden  Replacement  Options  shall  be  those  set  forth  in  the 
Golden Replacement Option Plan, which terms and conditions shall be substantially the same as those of the ECU Stock 
Option  Plan  (summarized  immediately  above  under  the  subheading  “ECU  Options”),  except  for  such  changes  as  are 
required  under  applicable  Law  or  stock  exchange  rules  and  such  changes  as  are  contemplated  by  the  Arrangement 
Agreement (including that Golden Replacement Options shall be exercisable for shares of Golden Stock as opposed to ECU 
Shares).  The  Golden  Replacement  Option  Plan  will  be  established  solely  for  the  purpose  of  issuing  and  governing  the 
Golden Replacement Options pursuant to the Arrangement; thereafter, no additional Golden Replacement Options will be 
granted pursuant to the Golden Replacement Option Plan.

Each whole February 2009 Warrant entitles its holder to acquire, subject to adjustment as summarized below, one ECU 
Share at an exercise price of Cdn$0.95 on or before 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) on February 20, 2014, after which time the 
February 2009 Warrant will be void and of no value.
The February 2009 Warrant Indenture provides that the share ratio and exercise price of the February 2009 Warrants are 
subject  to  adjustment  in  the  event  of  a  subdivision  or  consolidation  of  the  ECU  Shares.  The  February  2009  Warrant 
Indenture  also  provides  that  if  there  is  (a)  any  reclassification  or  change  of  the  ECU  Shares,  (b)  any  consolidation, 
amalgamation, arrangement or other business combination of ECU resulting in any reclassification or change of the ECU 
Shares into other shares, or (c) any sale, lease, exchange or transfer of the assets of ECU as an entirety or substantially as an 
entirety to another entity, then each holder of a February 2009 Warrant which is thereafter exercised shall receive, in lieu of 
ECU Shares, the kind and number or amount of other securities or property which such holder would have been entitled to 
receive as a result of such event if such holder had exercised the February 2009 Warrants prior to the event.
ECU also covenants in the February 2009 Warrant Indenture that, during the period in which the February 2009 Warrants 
are  exercisable,  it  will  give  notice  to  holders  of  February  2009  Warrants  of  certain  stated  events,  including  events  that 
would result in an adjustment to the exercise price of the February 2009 Warrants or the number of ECU Shares issuable 
upon exercise of the February 2009 Warrants, at least 14 days prior to the record date or effective date, as the case may be, 
of such events.
No  fractional  ECU  Shares  are  issuable  upon  the  exercise  of  any  February  2009  Warrants,  and  no  cash  or  other 
consideration will be paid in lieu of fractional shares. Holders of February 2009 Warrants do not have any voting or pre-
emptive rights or any other rights which a holder of ECU Shares would have, except that such holders will have the right to 
vote  at  the  Meeting  in  respect  of  the  Arrangement.  See  “The  Arrangement  –  Securityholder  and  Court  Approvals  –
Securityholder Approval”.
The  transfer  agent  and  registrar  for  the  February  2009  Warrants  is  Computershare  at  its  principal  offices  in  Montreal,

COMPARISON OF SHAREHOLDER RIGHTS UNDER THE QBCA AND DELAWARE LAW
Upon completion of the Arrangement, ECU Shareholders will no longer be shareholders of ECU  and  will  instead  hold 
shares of Golden Stock. Quebec Law and ECU’s articles of incorporation and by-laws govern ECU and its relations 
with its shareholders. Delaware Law and Golden’s certificate of incorporation and by-laws  govern Golden (and will 
govern the Combined Company) and its relations with its stockholders.
Although  the  rights  and  privileges  of  stockholders  of  a  Delaware  corporation  are,  in  many  instances, 
comparable to those of shareholders of a corporation organized under the QBCA, there are several differences. Attached 
at Appendix H to this Circular is a summary of the material differences in the rights of holders of ECU Shares and 
holders of shares of Golden Stock. These differences arise from the differences between the General Corporation Law of 
the State of Delaware  (the  “DGCL”)  and  the  QBCA  and  between  the  ECU  articles  of  incorporation  and  by-
laws and Golden’s certificate of incorporation and by-laws. This summary included at Appendix H is not intended to be 
complete and is qualified in its entirety by reference to the DGCL, the QBCA and the governing corporate instruments of 
ECU and Golden.

Floor,  Toronto,  Ontario,  Canada  M5E  1B8.  ECU’s  operations  office  is  located  at  Rio  Támesis  No. 2505,  Col.  Las 
Magdalenas, Torréon, Coahuila, Mexico 27010. ECU has three Mexican-incorporated subsidiaries: BLM Minera Mexicana 
S.A  de  C.V.,  Minera  William  S.A  de  C.V.  and  Minera  Labri  S.A  de  C.V.  ECU owns  all  of  the  shares  of  each  of  its 
subsidiaries, save  for one share of BLM Minera Mexicana S.A de C.V., one  share of  Minera William S.A de C.V. and 
thirteen shares of Minera Labri S.A de C.V., all of which are registered in the name of Michel Roy, the Chairman and Chief 
Executive Officer of ECU.   Michel Roy  will be transferring these shares in the  name  of the  Combined Company or of 
entities under its control prior to the Effective Date.
Overview
ECU is a Canadian-based mining company, actively engaged in gold, silver, lead and zinc exploration, mining and milling 
since 1997. ECU has a cluster of five mines in the historically prolific Velardeña Mining District of Central Mexico, where 
it has had a series of major discoveries.
ECU  has  three  major  properties  within  close  proximity  comprising  the  Velardeña  District  Properties.  These  are  the 
Velardeña Property, the Chicago Property and the San Diego Property (a 50% joint venture). The properties are located in 
Durango  State,  central  Mexico,  situated  approximately  95  kilometres  south-southwest  of  the  city  of  Torreón,  Coahuila 
State, and 140 kilometres northeast of the state capital Durango.
The MICON ECU Technical Report identifies a measured and indicated resource of 4 million tonnes containing 40 million 
ounces  of  silver-equivalent  and  an  inferred  resource  of  26  million  tonnes  containing  391  million  ounces  of  silver-
equivalent. ECU mines mineralized stope material from its mines and treats them at its wholly owned milling facilities.
ECU  has  a  340  tonne  per  day  flotation  mill  (the  “Sulphide  Mill”)  in  the  Village  of  Velardeña,  where  it  treats  its 
mineralized sulphide material to generate a lead/silver concentrate, a zinc concentrate, and a pyrite/gold concentrate. ECU 
also  owns  a  500  tonne  per  day  cyanide  leach  mill  (the  “Oxide  Mill”)  adjacent  to  the  Chicago  Property,  where  it  treats 
mineralized oxide material to generate silver/gold doré bars.
History
ECU’s  Velardeña  District  Properties  are  host  to  a  large  mineral  resource,  rich  in  gold  and  silver  and  rich  in  history. 
Historically,  the  450-year  old  mining  district  of  Velardeña  has  produced  over  500,000  ounces  of  gold  and  250  million 
ounces of silver.
In the early 1900s, the American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco) was active in the area, until low metal prices 
and political instability forced it to close in 1926. From that point up until the early 1990s, the area was operated by various 
small-scale, local miners. In 1994, William Resources Inc. acquired claims over the area. Three years later, in 1997, ECU 
acquired 93.4% of William Resources Inc.’s Mexican subsidiary BLM Minera Mexicana S.A. de C.V. which owned 100% 
of the Velardeña Property.
More recently, the Velardeña District Properties have been subject to aggressive exploration that consists of over 400 drill 
holes and over 72 kilometres of drilling. This exploration effort has led to the discovery of several new veins, as well as the 
lateral and depth extension of several existing high grade veins.

Exploration
Overview
Exploration on the Velardeña District Properties has been ongoing for several years. Major discoveries of gold and silver 
have been found through the expertise and experience of ECU’s team of senior mining professionals who have worked at 
developing and exploring  for  mineralized  material at the  Velardeña District Properties  ∀- a  known but under-exploited 
mineral bearing region in Mexico’s silver belt.
The team has established ECU as having a significant presence in precious and base metals through an exploration drilling 
program  that  has uncovered  major new discoveries. Expertise in the local geological  model of  mineralization  led to the 
discovery of several mineral-rich veins, metals-bearing skarns, stockwork zones of sheeted veins and deep seated massive 
sulphide intercepts at depth.
Location
The Velardeña District Properties are a group of three properties held by ECU within the Velardeña Mining District. The 
three properties are the Velardeña Property, the Chicago Property and the San Diego Property.
The Velardeña District Properties are located in the Velardeña Mining District, within the municipality of Cuencamé, in the 
northeast quadrant of the State of Durango, Mexico. The property is situated approximately 95 km southwest of the city of 
Torreón in the State of Coahuila and 140 km northeast of the city of Durango, capital of the State of Durango.
The  Velardeña  Property  is  located  at  latitude  and  longitude  coordinates  25  4’  34”N  and  103  41’  43”W.  This  property 
contains  the  Santa  Juana  mine,  which  has  been  the  focus  of  ECU’s  mining  efforts  since  1995,  as  well  as  the  historical 
Terneras, San Juanes and San Mateo mines.
The Chicago Property is located approximately 1-2 km south of the Velardeña Property and is centred at coordinates 25 3’ 
42”N and 103 41’ 46”. This property contains the historical Los Muertos-Chicago mine, the extension of which is being 
drilled by ECU.
The San Diego Property is situated approximately 9 km northeast of the Velardeña Property. It is approximately centred at 
co-ordinates 25 6’ 7”N and 103 37’ 19”. This property contains the historical La Cruz-La Rata and El Trovador mines as 
well as a number of other shallower shafts which were sunk on narrower veins such as the Cantarranas, Montanez and El 
Jal. The San Diego property is also subject to a joint venture agreement between ECU and Golden Tag Resources Ltd.
ECU holds the Velardeña District Properties through its Mexican subsidiary Minera William S.A. de C.V.  At present, the 
three properties comprise a total of 32 mineral concessions (20 for the Velardeña Property, 8 for the Chicago Property and 4 
for the San Diego Property). The mineral concessions in each of the properties vary in size and the concessions comprising 
each mineral property are contiguous.
Regional Geology
The Velardeña district is located on the eastern flank of the Sierra Madre Occidental mineral belt, on the boundary between 
the Sierra Madre and the Mesa Central metallogenic provinces. Most of Mexico’s high-grade silver mines are located in the 
Mesa Central province, near this contact.
The  regional  geology  is  characterized  by  a  thick  sequence  of  limestones  and  minor  calcareous  clastic  sediments  of 
Cretaceous  age,  intruded  by  Tertiary  plutons  of  acid  to  intermediate  composition.  During  the  Laramide  Orogeny,  the 
sediments  were  folded  into  symmetrical  anticlines  and  synclines  that  were  modified  into  a  series  of  asymmetrical 
overturned  folds  by  a  later  stage  of  compression.  This  event  also  buckled  the  stratigraphy  about  a  southwest  striking, 
vertically dipping hinge-line around the village of Velardeña.
A  series  of  felsic  to  intermediate  intrusive  rocks  occurs  over  a  strike  length  of  approximately  15  kilometres,  possibly 
located  along  the  hinge-line  mentioned  above.  Local  development  of  exoskarn,  endoskarn,  hornfels  and  marble  occur
- 114 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
associated with the intrusives. The mineralization at the Santa Maria Mine in Velardeña and all of the various workings on 
and around the property occurs along this trend and is spatially associated with the intrusives and related alteration.
Mineral Resources
The resource estimate in respect of the Velardeña District Properties was audited by MICON in connection with preparing 
the MICON ECU Technical Report.
Mineral resources in the measured and indicated category equal 293,000 ounces of gold, 16.1 million ounces of silver, 26.2 
million pounds of lead and 36.7 million pounds of zinc which translates into 40 million ounces of silver equivalent. In the 
inferred category, mineral resources equal 1.8 million ounces of gold, 248.1 million ounces of silver, 1 billion pounds of 
lead and 1.2 billion pounds of zinc for an inferred mineral inventory of 391 million ounces of silver equivalent.
The resource estimate is based on 46 veins and includes the sum of mineral resources from the main Velardeña Property, 
the Chicago Property and 50% of the joint venture San Diego Property. All of these properties are within close proximity to 
each other. Additional veins at Velardeña, which are well known and have been identified through surface sampling and/or 
underground workings, require further evaluation. It is anticipated that more veins exist in the Velardeña District Properties 
based on past geological mapping.
A cut-off value of US$45 per tonne (166 grams per tonne) was used for the narrow veins and was based on information 
derived from previous mining activities on the main Velardeña Property. A cut-off value of US$25 per tonne (92 grams per 
tonne) was used for the bulk tonnage vein packages and was based on previous bulk mining tests completed by ECU. In 
determining  the  silver  equivalent  value,  the  net  smelter  return  value  was  calculated  for  each  commodity  based  on 
metallurgical recoveries from the most recent tests and contracts for mineral concentrates treated from the mining activities 
on the Velardeña Property.
The Qualified Persons within the meaning of NI 43-101 responsible for the evaluation of the resource estimate are William 
J. Lewis, B.Sc., P. Geo., a senior geologist  with MICON, and Michel  Roy, P. Geo., the Chairman and Chief Executive 
Officer of ECU.
Cautionary Statements:
Readers are cautioned that there are no assurances that all or any part of the resource estimate will be economically viable 
and  although  the  information  in  this  Circular  is  based  on  the  best  available  data  ECU  has  collected  to  date,  a  material 
difference between the actual results and ECU’s expectations may arise once further exploration is completed.
Until a pre-feasibility study (within the meaning of the CIM Standards) is completed, there are no assurances the release of 
an updated mineral resource will be economically viable.
Mining Operations
ECU’s  mining  operations  are  exclusively  underground  mining  operations  where  ECU’s  team  of  experienced  miners  are 
extracting mineralized material from rich, high grade mineralized veins.
There are two principal phases of underground mining: development mining and production mining. Development mining 
is  composed  of  excavation  almost  entirely  in  (low-value)  waste  rock  in  order  to  gain  access  to  the  mineralized  veins. 
Production mining is the removal of the wanted high grade material from the underground mine leaving behind an open 
space known as a stope.
Milling Operations
ECU has two wholly-owned operating mills located close to its mines near the village of Velardeña, Durango, Mexico.
The first of the mills is a cyanidation leach plant, the Oxide Mill, with a Merrill Crowe circuit at a rated capacity of 500 
tonnes per day. This Oxide Mill is used for the treatment of ECU’s oxide resources and generates gold/silver doré bars.
- 115 -
Please contact Kingsdale Shareholder Services Inc. at 1-877-659-1819
if you have any questions, or require assistance completing your Proxy.
The second mill is a flotation mill, the Sulphide Mill, with a rated capacity of 340 tonnes per day that treats ECU’s sulphide 
resource.  The  Sulphide  Mill  generates  three  concentrates;  a  lead/silver  concentrate,  a  zinc  concentrate  and  a  pyrite/gold 
concentrate.
Cyanide Leach Mill
ECU  owns  a  conventional  cyanide  leach  mill  with  a  Merrill  Crowe  precipitation  circuit.  It  is  ideally  suited  to  process 
ECU’s oxide material and gold-pyrite concentrate inventory. ECU generates gold/silver doré bars from the mill which is 
sold to a third party refinery. The mill has a capacity to process mineralized material up to 500 tonnes per day.
The  mill  is  located  only  two  kilometres  from  ECU’s  Santa  Juana  mine  site  and  immediately  adjacent  to  its  Chicago 
Property. The close proximity of the mill to ECU’s mining operations gives ECU a significant advantage with respect to 
transportation of mineralized material.
The  mill  employs  a  cyanide  leaching  process  which  uses  a  cyanide  solution  to  dissolve  gold  from  host  rocks  for  later 
precipitation.  Mineralized  material  is  mined  from  ECU’s  underground  mines.  After  the  mineralized  material  has  been 
excavated, it is brought to a grinding mill, where the mineralized material is crushed into sand or smaller sized grains. Next, 
it is transported to the leaching plant where the mineralized material is mixed with a cyanide solution. The cyanide solution 
dissolves the gold from the crushed mineralized material. Next, the gold-bearing solution is collected. Finally, the gold is 
precipitated out of solution.
ECU’s method of precipitation is the Merrill Crowe recovery process where a different metal, zinc, is added to the solution. 
The added metal dissolves and causes the gold to precipitate out of solution. The precipitate is collected, melted and poured 
into a doré bar. The impurities are later removed in a refinery.
Flotation Mill
ECU owns a 340 tonnes per day flotation mill situated near the town of Velardeña which has been extensively upgraded. 
The mill has a fully operational lead/silver and zinc flotation circuit plus a pyrite/gold circuit to recover  more gold and 
silver from the sulphide material.
All the equipment necessary to operate the mills from the initial crushing circuit to grinding and then flotation is available. 
The  main  buildings  hosting  this  equipment  are  open  to  the  environment,  because  of  the  local  climate,  and  they  have 
ancillary buildings for warehousing, offices and maintenance as well as a fully functional laboratory to perform fire and 
atomic absorption (AA) assaying.
The mill treats  mineralized  material  which has been collected from ECU’s  mines. Lead/silver and zinc concentrates are 
generated from the mineralized material and sold to interested smelters in Mexico or abroad. The remaining material flows 
through a pyrite/gold circuit to enhance recoveries of the precious metals and creates a pyrite-arsenopyrite-gold concentrate 
that can either be sold as is, or roasted and then sold as an iron-gold concentrate, or run through a cyanide leach plant to 
recover the precious metal contents.

INFORMATION CONCERNING GOLDEN
The  following  information  is  presented  on  a  current  basis  and  reflects  the  current  business,  financial  and  share 
capital  position  of  Golden  as  disclosed  in  the  Golden  Annual  Report  filed  with  the  SEC  and  subsequent  public 
filings.    For additional  information  regarding  Golden,  please  refer  to  Golden’s  filings  with  the  Canadian  Securities 
Authorities  which  may  be  obtained  through  the  SEDAR  website  at  www.sedar.com,  and  with  the  SEC  which  may  be 
obtained  through  its  website  at  www.sec.gov,  in  each  case  under  Golden’s  profile,  and  in  particular  see  “Documents 
Incorporated by Reference”.
Overview of Golden
Golden  is  a  mineral  exploration  company  with  a  diversified  portfolio  of  precious  metals  and  other  mineral  exploration 
properties located in or near the traditional precious metals producing regions of Mexico and South America.
Golden was incorporated in Delaware under the Delaware General Corporation Law in March 2009, and is the successor to 
Apex  Silver  Mines  Limited  (“Apex  Silver”)  for  purposes  of  reporting  under  the  U.S.  Exchange  Act.    In  January  2009, 
Apex  Silver  and  its  wholly-owned  subsidiary,  Apex  Silver  Mines  Corporation,  filed  voluntary  petitions  for  relief  under 
Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. In connection with its Joint Plan of Reorganization, Apex Silver sold its interest 
in  the  San  Cristóbal  mine  in  Bolivia  to  the  Sumitomo  Corporation  (“Sumitomo”).  Substantially  all  of  Apex  Silver’s 
remaining assets, including its various subsidiaries that hold a broad portfolio of exploration properties, were assigned to 
Golden.
